definition: The quality or state of being indocile; dullness of intellect;unteachableness; intractableness.The stiffness and indocility of the Pharisees. W. Montagu.
A nitrogenous substance, C8H7NO, isomeric with oxindol,obtained as an oily liquid.
A work of art or of human industry, of an early epoch;especially, a book printed before A. D. 1500.
Peerless; incomparable. [Obs.] Spenser.
The quality or state of being imperious; arrogance;haughtiness.Imperiousness and severity is but an ill way of treating men who havereason of their own to guide them. Locke.
One who believes in incorporealism. Cudworth.
In an inscrutable manner.
In an icy manner; coldly.Faultily faultless, icily regular, splendidly null, Dead perfection,no more. Tennyson.
One who, or that which, infuses.
To put in action. [Obs.]
Within or beneath a membrane; as, intermembranous ossification.
Intermundane. [Obs.]

A series of antiphons and responses, expressing the sorrowfulremonstrance of our Lord with his people; -- sung on the morning ofthe Good Friday in place of the usual daily Mass of the Roman ritual.Grove.
A kind of tape or braid. Shak.
In an intellective manner. [R.] "Not intellectivelly to write."Warner.
To insert as in a sheath; to sheathe. Hughes.
Being, between worlds or orbs. [R.] "Intermundane spaces."Locke.
To cultivate by planting simultaneous crops in alternate rows;as, to intercrop an orchard. Also, to use for catch crops at seasonswhen the ground is not covered by crops of the regular rotation.
Unequal; uneven; various. [Obs.] Chaucer.

Incapable of being conquered, overcome, or subdued;unconquerable; insuperable; as, an invincible army, or obstacle.Lead forth to battle these my sons Invincible. Milton.-- In*vin"ci*ble*ness, n.-- In*vin"ci*bly, adv.
In transit; during passage; as, goods in transitu.
In an inconvenient manner; incommodiously; unsuitably;unseasonably.
The larva of any geometrid moth. See Geometrid.
Pertaining to, or proceeding by, induction; inductive.
An inequality.
So as not to be effaceable.
In an insular manner.
A nitrogenous compound, C7H6N2, analogous to indol, andproduced from a diazo derivative or cinnamic acid.
The quality or state of being inhuman; cruelty; barbarity.Man's inhumanity to man Makes countless thousands mourn. Burns.
That which is within; the interior. [Poetic] Mrs. Browning.
Idolatrous. [Obs.] Bale.
Not capable of being recovered, regained, or remedied;irreparable; as, an irrecoverable loss, debt, or injury.That which is past is gone and irrecoverable. Bacon.
In an informal manner.
An intermaxilla.
Act of drying in smoke.
In an incredible manner.
See Entangle.
In an insistent manner.
One who imparts.
To impregnate; to make fruitful. [Obs.]His perniciousss words, impregned With reason. Milton.Semele doth Bacchus bear Impregned of Jove. Dr. H. More.
In a manner not to be expressed in words; unspeakably. Milton.
Situated in an interaxis. Gwilt.
Ear of corn. [Obs.] Ainsworth.
Inconcocted. [Obs.]
To treat or impregnate with iodine or its compounds; as, toiodize a plate for photography. R. Hunt.
Of or relating to the English who are born or reside in India;Anglo-Indian.
The quality or state of being intensive; intensity. Sir M.Hale.
Serving to introduce something else; leading to the mainsubject or business; preliminary; prefatory; as, introductoryproceedings; an introductory discourse.
An icicle. [Prov. Eng.]
In an integral manner; wholly; completely; also, byintegration.
The act or ceremony of depositing a dead body in the earth;burial; sepulture; inhumation. T. Warton.
State or quality of being ignoble.
The state or quality of being infrangible; infrangibility.
A state of being inexplicable; inexplicability.
Unclean. [R.] Burton.
The state or quality of being ineligible.
In an ingenerable manner.

Between centers. Intercentral nerves (Physiol.), those nerveswhich transmit impulses between nerve centers, as opposed toperipheral fibers, which convey impulses between peripheral parts andnerve centers.

Unqualified or disqualified, in a legal sense; as, a man underthirty-five years of age is incapable of holding the office ofpresident of the United States; a person convicted on impeachment isthereby made incapable of holding an office of profit or honor underthe government.
To become stupid. [R.]
A place for keeping living insects.-- In`sec*ta"ri*um, n. Etym: [L.]
Not advisable.-- In`ad*vis"a*ble*ness, n.
Engaged in inspection; inspecting; involving inspection.
Pertaining to, or designating, an acid, C5H6O4, which isobtained as a white crystalline substance by decomposing aconitic andother organic acids.
To underwrite; to make insurance; as, a company insures atthree per cent.
Unquietness. [Obs.] Joye.
A chiding; rebuke; reproof. [Obs.] Hammond.
Not composite; uncompounded; simple. Incomposite numbers. SeePrime numbers, under Prime.
Not fit or possible to be recorded.
Totally surrounded with ice, so as to be incapable ofadvancing; as, an icebound vessel; also, surrounded by or fringedwith ice so as to hinder easy access; as, an icebound coast.

To lay within; hence, to insert, as pieces of pearl, iviry,choice woods, or the like, in a groundwork of some other material; toform an ornamental surface; to diversify or adorn with insertions.Look,how the floor of heaven Is thick inlaid with patines of brightgold. Shak.But these things are . . . borrowed by the monks to inlay theirstory. Milton.
See Iodo-.
To inclose. [Obs.] Fairfax.
Dried in smoke; smoked.
The state of being incommoded; inconvenience. [Obs.]
To throw out or reject as false or ungrounded; -- said of abill rejected by a grand jury for want of evidence. See Ignoramus.
A native, or one of the Scandinavian people, of Iceland.
To place or set in a diadem, as a gem or gems.
To penetrate between or within; to penetrate mutually.It interpenetrates my granite mass. Shelley.
An inward stroke; specif., in a steam or other engine, a strokein which the piston is moving away from the crank shaft; -- opposedto outstroke.
To breed; to nourish. [R.] W. Montagu.
Hindered; obstructed. [R.] Jer. Taylor.
Same as Inclined, 3.
Producing fire. [R.] Blount.
To sink or lay, as in a bed; to deposit in a partly inclosingmass, as of clay or mortar; to cover, as with earth, sand, etc.
Irrevocable. [R.]
Quality of being irreparable.
A heiress. Milman.
The quality or state of being improbable; unlikelihood; also,that which is improbable; an improbable event or result.
The branch of science which treats of fossil footprints.
Infection of the blood with ichorous or putrid substances.
Unequable. [R.] Bailey.
To lay up, as in a treasury; to hoard. [Obs.] Shak.
To unite to, or form into, a canton or separate community.Addison.
Want of precision. [R.]
In an inquisitorial manner.
I. [Obs.] Chaucer.
Resulting from, or produced by, the action of fire; as, lavasand basalt are igneous rocks.
To blame; to impute guilt to; to accuse; to involve orimplicate in guilt.That risk could only exculpate her and not inculpate them -- theprobabilities protected them so perfectly. H. James.
One who immigrates; one who comes to a country for the purposeof permanent residence; -- correlative of emigrant.
To ejaculate parenthetically. [R.] Thackeray.
Burning within.Her inburning wrath she gan abate. Spenser.
Within the thora
Between the epimeral plates of insects and crustaceans.
Convertible the one into the other; as, coin and bank notes areinterconvertible.
Not martial; unwarlike. [Obs.]
In an incorruptible manner.
Without settled determination; in a hesitating manner;doubtfully. [R.]
Unmerited. [Obs.] Charles I.
Indefeasible. [Obs.]
Insolent treatment; insult. [Obs.] "My speech of insultmentended." Shak.
The condition of an invaginated organ or part.
Intolerance. Bailey.
Belonging or pertaining to, or holding to the doctrines ormethods of, the Independents.
A South American freshwater dolphin (Inia Boliviensis). It isten or twelve feet long, and has a hairy snout.
Expressive of commund, entreaty, advice, or exhortation; as,the imperative mood.
The insertion of one or more clauses between the subject andthe verb, in a way that involves or complicates the construction.
To pay. [Obs.] Fabyan.
Imaginative. [R.] Chapman.
Unexpectedly. [Obs.]
Same as Ichnology. Hitchcock.
Pertaining to the infinite mood. "Infinitival stems." Fitzed.Hall.
Unbloody; not attended with blood; as, an incruental sacrifice.[Obs.] Brevint.
Free; not connected with the other organs.
One who, or that which, invites.
Without error, mistake, or deviation; unerringly. Glanvill.
Invincible. [Obs.] Joye.
The mixing of the food with the saliva and other secretions ofthe mouth in eating.
To wish mutually in regarded to each other. [Obs.] Donne.
In an incurable manner.
A kind of ophthalmoscope.
Pertaining to, or derived from, intuition; characterized byintuition; perceived by intuition; intuitive.

Without being known; in disguise; in an assumed character, orunder an assumed title; -- said esp. of great personages whosometimes adopt a disguise or an assumed character in order to avoidnotice.'T was long ago Since gods come down incognito. Prior.The prince royal of Persia came thither incognito. Tatler.
The act or process of irrigating, or the state of beingirrigated; especially, the operation of causing water to flow overlands, for nourishing plants.
Unmixed. [Obs.]How pure and immixed the design is. Boyle.

Not capable of expression or utterance in language; ineffable;unspeakable; indescribable; unutterable; as, inexpressible grief orpleasure. "Inexpressible grandeur." Blair.In orbs Of circuit inexpressible they stood. Milton.

To declaim or rail (against some person or thing); to uttercensorious and bitter language; to attack with harsh criticism orreproach, either spoken or written; to use invectives; -- withagainst; as, to inveigh against character, conduct, manners, customs,morals, a law, an abuse.All men inveighed against him; all men, except court vassals, opposedhim. Milton.The artificial life against which we inveighed. Hawthorne.
Falling or coming between; happening accidentally. [Obs.]Boyle.
One who imitates.
In an identical manner; with respect to identity. "Identicallythe same." Bp. Warburton. "Identically different." Ross.
The act of interlacing, or the state of being interlaced; also,that which is interlaced.
Within or between ventricles.
A thin membrane existing in the pollen grains of some plants,and situated between the extine and the intine, as in .
The quality or state of being insoluble; insolubility. Boyle.
Not dilatory. [Obs.]
Bright; clear. [R.] H. Taylor.
The quality or state of being inconsiderate. Tillotson.
Want of repentance; impenitence. Bp. Montagu.
To make pallid; to blanch. [Obs.] Feltham.
To paint; to adorn with colors. [R.] "To impaint his cause."Shak.
Leading a wicked life. [Obs.]
Want of fecundity or fruitfulness; barrenness; sterility;unproductiveness.
The act of darkening, or state of being dark; darkness;obscurity. Johnson.
The relation of freedom from the interventionof a medium;immediateness. Shak.
Unpleassantness; disagreeableness. [Obs.] Cockeram.
Same as Invertebrate.
To poison; to imbitter; to impair.

The act or process of inferring from premises or reasons;perception of the connection between ideas; that which is inferred;inference; deduction; conclusion.Fraudulent deductions or inconsequent illations from a falseconception of things. Sir T. Browne.
Unfitly; unsuitably; awkwardly.None of them are made foolishly or ineptly. Dr. H. More.
Having designs; -- chiefly used in composition; as, well-intentioned, having good designs; ill-intentioned, having illdesigns.
Isotropy.
Unconscious. [Obs.]
Contamination by illegality, as in cases of contraband goods;implication.
Capable of being changed or converted; as, invertible sugar.
Heavy; insupportable. [Obs.] Sir T. More.
Not disciplinable; undisciplinable. [R.]
In an inefficient manner.
Transpicuous within or between. [R.] Shelley.
Pertaining to, or designating, an acid, HNCS, isomeric withsulphocyanic acid.
Unworthy; undeserving; disgraceful; degrading. Chaucer.Counts it scorn to draw Comfort indign from any meaner thing. Trench.
Giving or producing light; used for illumination. Illuminatinggas. See Gas, n., 2 (a).
Not operative; not active; producing no effects; as, lawsrenderd inoperative by neglect; inoperative remedies or processes.
See Enstamp.
Idiomorphous.
Pertaining to a part of the columella of the ear, between thestapes and the mediostapedial.-- n.
One of the Infusoria.
To give inconvenience or trouble to; to disturb or molest; todiscommode; to worry; to put out; as, we are incommoded by want ofroom.
To make a dissonant, discordant noise one with another; to talkor chatter noisily. [R.] Daniel.
Unsuitableness; unaptness; unfitness; inability. [Obs.] Barrow.
Drunkenness; inebriation. E. Darwin.
The state of being indivisible; indivisibility. W. Montagu.
Divination by the heads or the entrails of fishes.
Not decipherable; incapable of being deciphered, explained, orsolved.-- In`de*ci"pher*a*bly, adv.
A worshiper of fire. [R.]
The act of sprinkling. [Obs.] Chapman.

Want of decision; want of settled purpose, or of firmness;indetermination; wavering of mind; irresolution; vacillation;hesitation.The term indecision . . . implies an idea very nicely different fromirresolution; yet it has a tendency to produce it. Shenstone.Indecision . . . is the natural accomplice of violence. Burke.
Without a placenta, as marsupials and monotremes.-- n.
The obtaining of benefice from Rome by solicitation, whichbenefice belonged to the disposal of the king or other lay patron ofthe realm.
Tightly drawn; or (perhaps) intricate. [Very rare]Like rats, oft bite the holy cords atwain, Which are too intrinse tounloose. Shak.
Pertaining to the mutual relations of States; existing between,or including, different States; as, interstate commerce. Story.
Notched like the part of a saw consisting of the teeth;serrated; as, an indented border or ordinary.
The condition or quality of being immobile; fixedness in placeor state.
The act of making inveterate. [R.] Bailey.
Farthest inward; most remote from the outward part; inmost;deepest within. Prov. xviii. 8.
Uncultivated. [Obs.] Sir T. Herbert.
Iteration. [Obs.]
To entangle as in a cobweb; to mix confusedly. [R.] Hudibras.Physiology imbrangled with an inapplicable logic. Coleridge.
One who serves an emperor; one who favors imperialism.
That branch of Christian science which treats of the methods ofsecuring unity among Christians or harmony and union among thechurches; -- called also Irenical theology. Schaff-Herzog.
Want of legal qualifications, or of legal power; as,incapability of holding an office.
In an impartial manner.
Not affable; reserved in social intercourse.
Not accompanied with excitement; as, an inirritative fever. E.Darwin.
To darken; to make black; to obscure.
The imperfect tense; or the form of a verb denoting theimperfect tense.
The state or quality of being intense; intensity; as, theintenseness of heat or cold; the intenseness of study or thought.

Having similar proportions, similar relations, or similardifferences of composition; -- said specifically of groups or serieswhich differ by a constant difference; as, ethane, ethylene, anacetylene, or their analogous compounds, form an isologous series.
In a manner or to a degree not to be overcome.
Inodorous. [Obs.] Bacon.
In an irreversible manner.
Pertaining to, or characterized by, insurrection; rebellious;seditious.Their murderous insurrectionary system. Burke.
The quality or state of being inaccessible; inaccessibleness."The inaccessibility of the precipice." Bp. Butler.
Intelligence. [Obs.] Evelyn.
The quality of being indefinite.
A white crystalline substance obtained by the partial reductionof isatin. [Written also isatyde.]

A genus of plants, several species of which have very beautifulflowers; -- so called because the elastic capsules burst whentouched, and scatter the seeds with considerable force. Called alsotouch-me-not, jewelweed, and snapweed. I. Balsamina (sometimes calledlady's slipper) is the common garden balsam.
One who makes an index.
Bearing inscription; of the character or nature of aninscription.
Carelessness; heedlessness; thoughtlessness; unconcern.
Inclosed or shut up as in a cavern. Drayton.
To reduce to bondage or servitude; to make a thrall, slave,vassal, or captive of; to enslave.She soothes, but never can inthrall my mind. Prior.
The state of being unpolluted; purity. [Obs.] Donne.
Not to be overcome by struggling; irresistible; inevitable. Bp.Pearson.The ineluctable conditions of matter. Hamerton.
A body of soldiers serving on foot; foot soldiers, indistinction from cavalry.

Not holding the faith; -- applied esp. to one who does notbelieve in the inspiration of the Scriptures, and the supernaturalorigin of Christianity.The infidel writer is a great enemy to society. V. Knox.
To bar in; to secure. [Obs.]To imbar their crooked titles. Shak.
Between or among colonies; pertaining to the intercourse ormutual relations of colonies; as, intercolonial trade.-- In`ter*co*lo"ni*al*ly, adv.
An instrument for ascertaining the strength of an indigosolution, as in volumetric analysis. Ure.
Intermediate; not final or definitive; made or done during theprogress of an action.
Not capable of being saturated or satisfied.

Not moderate; exceeding just or usual and suitable bounds;excessive; extravagant; unreasonable; as, immoderate demands;immoderate grief; immoderate laughter.So every scope by the immoderate use Turns to restraint. Shak.
The science of figures having equal perimeters or boundaries.
In an inexorable manner; inflexibly. "Inexorably firm."Thomson.
Insensibility. Bp. Hall.
The state or quality of being impracticable; impracticability.
Iodide. [Obs.]

Not pervious; not admitting of entrance or passage through; as,a substance impervious to water or air.This gulf impassable, impervious. Milton.The minds of these zealots were absolutely impervious. Macaulay.
The quality or state of being incorruptible.  Boyle.
One who forms ideas or conceptions; one who contrives. Bacon.
Quality of being ineffective.
The state of being inaquate. [Obs.] Bp. Gardiner.
That which impregnates. [R.] Glanvill.

The act or process of reasoning from a part to a whole, fromparticulars to generals, or from the individual to the universal;also, the result or inference so reached.Induction is an inference drawn from all the particulars. Sir W.Hamilton.Induction is the process by which we conclude that what is true ofcertain individuals of a class, is true of the whole class, or thatwhat is true at certain times will be true in similar circumstancesat all times. J. S. Mill.
Indivisible. [R.] Shak.
To put to inconvenience; to incommode; as, to inconvenience aneighbor.
Situated below the axil, as a bud.
One who illustrates.
Of or pertaining to interstices; intermediate; within thetissues; as, interstitial cavities or spaces in the tissues ofanimals or plants.
See Apophyllite. [R.]
A laminated, granular, siliceous rocks, often occurring inregions where the diamond is found.
The state or quality of not being consecutive. J. H. Newman.
One who, or that which, incloses; one who fences off land fromcommon grounds.
Not ready. [R.] Sterne.
A hard, earthy ore of iron. Clay ironstone. See under Clay.-- Ironstone china, a hard white pottery, first made in Englandduring the 18th century.
Of or pertaining to Idalium, a mountain city in Cyprus, or toVenus, to whom it was sacred. "Idalian Aphrodité." Tennyson.
In an innocent manner.
A cut; an incision; a gash. Derham.
The act or state of coming or falling between; occurrence;incident. [Obs.] Holland.
The state or quality of being illegible.
In the United States, a holiday, the 4th of July, commemoratingthe adoption of the Declaration of Independence on that day in 1776.
To insert, as a day or other portion of time, in a calendar.
Indefatigable. [Obs.] Daniel.
Not responsive; not able, ready, or inclined to respond.
Not pliable; inflexible; inyielding.
Not plausible; not wearing the appearance of truth orcredibility, and not likely to be believed. "Implausible harangues."Swift.-- Im*plau"si*ble*ness, n.-- Im*plau"si*bly, adv.
A sowing. [Obs.]
Not permanent.
Of a gray color, somewhat resembling that of iron freshlybroken.-- n.
Not to be returned.
Intervening space. Bp. Hacket.
In an inglorious manner; dishonorably; with shame;ignominiously; obscurely.
Interference; interposition. [Obs.] Bacon.
Invalidity; as, the invalidness of reasoning.
Denoting equal pressure; as, an isobaric line; specifically, ofor pertaining to isobars.
A name designating the East Indies, also the West Indies.Our king has all the Indies in his arms. Shak.
Want of aptitude.
Ignobleness. [Obs.] Bale.
See Yttrium.
Rising in opposition to civil or political authority, oragainst an established government; insubordinate; rebellious. "Theinsurgent provinces." Motley.
Within. [Obs.]This purse hath she inwith her bosom hid. Chaucer.
Not to be defeated; not defeasible; incapable of being annulledor made void; as, an indefeasible or title.That the king had a divine and an indefeasible right to the regalpower. Macaulay.
To breed by crossing different stocks of animals or plants.
In an indigent manner.
Not contaminated; pure. Moore.-- In`con*tam"i*nate*ness, n.
Indulgence. Dryden.
Immodesty. Sheldon.
To blow upon; to breath upon or into; to use insufflation upon.
A curve traced by the end of a string wound upon another curve,or unwound from it; -- called also evolvent. See Evolute.
Index; indication. [Obs.] B. Jonson.
See Incompatible.
In an intuitive manner.
Between phalanges; as, interphalangeal articulations.
The formal statement of an offense, as framed by theprosecuting authority of the State, and found by the grand jury.
One who importunes.
Not devoted. [Obs.] Bentley. Clarendon.
An insulating material, usually some variety of compressedcellulose, made of sawdust, paper pulp, cotton waste, etc.
To animate. [R.] B. Jonson.
The process of becoming, or the state or condition of being,incapsulated; as, incapsulation of the ovum in the uterus.
To disquiet. [Obs.] Joye.
To twist together one with another; to intertwine.
Exemption from error; inerrability; infallibility. Hammond.
Inertness; inertia. [R.] Good.
The goddess of the rainbow, and swift-footed messenger of thegods. Shak.
Incorruptible; not liable to decay. Akenside.

A white, crystalline substance, C8H7N, obtained from blueindigo, and almost all indigo derivatives, by a process of reduction.It is also formed from albuminous matter, together with skatol, byputrefaction, and by fusion with caustic potash, and is present inhuman excrement, as well as in the intestinal canal of someherbivora.
See Encyst.
Want of application, attention, or diligence; negligence;indolence.
Irritability.
Dividing into parts; crossing; intersecting.
In an inclusive manner.

Not defensible; not capable of being defended, maintained,vindicated, or justified; unjustifiable; untenable; as, anindefensible fortress, position, cause, etc.Men find that something can be said in favor of what, on the veryproposal, they thought utterly indefensible. Burke.
Illicit. [R.] Cotgrave.
Not amovable or removable. [R.] Palgrave.
Incubation. [R.] Sterne.
Without eloquence.
To let in light upon, as by cutting away branches. [Obs.]
Curved; bent; crooked. Derham.
Same as Ideogram.
Mutually visible, or in sight, the one from the other, asstations.
See Index.
So as to be inexpugnable; in an inexpugnable manner. Dr. H.More.
Inconsistency. [R.]
A rush inwards; as, the inrush of the tide. G. Eliot.
To intermeddle with the effects or goods of another.
The quality or state of being invincible; invincibleness.
Incapable of slipping, or of error. [R.]Morally immutable and illapsable. Glanvill.
The act of instigating, or the state of being instigated;incitement; esp. to evil or wickedness.The baseness and villainy that . . . the instigation of the devilcould bring the sons of men to. South.
Causing infliction; acting as an infliction. Whitehead.
To interweave. [R.]
The state of being incalescent, or of growing warm. Sir T.Browne.
Of the nature of an impediment; hindering; obstructing;impeditive.Things so impediental to success. G. H. Lewes.
without significance, importance, or effect; to no purpose."Anger insignificantly fierce." Cowper.
The final adult, and usually winged, state of an insect. SeeIllust. of Ant-lion, and Army worm.
Of, pertaining to, or resembling, an Ishmaelite or theIshmaelites.
One who, or that which, improves.
The act of interspersing, or the state of being interspersed.

Any defensive work consisting of at least a trench or ditch anda parapet made from the earth thrown up in making such a ditch.On our side, we have thrown up intrenchments on Winter and ProspectHills. Washington.
To treat disdainfully or with indignity; to contemn. [Obs.]Spenser.

The junction or connection of vessels, channels, or passages,so that their contents pass from one to the other; union by mouths orducts; anastomosis; intercommunication; as, inosculation of veins,etc. Ray.

Not perceptible; not to be apprehended or cognized by thesouses; not discernible by the mind; not easily apprehended.Almost imperceptible to the touch. Dryden.Its operation is slow, and in some cases almost imperceptible. Burke.-- Im`per*cep"ti*ble*ness, n.-- Im`per*cep"ti*bly, adv.Their . . . subility and imperceptibleness. Sir M. Hale.
Transferred by imputation; that may be imputed.-- Im*put"a*tive*ly, adv.Actual righteousness as well as imputative. Bp. Warburton.
The quality of being impressionable.
The state or quality of being imperfectible. [R.]
To insult. [Obs.] Eikon Basilike.
The act or business of gathering or collecting anything;especially, the gathering of the fruits of the earth; harvest.Thou shalt keep . . . the feast of ingathering. Ex. xxii. 16.
See Envenom.
To supply or stock with money. [Obs.]
Incapability of being mixed, or mingled.
The quality or state of being involuntary; unwillingness;automatism.
A genus of herbs, some species of which, especially the Isatistinctoria, yield a blue dye similar to indigo; woad.
Beyond memory. Bentley.

Applied to those actions, or muscular movements, which areautomatic expressions of dominant ideas, rather than the result ofdistinct volitional efforts, as the act of expressing the thoughts inspeech, or in writing, while the mind is occupied in the compositionof the sentence. Carpenter.
A fossil fish, or fragment of a fish.

To become the same; to coalesce in interest, purpose, use,effect, etc. [Obs. or R.]An enlightened self-interest, which, when well understood, they tellus will identify with an interest more enlarged and public. Burke.
To cover with a casque or as with a casque. Sherwood.
Uniform in time; of equal time; performed in equal times;recurring at regular intervals; isochronal vibrations oroscillations.

Urged or sas, birds instinct with life.The chariot of paternal deity . . . Itself instinct with spirit, butconvoyed By four cherubic shapes. Milton.A noble performance, instinct with sound principle. Brougham.
A woman who instructs; a preceptress; a governess. Johnson.
Void of understanding. [Obs.] Bp. Pearson.
Unpunished. [R.]
Natural disposition; natural quality or abilities.
Between molecules; situated, or acting, between the moleculesof bodies.
Not capable of being represented or portrayed.
Acting momentarily, or by impulse; not continuous; -- said offorces.
The act or process of intensifying, or of making more intense.
without efficacy or effect.
The African sugar cane (Holcus saccharatus), -- resembling thesorghum, or Chinese sugar cane.
The murder of an infant born alive; the murder or killing of anewly born or young child; child murder.

Not producing the proper effect; without effect; inefficient;weak; useless; futile; unavailing; as, an ineffectual attempt; anineffectual expedient. Pope.The peony root has been much commended, . . . and yet has been bymany found ineffectual. Boyle.
The quality of being imperishable: indstructibility. "Theimperishability of the universe." Milman.
Etym: [A word not fully approved, but sometimes used for theadverb ill.]
In the same place; -- abbreviated ibid. or ib.
In an inviolate manner.
In an inextricable manner.
Freedom or exemption from error; infallibility. Eikon Basilike.
The state of being inferior; a lower state or condition; as,inferiority of rank, of talents, of age, of worth.A deep sense of our own great inferiority. Boyle.
To impregnate. [Obs.] Sir T. Browne.
To invest with imperial authority, character, or style; tobring to the form of an empire. Fuller.
Inconvertibility.
To appropriate; to limit. [Obs.]He would in like manner improper and inclose the sunbeams to comfortthe rich and not the poor. Jewel.
To put in a state like paradise; to make supremely happy."Imparadised in one another's arms." Milton.
See Ichthyosauria.

A term used in designating many parts otherwise unnamed; as,the innominate artery, a great branch of the arch of the aorta; theinnominate vein, a great branch of the superior vena cava. Innominatebone (Anat.), the great bone which makes a lateral half of the pelvisin mammals; hip bone; haunch bone; huckle bone. It is composed ofthree bones, ilium, ischium, and pubis, consolidated into one in theadult, though separate in the fetus, as also in many adult reptilesand amphibians.-- Innominate contracts (Law), in the Roman law, contracts without aspecific name.
A genus of chilognathous myriapods. The body is long and round,consisting of numerous smooth, equal segments, each of which bearstwo pairs of short legs. It includes the galleyworms. SeeChilognatha.
Incapable of being reclaimed. Addison.-- Ir`re*claim"a*bly, ad
Incapable of being navigated; impassable by ships or vessels.Drygen.-- In*nav"i*ga*bly, adv.
Serving to give force or emphasis; as, an intensive verb orpreposition.
Self-worship; excessive self-esteem.
In early Christian and eccesiastical art, an emblematic fish,or the Greek word for fish, which combined the initials of the Greekwords

A family of languages, mostly of the isolating type, althoughsome are agglutinative, spoken in the great area extending fromnorthern India in the west to Formosa in the east and from CentralAsia in the north to the Malay Peninsula in the south.
Between the kidneys; as, the interrenal body, an organ found inmany fishes.-- n.
To render more grievous; to aggravate. [Obs.] Sir P. Sidney.
To incommode. [Obs.] Bp. Hall.
A hindering; a hindrance. [Obs.] Baxier.
To interest or affect. [Obs.] Hooker.
To communicate mutually; to hold mutual communication.
See Aisle.
Unsubstantial; not real or strong. "Insubstantial pageant."[R.] Shak.

Not to be persuaded or moved by entreaty or prayer; firm;determined; unyielding; unchangeable; inflexible; relentless; as, aninexorable prince or tyrant; an inexorable judge. "Inexorableequality of laws." Gibbon. "Death's inexorable doom." Dryden.You are more inhuman, more inexorable, O, ten times more than tigersof Hyrcania. Shak.
To store up; to inclose; to contain. [Obs.] Wyclif.
Of or pertaining to the individual or individualism. LondonAthenæum.
The aititude through which a heavy body must fall to acquire avelocity equal to that with which a ball is discharged from a piece.
Not conversant; not acquainted; not versed; unfamiliar.
A searcher; an explorer; an investigator. [Obs.]Searched into by such skillful indagators of nature. Boyle.
Pepsin modified by exposure to a temperature of from 40º to 60C.
The state of being insanable or incurable; insanableness.
The right or privilege of intercommoning.
Want of modesty, delicacy, or decent reserve; indecency. "Apiece of immodesty." Pope.
In an ignominious manner; disgracefully; shamefully;ingloriously.
The state or quality of being eminent; greatness; grandeur;glory; fame.
One given to the introspective method of examining thephenomena of the soul.
A division of Foraminifera, including those in which the shellis not porous.
Not opportune; inconvenient; unseasonable; as, an inopportuneoccurrence, remark, etc.No visit could have been more inopportune. T. Hook.
Capable of being insnared or entrapped. [R.] Cudworth.
In an indispensable manner. "Indispensably necessary." Bp.Warburton.

To teach and impress by frequent repetitions or admonitions; tourge on the mind; as, Christ inculcates on his followers humility.The most obvious and necessary duties of life they have not yet hadauthority enough to enforce and inculcate upon men's minds. S.Clarke.

Not efficacious; not having power to produce the effectdesired; inadequate; incompetent; inefficient; impotent. Boyle.The authority of Parliament must become inefficacious . . . torestrain the growth of disorders. Burke.
Disconnection.
. See under Iron, a.
The act of surrounding with a bank; a bank or mound raised fordefense, a roadway, etc.; an embankment. See Embankment.
Same as Identism.
Hippocras. [Obs.] Chaucer.
Not resolute; not decided or determined; wavering; given todoubt or irresolution.Weak and irresolute is man. Cowper.
One who instructs; one who imparts knowledge to another; ateacher.
That which is introduced into the body by the stomach oralimentary canal; -- opposed to egesta.
One of the Illuminati.
An alkaloid found in nux vomica, and extracted as a whitecrystalline substance.
The quality or state of being irrefragable; incapability ofbeing refuted.
Exempt; protected by inoculation.-- Im*mu"nize, v. t.
An ingenuous or naïve girl or young woman, or an actressrepresenting such a person.
In an intemperate manner; immoderately; excessively; withoutrestraint.The people . . . who behaved very unwisely and intemperately on thatoccasion. Burke.
One who importunes; an importuner. [Obs.] Sir E. Sandys.

A morbid condition due to intestinal obstruction. It ischaracterized by complete constipation, with griping pains in theabdomen, which is greatly distended, and in the later stages byvomiting of fecal matter. Called also ileac, or iliac, passion.
Between the branchiæ.
So as to incite or stimulate.
An island; -- often used in the names of small islands off thecoast of Scotland, as in Inchcolm, Inchkeith, etc. [Scot.]
Untrodden. [R.] Hudibras.-- In"vi*ous*ness, n. [R.]
Not dissolvable; incapable of being dissolved or separated;incapable oas, an indissolvable bond of union. Bp. Warburton.
Having temporary cessations; not continual; intermittent."Intermissive miseries." Shak. "Intermissive wars." Howell.
The quality of being intransmutable.
Incapable of being read; not legible; as, illegiblehandwriting; an illegible inscription.-- Il*leg"i*ble*ness, n.-- Il*leg"i*bly, adv.
The natural history of fishes; that branch of zoölogy whichrelates to fishes, including their structure, classification, andhabits.
Stimulation.
Want of being or existence.
Represented as burning, or as adorned with tongues of flame.
In an inexplicable manner.
Want of power to pass, or to permit passage; impassableness.Immeability of the juices. Arbuthnot.
Flame; blaze; a fire; a fireplace. [Obs. or Scot.] Burns. Inglenock, the chimney corner.-- Ingle side, Ingle cheek, the fireside.
Incognito. [Colloq.]Depend upon it -- he'll remain incog. Addison.
Inclosed in a cave.
A female interlocutor.
Livery of seizin.The grant of land or a feud was perfected by the ceremonyoinvestiture, or open delivery of possession. Blackstone.
Absence of virility or manhood; effeminacy. Prynne.
To fix firmly, as in cube; to secure or place firmly. [Obs.]Milton.
To knit together; to unite closely; to intertwine.
The quality of being incoincident; want of coincidence. [R.]
Intoxicated, or partially so; intoxicating. [R.] T. Brown.
The act of immortalizing, or state of being immortalized.
Want of caution. Pope.
In an indignant manner.
Pitiless; cruel. [Obs.]
Want of moderation. Hallywell.
Not discoverable; undiscoverable. J. Conybeare.
Importance; significance; consequence; that which is important.[Obs.] Shak. "Careful to conceal importancies." Fuller.
Not explosive.
To inculpate. [Obs.] Shelton.
To lie in ambush for. [Obs.] Heywood.

A morbid condition of any part of the body, consisting incongestion of the blood vessels, with obstruction of the bloodcurrent, and growth of morbid tissue. It is manifested outwardly byredness and swelling, attended with heat and pain.

Incapable of being fatigued; not readily exhausted; unremittingin labor or effort; untiring; unwearying; not yielding to fatigue;as, indefatigable exertions, perseverance, application. "A constant,indefatigable attendance." South.Upborne with indefatigable wings. Milton.
Not practical.
A poisoner. [Obs.] Beau. & Fi.

Of or pertaining to an imago. Imaginal disks (Zoöl.), masses ofhypodermic cells, carried by the larvæ of some insects after leavingthe egg, from which masses the wings and legs of the adult aresubsequently formed.
Exhibiting the prismatic colors; irised; iridescent. W.Phillips.
Not tractile; incapable of being drawn out or extended. Bacon.
Inscription. [Obs.]
Capacity for imagination. [R.] Coleridge.
Of or like ichor; thin; watery; serous; sanious.
Indigence.New indigencies founded upon new desires. South.
The quality of being inexcitable; insusceptibility toexcitement.
Not closing or shutting.
Not retentive; as, an irretentive memory.
Indeliberate. [Obs.]
The want of the quality of coloring or tingeing other bodies.Kirwan.
Without termination; admitting no limit; boundless; endless;wearisomely protracted; as, interminable space or duration;interminable sufferings.That wild interminable waste of waves. Grainger.
To write one's name, alone or with other words, upon the backof (a paper), for the purpose of transferring it, or to secure thepayment of a
Not repealable; not capable of being repealed or revoked, as alaw.-- Ir`re*peal"a*ble*ness, n.-- Ir`re*peal"a*bly, adv.
Pertaining to the ilium; iliac.
Fated to be unfortunate; unlucky; as, an ill-starred man orday.
The last, and usually the longest, division of the smallintestine; the part between the jejunum and large intestine. [Writtenalso ileon, and ilium.]
Innocuousness.
Not instrument (to); not appropriate; unbecoming; unsuitable;not specially fitted; -- followed by to or for.-- In`ap*pro"pri*ate*ly, adv.-- In`ap*pro"pri*ate*ness, n.
Ignominy. [R. & Obs.]I blush to think upon this ignomy. Shak.
Not perceived. [Obs.]

That which impedes or hinders progress, motion, activity, oreffect.Thus far into the bowels of the land Have we marched on withoutimpediment. Shak.Impediment in speech, a defect which prevents distinct utterance.
Not abstracted.
Want of exact correspondence. [Obs.] Puller.
Want of extension; unextended state.
The quality of being incessant; unintermitted continuance;unceasingness. Dr. T. Dwight.

Originating in, or derived from, the constitution of theintellect, as opposed to acquired from experience; as, innate ideas.See A priori, Intuitive.There is an innate light in every man, discovering to him the firstlines of duty in the common notions of good and evil. South.Men would not be guilty if they did not carry in their mind commonnotions of morality,innate and written in divine letters. Fleming(Origen).If I could only show,as I hope I shall . . . how men, barely by theuse of their natural faculties, may attain to all the knowledge theyhave, without the help of any innate impressions; and may arrive atcertainty without any such original notions or principles. Locke.
Not clear or melodious.
Having the legs similar in structure; belonging to the Isopoda.-- n.
Not observant; regardless; heedless. Bp. Hurd.-- In`ob*serv"ant*ly, adv.
Inward; internal; intimate. [Obs.] Sir K. Digby.
Not arable. [R.]
The act of interdicting; prohibition; prohibiting decree;curse; interdict.The truest issue of thy throne By his own interdiction standsaccurst. Shak.

One who interviews; especially, one who obtains an interviewwith another for the purpose of eliciting his opinions or obtaininginformation for publication.It would have made him the prince of interviewers in these days.Leslie Stephen.
The state or quality of not being deficient. [Obs.] Strype.
The quality or state of being inimitable; inimitableness.Norris.
In a manner that forbids alienation; as, rights inalienablyvested.

Suggestive; representing the whole by a part, as a fleet by aship, a forest by a tree, etc. Indicative mood (Gram.), that mood orform of the verb which indicates, that is, which simply affirms ordenies or inquires; as, he writes; he is not writing; has the mailarrived
The state or quality of being isochronous.
Unconscionable. [Obs.] Spenser.
Motion on foot; progress in walking. [Obs.]The incession or local motion of animals. Sir T. Browne.
Not capable of being done or accomplished; impracticable.Glanvill.
Undepraved. [R.] Davies (Holy Roode).
Of or pertaining to the iris. "Irian nerves." Dunglison.
In an immovable manner.
Same as Id.
In an indefensible manner.
Having the quality of leaning or inclining; as, the inclinatoryneedle.-- In*clin"a*to*ri*ly, adv. Sir T. Browne.
Not expected or looked for. [Obs.]
Insipid; dull; stupid. [Obs.] Milton.
One who indicts.
An interregnum. [Obs.] Blount.
To allure; to lay a bait for. [Obs.]To inescate and beguile young women! Burton.
To act as an interpreter. Shak.
One who, or that which, interposes or intervenes; an obstacleor interruption; a mediator or agent between parties. Shak.
Together. [Obs.] Chaucer.
Between the metacarpal bones.
Inestimably. Bp. Hall.
Not risible. [R.]
One who, or that which, infests.

To lay under an interdict; to cut off from the enjoyment ofreligious privileges, as a city, a church, an individual.An archbishop may not only excommunicate and interdict hissuffragans, but his vicar general may do the same. Ayliffe.
To supply with nerves; as, the heart is innervated bypneumogastric and sympathetic branches.
A pendent, and usually conical, mass of ice, formed by freezingof dripping water; as, the icicles on the eaves of a house.
A combining from (also used adjectively), signifying:Pertaining to, or designating, the characteristic, nitrogenousradical, NOH, called the isonitroso group.
Descriptive of idols. [R.] Southey.
See Encompass.
Not to be expected or anticipated. [Obs.] Bp. Hall.
The quality or state of being incommunicable, or incapable ofbeing imparted.
Not exact; not precisely correct or true; inaccurate.

Not possible; incapable of being done, of existing, etc.;unattainable in the nature of things, or by means at command;insuperably difficult under the circumstances; absurd orimpracticable; not feasible.With men this is impossible; but with God all things are possible.Matt. xix. 26.Without faith it is impossible to please him. Heb. xi. 6.Impossible quantity (Math.), an imagnary quantity. See Imaginary.
I [Obs.] Piers Plowman.
See Ensue, v. i.
One who inveighs.
Deepest within; farthest from the surface or external part;innermost.And pierce the inmost center of the earth. Shak.The silent, slow, consuming fires, Which on my inmost vitals prey.Addison.
The external occipital protuberance of the skull.
The driving of one fragment of bone into another so that thefragments are not movable upon each other; as, impaction of the skullor of the hip.
Between alveoli; as, the interalveolar septa between adjacentair cells in the lungs.
To hinder; to stop in progress; to obstruct; as, to impede theadvance of troops.Whatever hinders or impedes The action of the nobler will. Logfellow.
Freedom from thirst. [Obs.]The insitiency of a camel for traveling in deserts. Grew.
The condition of not having reached puberty, or the age ofability to reproduce one's species; want of age at which the marriagecontract can be legally entered into.
Not laudable; not praise-worthy; worthy of censure ordisapprobation. Milton.-- Il*laud"a*bly, adv. [Obs.] Broome.
Instrumental. [R.]
Sleeplessness.

A transliteration of the four constants forming the Hebrewtetragrammaton or "incommunicable name" of the Supreme Being, whichin latter Jewish tradition is not pronounced save with the vowels ofadonai or elohim, so that the true pronunciation is lost.
An Indiaman.
Generated within; inborn; innate; as, ingenerate powers ofbody. W. Wotton.Those virtues were rather feigned and affected . . . than truequalities ingenerate in his judgment. Bacon.
To interpel. [Obs.]
A device on a shield or seal, or used as a bookplate or thelike. [Written also imprese and impress.]My impresa to your lordship; a swain Flying to a laurel for shelter.J. Webster.
To stud as with stars. [R.] "A golden throne instarred withgems." J. Barlow.
Enthronement. Bp. Warburton.
In the manner of an imp.
Act of making hollow; also, a hollow; an exvation; adepression.
Indefatigableness; unweariedness. [Obs.] J. Gregory.
Unpalatable. [R.]
Repeating; iterating; as, an iterant echo. Bacon.
Want of verisimilitude or likelihood; improbability.
Conveying a hint; significant. [Obs.] Burton.
The state or quality of being infinite; infinity; greatness;immensity. Jer. Taylor.
Unseasonableness; untimeliness. [Obs.] Hales.
Between the arms.
Surreptitious; spurious. [Obs.] Dr. Castell (1673).

Coming and going at intervals; alternating; recurrent;periodic; as, an intermittent fever. Boyle. Intermittent fever(Med.), a disease with fever which recurs at certain intervals; --applied particularly to fever and ague. See Fever.-- Intermittent gearing (Mach.), gearing which receives, orproduces, intermittent motion.-- Intermittent springs, springs which flow at intervals, notapparently dependent upon rain or drought. They probably owe theirintermittent action to their being connected with natural reservoirsin hills or mountains by passages having the form of a siphon, thewater beginning to flow when it has accumulated so as to fill theupper part of the siphon, and ceasing when, by running through it, ithas fallen below the orifice of the upper part of the siphon in thereservoir.
Without effect; in vain.Hereford . . . had been besieged for abouineffectually by the Scots.Ludlow.
See Endamage. [R.]
Rendered electro-polar by induction, or brought into theopposite electrical state by the influence of inductive bodies.
Same as Inheritress. Shak.
Pertaining to, or designating, a complex nitrogenous acid,isomeric with uric acid.
The quality of being injudicious; want of sound judgment;indiscretion. Whitlock.
A writer or compiler of, or a commentator on, institutes. [R.]Harvey.
A rubbing or chafing of the skin; especially, an abrasion orexcoriation of the skin between folds, as in fat or neglectedchildren.
The sweetbread of a deer. Cotgrave.
Growing wholly under water. Gray.
Unaffected. [Obs.] -- In`af*fect"ed*ly, adv. [Obs.]

Not following from the premises; not regularly inferred;invalid; not characterized by logical method; illogical; arbitrary;inconsistent; of no consequence.Loose and inconsequent conjectures. Sir T. Browne.
To degrade to the state of a brute; to make brutal.And mixed with bestial slime, This essence to incarnate and imbrute.Milton.

Not capable of being counted, enumerated, or numbered, formultitude; countless; numberless; unnumbered, hence, indefinitelynumerous; of great number.Innumerable as the stars of night. Milton.-- In*nu"mer*a*ble*ness, n.-- In*nu"mer*a*bly, adv.
To cover with a film; to coat thinly; as, to infilm one metalwith another in the process of gilding; to infilm the glass of amirror. [R.]
To convert into a stony substance; to petrity. [R.] Bacon.
Without a port or harbor. [R.]
One who innovates. Shak.
Want of evidence; obscurity. [Obs.] Barrow.
Burnt in. [Obs.]
See Immersible.
A Mohammedan.
In an infertile manner.

Any action toward another which manifests contempt for him; anoffense against personal dignity; unmerited contemptuous treatment;contumely; incivility or injury, accompanied with insult.How might a prince of my great hopes forget So great indignities youlaid upon me Shak.A person of so great place and worth constrained to endure so foulindignities. Hooker.
Immeasurable.What an immensurable space is the firmament. Derham.
To throw or spread light upon; to make light or bright; toilluminate; to illumine. Shak.The mountain's brow, Illumed with fluid gold. Thomson.

The quality or state of being infallible, or exempt from error;inerrability.Infallibility is the highest perfection of the knowing faculty.Tillotson.Papal infallibility (R. C. Ch.), the dogma that the pope can not,when acting in his official character of supreme pontiff, err indefining a doctrine of Christian faith or rule of morals, to be heldby the church. This was decreed by the Ecumenical Council at theVatican, July 18, 1870.
Lying toward the mesial plane; mesial. Internal angle (Geom.),an interior angle. See under Interior.-- Internal gear (Mach.), a gear in which the teeth project inwardfrom the rim instead of outward.
Having the leaves so placed that the upper part of each onecovers the base of the leaf next above it, as in hepatic mosses ofthe genus Frullania. See Succubous.
The act of stuffing or filling; an overloading and obstructionof any organ or vessel of the body; constipation.
To fertilize by the impregnation of one species or variety byanother; to impregnate by a different species or variety.
To hide in a shell. [Obs.] Shak.
To question imperatively, as a minister, or other executiveofficer, in explanation of his conduct; -- generally on the part of alegislative body.
That part of theological science directly preliminary to actualexegesis, or interpretation of the Scriptures.
Want of conformity; nonconformity. [Obs.]
Hanging over; overhanging; suspended so as to menace; imminet;threatening.An impending brow. Hawthorne.And nodding Ilion waits th' impending fall. Pope.
Human exertion of any kind employed for the creation of value,and regarded by some as a species of capital or wealth; labor.
A device for opening and closing an electrical circuit; avibrating spring or tuning fork, arranged to make and break a circuitat rapidly recurring intervals, by the action of the current itself.
Quality of being instantaneous. Shenstone.

Exerting or possessing influence or power; potent; efficacious;effective; strong; having authority or ascendency; as, an influentialman, station, argument, etc.A very influential Gascon prefix. Earle.
The state of being inviolate.
The state of being indecisive; unsettled state.
The quality of being intrinsical; intrinsicality.
One who lives in the interior of a country, or at a distancefrom the sea. Sir T. Browne.
Intersected, as with veins.
Any very hard rock.
Having the gills on the sides of the body, under the margin ofthe mantle; belonging to the Inferobranchiata.
A horizontal section of a building or other object, showing itstrue dimensions according to a geometric scale; a ground plan; a map;also, the art of making such plans.
Capable of being imposed or laid on. Hammond.
One who implores. [Obs.]Mere implorators of unholy suits. Shak.
Between the planet Mercury and the sun; -- as, the hypotheticalVulcan is intramercurial.
The quality of being imprescriptible.
A dictionary of a peculiar dialect, or of the words and phrasespeculiar to one part of a country; a glossary.
An epidemic affection characterized by acute nasal catarrh, orby inflammation of the throat or the bronchi, and usually accompaniedby fever.
In an incoherent manner; without due connection of parts.
Idiocy. [R.]
An introductory act or rite. [R.]
Not equitable; not just. Burke.
Interjectional.
Absolute seignory or possession; the act of investing with suchpossession. [R.] Cotgrave.
A flowing between. [Obs.] Bailey.
Endless; as, interminate sleep. Chapman.
In an imposing manner.
Done, attempted, or said, at an unsuitable or unpropitioustime.
See Embark.
See Premaxilla.
One of the Insectivora.
Immediately; instantly; at once; as, he left instanter.
To join together.
One who inscribes. Pownall.
The quality or state of being intelligible; clearness;perspicuity; definiteness.
An entomologist. [Obs.]
One who has a legal settlement in a town, city, or parish; apermanent resident.

A picture produced by superposing a very light print, renderedtranslucent by varnish, and tinted upon the back, upon a strongerprint, so as to give the effect of a photograph in natural colors; --called also hellenotype. Knight.
To intrigue. [Obs.] Daniel.
One who, or that which, infects.
Interminable; interminate; endless; unending. [Obs.] Akenside.
Something intervening. Holland.
Within the nucleus of a cell; as. the intranuclear network offibrils, seen in the first stages of karyokinesis.
The condition, character, or practice of an impostor. Milton.
Not compliant; unyielding to request, solicitation, or command;stubborn.-- In`com*pli"ant*ly, adv.
Broken with violence.
. A combining form from the Gr. idea.
To bend; to curve; to make crooked.
Multipied an infinite number of times. [R.] Wollaston.
Want of comity; incivility; rudeness. [R.]
A passing or running between; occurrence. Boyle.
Illuminism. [R.]
Shining between.
To place in, or as in, an orb a sphere. Cf. Ensphere.Bright aërial spirits live insphered In regions mild of calm andserene air. Milton.
Want of occupation.
The quality or state of being inductile.
Lack of probity; want of integrity or rectitude; dishonesty.Persons . . . cast out for notorious improbity. Hooker.
The state of being an inmate. [R.] Craig.

Existing only in imagination or fancy; not real; fancied;visionary; ideal.Wilt thou add to all the griefs I suffer Imaginary ills and fanciedtortures Addison.Imaginary calculus See under Calculus.-- Imaginary expression or quantity (Alg.), an algebraic expressionwhich involves the impossible operation of taking the square root ofa negative quantity; as, sq. root-9, a + b sq. root-1.-- Imaginary points, lines, surfaces, etc. (Geom.), points, lines,surfaces, etc., imagined to exist, although by reason of certainchanges of a figure they have in fact ceased to have a realexistence.
Between lobules; as, the interlobular branches of the portalvein.
Possessive form of the pronoun it. See It.
Uncharitable; unfeeling. [Obs.] Shak.
The state of being endless.
To make immovable; in surgery, to make immovable (a naturallymobile part, as a joint) by the use of splints, or stiffenedbandages.
The act of impugning, or the state of being impugned. Ed. Rev.

To plungel into, under, or within anything especially a fuid;to dip; to immerse. See Immerse.We took . . . lukewarm water, and in it immerged a quantity of theleaves of senna. Boyle.Their souls are immerged in matter. Jer. Taylor.
Containing or expressing entreaty. [Obs.] Jer. Taylor.
Having no decidua; nondeciduate.
The act of infesting or state of being infested; molestation;vexation; annoyance. Bacon.Free from the infestation of enemies. Donne.
Incapable of being revealed.-- Ir`re*veal"a*bly, adv.
The state of being infeasible; impracticability.
A teaching and impressing by frequent repetitions. Bp. Hall.
Not concealable. "Inconcealable imperfections." Sir T. Browne.
An unorganized ferment which causes cane sugar to take up amolecule of water and be converted into invert sugar.
Not expressing meaning; not significant.
Making irps. [Obs.] B. Jonson.
To give invitation. Milton.
A theory of the origin of ideas which derives them exclusivelyfrom sensation.
To take by force for public service; as, to impress sailors ormoney.The second five thousand pounds impressed for the service of the sickand wounded prisoners. Evelyn.
Remaining closed at maturity, or not opening along regularlines, as the acorn, or a cocoanut.
The act of issuing, or giving out; as, the issuance of anorder; the issuance of rations, and the like.
Full of invention. J. Gifford.
A large mass of ice, generally floating in the ocean.
Like an idiot; foolish.

Not pious; wanting piety; irreligious; irreverent; ungodly;profane; wanting in reverence for the Supreme Being; as, an impiousdeed; impious language.When vice prevails, and impious men bear away, The post of honor is aprivate station. Addison.
Incapable of being effaced; indelible; ineradicable.
Not having organic structure; devoid of organs; inorganic.
A naval vessel having the parts above water covered andprotected by iron or steel usually in large plates closely joined andmade sufficiently thick and strong to resist heavy shot.
The act of inveigling, or the state of being inveigled; thatwhich inveigles; enticement; seduction. South.
Not effective; ineffectual; futile; inefficient; useless; as,an ineffective appeal.The word of God, without the spirit, [is] a dead and ineffectiveletter. Jer. Taylor.
Incalescence. Ray.
To join mutually; to unite. [R.] Shak.
One who asks questions; a questioner.
Immaterial; incorporeal; spiritual. [Obs.] Sir W. Raleigh.
In an implacable manner.
Pertaining to, having the nature of, or resembling, an insect.Howell.
Having banners.
Intentionally. [R.] Milton.
Unmeasured; unlimited. [R.] W. Montagu.

Not redeemable; that can not be redeemed; not payable in goldor silver, as a bond; -- used especially of such government notes,issued as currency, as are not convertible into coin at the pleasureof the holder.-- Ir`re*deem"a*ble*ness, adv.
To stop; to close; to make fast; as, to instop the seams.[Obs.] Dryden.
Incapable of being demonstrated.-- In`de*mon"stra*ble*ness, n.
In an ingenious manner; with ingenuity; skillfully; wittily;cleverly."Too ingeniously politic." Sir W. Temple.

A country in Southern Asia; the two peninsulas of Hither andFarther India; in a restricted sense, Hither India, or Hindostan.India ink, a nearly black pigment brought chiefly from China, usedfor water colors. It is in rolls, or in square, and consists oflampblack or ivory black and animal glue. Called also China ink. Thetrue India ink is sepia. See Sepia.-- India matting, floor matting made in China, India, etc., fromgrass and reeds; -- also called Canton, or China, matting.-- India paper, a variety of Chinese paper, of smooth but not glossysurface, used for printing from engravings, woodcuts, etc.-- India proof (Engraving), a proof impression from an engravedplate, taken on India paper.-- India rubber. See Caoutchouc.-- India-rubber tree (Bot.), any tree yielding caoutchouc, butespecially the East Indian Ficus elastica, often cultivated for itslarge, shining, elliptical leaves.
A call or summons; especially, a judicial call, demand, ororder; as, the invocation of papers or evidence into court.
Covered; -- applied to seeds which have the usual integumentarycovering.
Not reconcilable; implacable; incompatible; inconsistent;disagreeing; as, irreconcilable enemies, statements.-- Ir*rec"on*ci`la*ble*ness, n.-- Ir*rec"on*ci`la*bly, adv.
The act of whispering into something. [Obs.] Johnson.

Not relative; without mutual relations; unconnected.-- Ir*rel"a*tive*ly, adv. Irrelative chords (Mus.), those having nocommon tone.-- Irrelative repetition (Biol.), the multiplication of parts thatserve for a common purpose, but have no mutual dependence orconnection. Owen.
The quality or relations of being immediate in manner, place,or time; exemption from second or interventing causes. Bp. Hall.
To bury in, or cast into, a ditch. Bp. Hall.
Condition or quality of being incircumscriptible or limitless.Jer. Taylor.
Without reason; madly; foolishly.
Not cognizable; incapable of being recognized, known, ordistinguished. H. Spenser.The Lettish race, not a primitive stock of the Slavi, but a distinctbranch, now become incognizable. Tooke.
The quality of being integrable.
Without authority; not authoritative.
In an incomplete manner.

An adjustable diaphragm, suggesting the iris of the eye in itsaction, for regulating the aperture of a lens, consisting of a numberof thin pieces fastened to a ring. It is used in cameras andmicroscopes.
Below the orbit; as, the infraorbital foramen; the infraorbitalnerve.
To mingle; to mix; to unite; to blend. [R.] Thomson.
A method or practice of the administration of the sacrament bydipping the bread or wafer in the wine and administering bothtogether.
Internally;A lie is a thing absolutely and intrinsically evil. South.
Eating, or subsisting on, fish.

An Italic letter, character, or type (see Italic, a., 2.); --often in the plural; as, the Italics are the author's. Italic lettersare used to distinguish words for emphasis, importance, antithesis,etc. Also, collectively, Italic letters.
One of the Insessores. The group includes most of the commonsinging birds.

To shut up or place in an inclosure called a pound; hence, tohold in the custody of a court; as, to impound stray cattle; toimpound a document for safe keeping.But taken and impounded as a stray, The king of Scots. Shak.
To pledge mutually. [R.]
In being; actually existing; -- distinguished from in posse, orin potentia, which denote that a thing is not, but may be.
Unarmed; destitute of prickles or thorns, as a leaf. Gray.
Conducive; instrumental. [Obs.] Sir T. Browne.
Not trembling or shaking with fear; fearless; bold; brave;undaunted; courageous; as, an intrepid soldier; intrepid spirit.
See Umpire. [Obs.] Huloet.
Quality of being imposable.
The postero-inferior opercular bone, in fishes.
Unfading; lasting. [Obs.] Bp. Hall.
Inconvenience; trouble; annoyance; disadvantage; encumbrance.[Archaic] Bunyan.A great incommodity to the body. Jer. Taylor.Buried him under a bulk of incommodities. Hawthorne.

The quality of being indelicate; want of delicacy, or of a nicesense of, or regard for, purity, propriety, or refinement in manners,language, etc.; rudeness; coarseness; also, that which is offensiveto refined taste or purity of mind.The indelicacy of English comedy. Blair.Your papers would be chargeable with worse than indelicacy; theywould be immoral. Addison.
See Commendam, and Partnership in Commendam, under Partnership.
Situated below the eyes, as the antenna of certain insects.
Want of retaining power; forgetfulness. De Quincey.
Received into some other thing or part, as a sword into asheath; invaginated.

A solid bounded by twenty sides or faces. Regular icosahedron,one of the five regular polyhedrons, bounded by twenty equilateraltriangules. Five triangules meet to form each solid angle of thepolyhedron.
One who instigates or incites.
A performer on a musical instrument; an instrumentalist.
The act of indoctrinating, or the condition of beingindoctrinated; instruction in the rudiments and principles of anyscience or system of belief; information. Sir T. Browne.
Impudence. [Obs.] Burton.Audacious without impudency. Shak.
Incommunicative; unsocial; reserved. [Obs.]
See Inward.
The act of penetrating between or within other substances;mutual penetration. Milman.
Initiation; beginning. [Obs.] Sir R. Naunton.

One of the classes of Arthropoda, including those that have onepair of antennæ, three pairs of mouth organs, and breathe air bymeans of tracheæ, opening by spiracles along the sides of the body.In this sense it includes the Hexapoda, or six-legged insects and theMyriapoda, with numerous legs. See Insect, n.
Same. [Obs.] Chaucer.
The great flexor muscle of the hip joint, divisible into twoparts, the iliac and great psoas, -- often regarded as distinctmuscles.
An eruption of small, isolated, acuminated vesicles, producedby the entrance of a parasitic mite (the Sarcoptes scabei), andattended with itching. It is transmissible by contact.
A lessening; diminution; decrease. [R.] Ray.
Unpleasing; displeasing. [Obs.] Overbury.
Situated between rivers. [R.] "An interamnian country." J.Bryant.
The act or process of intensifying; intensification; climax.[R.] Carlyle.
A substance resembling inulin, found in the unripe bulbs of thedahila.
Contrary to the rubric; not rubrical.
Not remitting; unforgiving.
Immediateness.

The quality of being impartial; freedom from bias orfavoritism; disinterestedness; equitableness; fairness; as,impartiality of judgment, of treatment, etc.Impartiality strips the mind of prejudice and passion. South.

Not distinguishable; not capable of being perceived, known, ordiscriminated as separate and distinct; hence, not capable of beingperceived or known; as, in the distance the flagship wasindisguishable; the two copies were indisguishable in form or color;the difference between them was indisguishable.
In a vacuum; in empty space; as, experiments in vacuo.

Want of distinction or distinguishableness; confusion;uncertainty; indiscrimination.The indistinction of many of the same name . . . hath made somedoubt. Sir T. Browne.An indistinction of all persons, or equality of all orders, is farfrom being agreeable to the will of God. Sprat.
A modern term applied to animals (as a boar) when borne asraging, or with furious aspect.
Want of goodness. [Obs.] Burton.
Inquisitional.
See Emblaze.

One who or that which interprets, explains, or expounds; atranslator; especially, a person who translates orally between twoparties.We think most men's actions to be the interpreters of their thoughts.Locke.
Invitation. [Obs.] Chapman.
In echinoderms, one of the areas or zones intervening betweentwo ambulacra. See Illust. of Ambulacrum.
The quality or condition of being impassible; insusceptibilityof injury from external things.
Capable of being inquired into; subject or liable toinquisition or inquest. Bacon.
In an indefinable manner.

Incapable of being limited or bounded; immeasurable; limitless;boundless; as, illimitable space.The wild, the irregular, the illimitable, and the luxuriant, havetheir appropriate force of beauty. De Quincey.
The quality or state of being inscrutable; inscrutability.
Of or pertaining to an idealogue, or to idealization.
The person who indorses. [Written also endorser.]
The quality or state of being inalienable.
The state or quality of being incorporeal or bodiless;immateriality; incorporealism. G. Eliot.
The state or quality of being inclinable; inclination.
A female introducer.
Not capable of being extended; not elastic; as, inextensiblefibers.
Not regularly following from the premises; hence, irrelevant;unimportant; of no consequence. Chesterfield.-- In*con`se*quen"tial*ly, adv.
The nightmare. See Nightmare.Such as are troubled with incubus, or witch-ridden, as we call it.Burton.
One who, or that which, iodizes.
Want of discrimination or distinction; impartiality. Jefferson.
Not punctual. [R.]
Without violation.

One of that class of Calvinists who consider the decree ofelection as contemplating the apostasy as past and the elect as beingat the time of election in a fallen and guilty state; -- opposed toSupralapsarian. The former considered the election of grace as aremedy for an existing evil; the latter regarded the fall as a partof God's original purpose in regard to men.
In a illegal manner; unlawfully.
A leaf inserted between other leaves; a blank leaf inserted, asin a book.
The state or quality of being indispensable, or absolutelynecessary. S. Clarke.
A blowing or breathing into; inflation; inspiration.The divine breath that blows the nostrils out To ineffable inflatus.Mrs. Browning.
More within. [Obs.] Baret.
Inharmonious; unmusical; discordant. Bacon.
A proposition or device for securing peace, especially in thechurch. South.
To bathe; to wash freely; to immerce.And gave her to his daughters to imbathe In nectared lavers strewedwith asphodel. Milton.
Want of suavity; unpleasantness. [Obs.] Burton.

Apt to intrude; characterized by intrusion; entering withoutright or welcome. Intrusive rocks (Geol.), rocks which have beenforced, while in a plastic or melted state, into the cavities orbetween the cracks or layers of other rocks. The term is sometimesused as equivalent to plutonic rocks. It is then contrasted witheffusive or volcanic rocks.-- In*tru"sive*ly, adv.-- In*tru"sive*ness, n.
Incoherence.
Free from itching.
The people governed by the Incas, now represented by theQuichua tribe. Inca dove (Zoöl.), a small dove (Scardafella inca),native of Arizona, Lower California, and Mexico.

Not explicable; not explainable; incapable of being explained,interpreted, or accounted for; as, an inexplicable mystery. "Aninexplicable scratching." Cowper.Their reason is disturbed; their views become vast and perplexed, toothers inexplicable, to themselves uncertain. Burke.
Same as Funnelform.
The act of incurring, bringing on, or subjecting one's self to(something troublesome or burdensome); as, the incurrence of guilt,debt, responsibility, etc.
To become drunk. [Obs.] Bacon.
To ingraft, as a tree or plant, by the insertion of a bud oreye; to inoculate.The arts of grafting and ineying. J. Philips.
In an impulsive manner.
Inhaling; used for inhaling.
Tending to implicate.
A substance which is similar to another in crystalline form andcomposition.
Flowing with fire. [Obs.] Cockerman.
In an ignoble manner; basely.

Inflectional; characterized by variation, or change in form, tomark case, tense, etc.; subject to inflection. Inflective language(Philol.), a language like the Greek or Latin, consisting largely ofstems with variable terminations or suffixes which were onceindependent words. English is both agglutinative, as, manlike,headache, and inflective, as, he, his, him. Cf. Agglutinative.
See Endear.
To render invalid; to weaken or lessen the force of; to destroythe authority of; to render of no force or effect; to overthrow; as,to invalidate an agreement or argument.
Not accordant; discordant.
Ineffectual; impracticable. [R.] Bp. Hall.
The religion of the Izedis.
To become immortal. [R.]
The third joint of the typical appendages of Crustacea.
. In faith; indeed; truly. Shak.

The act of making timid or fearful or of deterring by threats;the state of being intimidated; as, the voters were kept from thepolls by intimidation.The king carried his measures in Parliament by intimidation. Paley.
Same as Hyosternal (a).
Not mechanical. [Obs.] Cheyne.-- Im"me*chan"ic*al*ly, adv. [Obs.]
In a imaginary manner; in imagination. B. Jonson.
See Indigo white, under Indigo.
The quality of being imperviable.
To put a coach.

Not politic; contrary to, or wanting in, policy; unwise;imprudent; indiscreet; inexpedient; as, an impolitic ruler, law, ormeasure.The most unjust and impolitic of all things, unequal taxation. Burke.
The state of being closely surrounded, crowded, or pressed, asby ice. [R.] Kane.
To have an interview with; to question or converse with,especially for the purpose of obtaining information for publication.[Recent]
A title borne by every one of the daughters of the kings ofSpain and Portugal, except the eldest.
The quality of being insusceptible of feeling, pain, orsuffering; impassiveness.
A remedy for the jaundice.

Not decorous; violating good manners; contrary to good breedingor etiquette; unbecoming; improper; out of place; as, indecorousconduct.It was useless and indecorous to attempt anything more by merestruggle. Burke.
A menace or threat. [Obs.] Jer. Taylor.
The neuter reciprocal pronoun of It; as, the thing is good initself; it stands by itself.Borrowing of foreigners, in itself, makes not the kingdom rich orpoor. Locke.
Of an isabel or isabella color.

Remission of the temporal punishment due to sins, after theguilt of sin has been remitted by sincere repentance; absolution fromthe censures and public penances of the church. It is a payment ofthe debt of justice to God by the application of the merits of Christand his saints to the contrite soul through the church. It istherefore believed to diminish or destroy for sins the punishment ofpurgatory.
One who searches diligently into a subject.
See Enchase.
Want of effervescence. Kirwan.
Mutual communication. Owen.

A contrivance for forcing feed water into a steam boiler by thedirect action of the steam upon the water. The water is driven intothe boiler by the impulse of a jet of the steam which becomescondensed as soon as it strikes the stream of cold water it impels; -- also called Giffard's injector, from the inventor.
Uniformity of physical properties in all directions in a body;absence of all kinds of polarity; specifically, equal elasticity inall directions.
Inveteracy. Sir T. Browne.
Uninhabited. [Obs.] Brathwait.
Capable of being imagined; conceivable.Men sunk into the greatest darkness imaginable. Tillotson.-- Im*ag"i*na*ble*ness, n.-- Im*ag"i*na*bly, adv.

The quality or state of being inconsequent; want of just orlogical inference or argument; inconclusiveness. Bp. Stillingfleet.Strange, that you should not see the inconsequence of your ownreasoning! Bp. Hurd.
See Exstipulate.
Not bearing anthers; -- said of sterile stamens.
A white, crystalline, sugarlike substance, obtained by thedecomposition of certain glucosides, and intermediate in naturebetween the hexacid alcohols (ductile, mannite, etc.) and theglucoses.
Not connectedly; without connection. [Obs.] Sir T. Browne.
A choking coil.
Capable of being understood or comprehended; as, anintelligible account or description; intelligible pronunciation,writing, etc.The intelligible forms of ancient poets. Coleridge.
So as not to be eradicable.

One with whom marriage is designed; one who is betrothed; anaffianced lover.If it were not that I might appear to disparage his intended, . . . Iwould add that to me she seems to be throwing herself away. Dickens.
Lying outside the visible spectrum at its red end; -- said ofrays less refrangible than the extreme red rays.
The act of separating a body from others by nonconductors, soas to prevent the transfer of electricity or of heat; also, the stateof a body so separated.
In an incredulous manner; with incredulity.
The quality or state of being inanimate.The deadness and inanimateness of the subject. W. Montagu.
One who interpolates; esp., one who inserts foreign or spuriousmatter in genuine writings.
Not embryonate.
Not associate; without a companion; single; solitary; recluse.[Obs.] "The insociate virgin life." B. Jonson.
Not congealable.
Not proportionate. [Obs.]
The state of being indefatigable.
To form an image or likeness of. [R.] Cudworth.

To fall or dash against; to touch upon; to strike; to hit; tociash with; -- with on or upon.The cause of reflection is not the impinging of light on the solid orimpervious parts of bodies. Sir I. Newton.But, in the present order of things, not to be employed withoutimpinging on God's justice. Bp. Warburton.
Not damaged. [Obs.] Milton.

The condition of being inebriated; intoxication; figuratively,deprivation of sense and judgment by anything that exhilarates, assuccess. Sir T. Browne.Preserve him from the inebriation of prosperity. Macaulay.
Mischievous; hurtful; harassing. [Obs.] Spenser.
Tending to invade; characterized by invasion; aggressive."Invasive war." Hoole.

To instruct in the rudiments or principles of learning, or of abranch of learning; to imbue with learning; to instruct in, or imbuewith, principles or doctrines; to teach; -- often followed by in.A master that . . . took much delight in indoctrinating his young,unexperienced favorite. Clarendon.
A decree of the Sultan.
Not consisting of an equal number of syllables; as, animparisyllabic noun, one which has not the same number of syllablesin all the cases; as, lapis, lapidis; mens, mentis.
Independency; the church system of Independents. Bp. Gauden.
Not relevant; not applicable or pertinent; not bearing upon orserving to support; foreign; extraneous; as, testimony or argumentsirrelevant to a case.-- Ir*rel"a*vant*ly, adv.
Identical. [Obs.] Hudibras.
Impropriety. [Obs.]
Want of celebrity or distinction; obscurity. [R.] Coleridge.
To graze cattle promiscuously in the commons of each other, asthe inhabitants of adjoining townships, manors, etc.
Incapable of being alienated, surrendered, or transferred toanother; not alienable; as, in inalienable birthright.
An inclined plane; an ascent o
The quality of being innate.
Indefiniteness; vagueness; also, number or quantity not limitedby our understanding, though yet finite. [Obs.] Sir M . Hale.
To lay in order, one lapping over another, so as to form animbricated surface.
An impassable road or way; a  blind alley; cul-de-sac; fig., aposition or predicament affording no escape.

Aryan; -- applied to the languages of India and Europe whichare derived from the prehistoric Aryan language; also, pertaining tothe people or nations who speak these languages; as, the Indo-European or Aryan family.The common origin of the Indo-European nations. Tylor.
In the thorax.
Infancy. [R.]
The state or quality of being irregular; that which isirregular.
To store in a barn. [Obs.]
Inconvenience.
The state or quality of being irresoluble; insolubility.
See Endurance.
Uncleanness; filthness. [R.] W. Montagu.
The state or quality of being inadmissible, or not to bereceived.
To pour in; to infuse. [Obs.] Sir T. More.

The mutual influence, under certain conditions, of two streamsof light, or series of pulsations of sound, or, generally, two wavesor vibrations of any kind, producing certain characteristicphenomena, as colored fringes, dark bands, or darkness, in the caseof light, silence or increased intensity in sounds; neutralization orsuperposition of waves generally.
The state or office of an imitator. "Servile imitatorship."Marston.
The act of individuating or state of being individuated;individualization. H. Spencer.
Without contents; empty; void of sense or intelligence;purposeless; pointless; characterless; useless. "Vague and inaneinstincts." I. Taylor.-- In*ane"ly, adv.
In an irretrievable manner.

An extinct genus of toothed birds found in the AmericanCretaceous formation. It is remarkable for having biconcave vertebræ,and sharp, conical teeth set in sockets. Its wings were welldeveloped. It is the type of the order Odontotormæ.
See Thalamencephalon.
A woman who invents. Dryden.
A mark or signature peculiar to an individual; a trade-mark.
The act or custom of holding an interview or interviews.An article on interviewing in the "Nation" of January 28, 1869, . . .was the first formal notice of the practice under that name. TheAmerican.
The quality or state of being insipid; vapidity. "Dryden'slines shine strongly through the insipidity of Tate's." Pope.
To render null and void. [R.] Abp. Bramhall.
In an itinerant manner.

Not permeable; not permitting passage, as of a fluid. throughits substance; impervious; impenetrable; as, India rubber isimpermeable to water and to air.-- Im*per"me*a*ble*ness, n.-- Im*per"me*a*bly, adv.
Lands recovered from the sea. Ainsworth.
Being between petioles. Cf. Intrapetiolar.
A line connecting the points on the surface of the earth wherea certain temperature is found at the same depth.
Virtually involved or included; involved in substance;inferential; tacitly conceded; -- the correlative of express, orexpressed. See Imply.
The quality or state of being irrefrangible; irrefrangibleness.
Destitute of pores; very close or compact in texture; solid.Sir T. Browne.
An isomer. [R.]
Presiding over fire; also, fiery.Vulcan is called the powerful ignipotent. Pope.

Wrought or worked in or among other things; worked into anyfabric so as to from a part of its texture; wrought or adorned, aswith figures.His mantle hairy, and his bonnet sedge, Inwrought with figures dim.Milton.
Contained between lines; written or inserted between linesalready written or printed; containing interlineations; as, aninterlinear manuscript, translation, etc.-- In`ter*lin"e*ar*ly, adv.
The quality or state of being inviolable; as, theinviolableness of divine justice.
Innocence.
To encircle. [R.] Beau. & Fl.
Inquiry. [Obs.] Latimer.
Invulnerability.
By insinuation.
Mutual dependence. "The interdependence of virtue andknowledge." M. Arnold.
See Engorge. Milton.
One who offers in sacrifice; specifically, one of a sect ofRussian fanatics who practice self-mutilatio and sacrifice.

An expression which, being differentiated, will produce a givendifferential. See differential Differential, and Integration. Cf.Fluent. Elliptic integral, one of an important class of integrals,occurring in the higher mathematics; -- so called because one of theintegrals expresses the length of an arc of an ellipse.
Want of knowledge; ignorance. [Obs.]
