Unimportant; trifling. [Obs.] "Trifling and inconcerningmatters." Fuller.
Ignorant. [Obs.]
In an invective manner. Shak.
Irrationality.
See Endow.
One who uses irony.
Breathing or exhaling incense. "Incense-breathing morn." Gray.
Same as Ixtle.
To ride over or through. [Obs.] Dr. H. More.
Situated upon, attached to, or growing out of, some part; --said especially of the parts of the flower; as, the calyx, corolla,and stamens of many flowers are inserted upon the receptacle. Gray.
Unceasingly; continually. Shak.
Not concurring; disagreeing. [R.] Sir T. Browne.
To put in, or as in, a hearse or coffin. Shak.
In an influential manner.
To graft by uniting, as a scion, to a stock, without separatingeither from its root before the union is complete; -- also called tograft by approach. P. Miler.
Boding evil; inauspicious; ill-omened. "Ill-boding stars."Shak.
In an inverse order or manner; by inversion; -- opposed todirectly. Inversely proportional. See Directly proportional, underDirectly, and Inversion, 4.
The quality or state of being irascible; irritability oftemper; irascibleness.
To inclose, as in a mew or cage. [R.] "Inmew the town below."Beau. & Fl.
The quality of being infectious.
A female impropriator.

The quality of being inefficient; want of power or energysufficient; want of power or energy sufficient for the desiredeffect; inefficacy; incapacity; as, he was discharged from hisposition for inefficiency.

Wanting any of the usual floral organs; -- said of a flower.Incomplete equation (Alg.), an equation some of whose terms arewanting; or one in which the coefficient of some one or more of thepowers of the unknown quantity is equal to 0.
Increasing; on the increase; -- said of the moon represented asthe new moon, with the points turned toward the dexter side.
To style. [Obs.] Crashaw.
Trifling. [R.] "Immoment toys." Shak.

The dissapearance of a celestail body, by passing either behindanother, as in the occultation of a star, or into its shadow, as inthe eclipse of a satellite; -- opposed to emersion. Immersion lens, amicroscopic objective of short focal distance designed to work with adrop of liquid, as oil, between the front lens and the slide, so thatthis lens is practically immersed.
In an immeasurable manner or degree. "Immeasurably distant."Wordsworth.
Ineffectualness. [R.]
One who, or that which, interposes; an interloper, an opponent.[R.] Heywood.

The condition or quality of being incorrupt or incorruptible;absence of, or exemption from, corruption.It is sown in corruption; it is raised in incorruption. 1 Cor. xv.42.The same preservation, or, rather, incorruption, we have observed inthe flesh of turkeys, capons, etc. Sir T. Browne.
Not renowned. [Obs.]
Sensibility; feeling; -- opposed to apathy. [R.]
The quality of being impulsive.
One who imposes.The imposers of these oaths might repent. Walton.

A proceeding in the nature of a prosecution for some offensagainst the government, instituted and prosecuted, really ornominally, by some authorized public officer on behalt of thegovernment. It differs from an indictment in criminal cases chieflyin not being based on the finding of a grand juri. See Indictment.
The quality of being incorporeal; immateriality. Berkeley.
The act of dashing or striking against. Sir T. Browne.
Mutual dependence; as, interdependency of interests. DeQuincey.
Between the auricles; as, the interauricular partition of theheart.
Lying or situated beneath the world.
Increase. [R.] Bacon.
Not to stimulate; to soothe; to quiet. [Obs.] Cheyne.
Same as Indigene. Darwin.
The state or quality of being interchangeable;interchangeableness.
Not applicable; incapable of being applied; not adapted; notsuitable; as, the argument is inapplicable to the case. J. S. Mill.
A line connecting or marking points on the earth's surface,which have the same mean summer rainfall.
See Engender.
A person born in India, of mixed Indian and British blood; ahalf-caste. Malcom.
Insecurity; danger. [Obs.]

A mutual agreement in writing between two or more parties,whereof each party has usually a counterpart or duplicate; sometimesin the pl., a short form for indentures of apprenticeship, thecontract by which a youth is bound apprentice to a master.The law is the best expositor of the gospel; they are like a pair ofindentures: they answer in every part. C. Leslie.
Incorrectness; want of exactness.
To make an invasion. Brougham.
So as not to be responsible.
Undisputed.
To dwell in; to abide within; to remain in possession.The Holy Ghost became a dove, not as a symbol, but as a constantlyindwelt form. Milman.
Incapable of being

Consisting in industry; pertaining to industry, or the arts andproducts of industry; concerning those employed in labor, especiallyin manual labor, and their wages, duties, and rights.The great ideas of industrial development and economic socialamelioration. M. Arnold.
Intoxicating.
By way of inference.
Not capable of being passed over; insuperable; insurmountable.
A female messenger. [R.]
Unchastity. [Obs.] Milton.
Embossed or raised work. [Obs.] Beau. & Fl.
To plunge. Fuller.
Existing or carried on between colleges or universities; as,intercollegiate relations, rivalry, games, etc.

Not communicative; not free or apt to impart to others inconversation; reserved; silent; as, the messenger wasincommunicative; hence, not disposed to hold fellowship orintercourse with others; exclusive.The Chinese . . . an incommunicative nation. C. Buchanan.-- In`com*mu"ni*ca*tive*ly, adv.-- In`com*mu"ni*ca*tive*ness, n. Lamb.His usual incommunicativeness. G. Eliot.
Dissimilar; incongruous; unsuitable. [Obs.] Cudworth.
A silver coin of Japan, worth about thirty-four cents. [Writtenalso itzebu, ichebu, itcheboo, etc.]
Between fascicles or bundles; as, the interfascicular spaces ofconnective tissue.
Of or pertaining to the interoperculum.-- n.
Intellectual powers; possession of intellect; quality of beingintellectual.
The act of baiting; allurement. [Obs.] Hallywell.
One who instills. Skelton.
To dry by exposing to smoke; to expose to smoke.
Indistinguishable. [Obs.] T. Warton.
Having power to inform, animate, or vivify. Dr. H. More.
In a manner that renders cure impracticable or impossible;irremediably. "Incurably diseased." Bp. Hall. "Incurably wicked."Blair.
The quality of being inharmonious; want of harmony; discord.The inharmoniousness of a verse. A. Tucker.
Not prejuged; unprejudiced; impartial. [Obs.] Sir T. Browne.
In a manner not admitting of being convinced.
Operation. [Obs.]
The power or character of an emperor; imperial authority; thespirit of empire.Roman imperialism had divided the world. C. H. Pearson.
Of or pertaining to islands; full of islands. Cotgrave.
One who inoculates; one who propagates plants or diseases byinoculation.

The state or quality of being immense; inlimited orimmeasurable extension; infinity; vastness in extent or bulk;greatness.Lost in the wilds of vast immensity. Blackmore.The immensity of the material system. I. Taylor.
Indomitable. [Obs.]
Entrail or inside. [Obs.] G. Fletcher.
The quality or state of being incompatible; incompatibility.

Not probable; unlikely to be true; not to be expected under thecircumstances or in the usual course of events; as, an improbablestory or event.He . . . sent to Elutherius, then bishop of Rome, an improbableletter, as some of the contents discover. Milton.-- Im*prob"a*ble*ness, n.-- Im*prob"a*bly, adv.
Silver iodide, a mineral of a yellowish color.
One who inculcates. Boyle.
One who intrudes; one who thrusts himself in, or enters withoutright, or without leave or welcome; a trespasser.They were all strangers and intruders. Locke.
The state or quality of being inexpressive.
Defenseless. [Obs.]The sword awes the indefensive villager. Sir T. Herbert.
In an inhuman manner; cruelly; barbarously.
Usefulness or agency, as means to an end; instrumentality. [R.]Hammond.
Mutual communion; as, an intercommunion of deities. Faber.

Not comparable; admitting of no comparison with others;unapproachably eminent; without a peer or equal; matchless; peerless;transcendent.A merchant of incomparable wealth. Shak.A new hypothesis . . . which hath the incomparable Sir Isaac Newtonfor a patron. Bp. Warburton.-- In*com"pa*ra*ble*ness, n.-- In*com"pa*ra*bly, adv.Delights incomparably all those corporeal things. Bp. Wilkins.

Capable of being insured against loss, damage, death, etc.;proper to be insured.The French law annuls the latter policies so far as they exceed theinsurable interest which remained in the insured at the time of thesubscription thereof. Walsh.
Within cartilage; endochondral; as, intercartilaginousossification.
Capacity of things to move among each other; as, theintermobility of fluid particles.
A peculiar substance obtained from the thyroid gland,containing from nine to ten per cent of iodine.
Overflowing. [R.] Shenstone.
Within the colon; as, the intracolic valve.
The interior curve of an arch; esp., the inner or lower curvedface of the whole body of voussoirs taken together. See Extrados.
Interpretation. [Obs.] Milton.
The state or quality of being imporous; want of porosity;compactness. "The . . . imporosity betwixt the tangible parts."Bacon.
The quality or condition of being indistinct; want ofdefiniteness; dimness; confusion; as, the indistinctness of apicture, or of comprehension; indistinctness of vision.
Mutually dependent.
Wanting the power of procreation; unable to copulate; also,sometimes, sterile; barren.
The crop, or craw, of birds.
To introduce novelties or changes; -- sometimes with in or on.Bacon.Every man,therefore,is not fit to innovate. Dryden.
Illustrated; distinguished; illustrious. [Obs.]This most gallant, illustrate, and learned gentleman. Shak.
Not crystallizable; incapable of being formed into crystals.
One given to fanciful ideas or theories; a theorist; aspectator. [R.] Mrs. Browning.

To enlarge or expand with heat; to swell; specifically, toswell up or bubble up under the action of heat, as before theblowpipe.In a higher heat, it intumesces, and melts into a yellowish blackmass. Kirwan.

Situated between the petiole and the stem; -- said of the pairof stipules at the base of a petiole when united by those marginsnext the petiole, thus seeming to form a single stipule between thepetiole and the stem or branch; -- often confounded withinterpetiolar, from which it differs essentially in meaning.
Discriminating marks; signs; tokens; indications; appearances.Burrill.
In a indistinguishable manner. Sir W. Scott.

A machine built as an induction motor and driven abovesynchronous speed, thus acting as an alternating-current generator; -- called also asynchronous generator. Below synchronism the machinetakes in electrical energy and acts as an induction motor; atsynchronism the power component of current becomes zero and changessign, so that above synchronism the machine (driven for this purposeby mechanical power) gives out electrical energy as a generator.
To produce or render extemporaneous compositions, especially inverse or in music, without previous preparation; hence, to doanything offhand.
Unpremeditated; impromptu; extempore. [R.]

Extending beyond the reach of memory, record, or tradition;indefinitely ancient; as, existing from time immemorial. "Immemorialelms." Tennyson. "Immemorial usage or custom." Sir M. Hale. Timeimmemorial (Eng. Law.), a time antedating (legal) history, and beyond"legal memory" so called; formerly an indefinite time, but in 1276this time was fixed by statute as the begining of the reign ofRichard I. (1189). Proof of unbroken possession or use of any rightsince that date made it unnecessary to establish the original grant.In 1832 the plan of dating legal memory from a fixed time wasabandoned and the principle substituted that rights which had beenenjoyed for full twenty years (or as against the crown thirty years)should not be liable to impeachment merely by proving that they hadnot been enjoyed before.
Of or pertaining to Indonesia or Indonesians.
To strike or stamp in. [Obs.] Becon.
Of, pertaining to, or like, an index; having the form of anindex.
Not refrangible; that can not be refracted in passing from onemedium to another.-- Ir`re*fran"gi*ble*ness, n.
Want of, or freedom from, responsibility or accountability.
To take into, or as into, the stomach or alimentary canal. SirT. Browne.
See Incompatibility.
To infix, as in a globe; to fix or secure firmly. [Obs.]Milton.
The quality of being inexorable, or unyielding to entreaty.Paley.
To groove in; to join in or with a groove. Tennyson.
Incapable of being burnt; incombustibe. Sir T. Browne.
To show or manifest by symptoms; to point to as the properremedies; as, great prostration of strength indicates the use ofstimulants.
A Linnæan class of plants, having twenty or more stamensinserted in the calyx.
Intolerance; want of toleration; refusal to tolerate adifference of opinion.
Valuable additions or betterments, as buildings, clearings,drains, fences, etc., on premises.
Not to be expected; inconceivable. [Obs.] "Inopinable,incredible . . . saings." Latimer.

An oily, volatile hydrocarbon, obtained by the distillation ofcaoutchouc or guttaipercha.C5H8 -- unsaturated, and used to makesynthetic rubber by polymerization. In organic chemistry, viewedconceptually as the building block of the terpene series ofhydrocarbons

An extinct genus of marine reptiles; -- so named from theirshort, biconcave vertebræ, resembling those of fishes. Severalspecies, varying in length from ten to thirty feet, are known fromthe Liassic, Oölitic, and Cretaceous formations.
Impregnable. [Obs.]
To interrupt, break in upon, or intercede with. [Obs.]I am interpelled by many businesses. Howell.
The view that the sanction of truth is its utility, or thattruth is genuine only in so far as it is a valuable instrument. --In`stru*men"tal*ist, n.
Of or pertaining to idealists or their theories.
Having a tendency to flow in; having influence; influential.[R.] Holdsworth.
Resembling a series of dovetails; -- said of a line ofdivision, such as the border of an ordinary.
Pertaining to insurrection; consisting in insurrection.
To create within. [R.]

That can not be successfully resisted or opposed; superior toopposition; resistless; overpowering; as, an irresistible attraction.An irresistible law of our nature impels us to seek happiness. J. M.Mason.
Not susceptible of excitement; dull; lifeless; torpid.
The quality of being inconceivable; inconceivableness.The inconceivability of the Infinite. Mansel.
One who invades; an assailant; an encroacher; an intruder.
Not complex; uncompounded; simple. Barrow.
The act of taking or putting into the stomach; as, theingestion of milk or other food.
See Enchant.
Want of adhesion.
The act of bedewing; the state of being moistened with de[Obs.] Chambers.
To guzzle; to swill. Burton.
Being within the material world; -- opposed to extramundane.
Not leviable; incapable of being imposed, or collected. [R.]Sir M. Hale.
To enter in a list, or on a piece of parchment, called a panel;to form or enroll, as a list of jurors in a court of justice.Blackstone.
To breathe or draw into the lungs; to inspire; as, to inhaleair; -- opposed to exhale.Martin was walking forth to inhale the fresh breeze of the evening.Arbuthnot.

Absence of interest in, or influence from, anything;unconcernedness; equilibrium; indifferentism; indifference.Gladstone.To give ourselves to a detestable indifferency or neutrality in thiscause. Fuller.Moral liberty . . . does not, after all, consist in a power ofindifferency, or in a power of choosing without regard to motives.Hazlitt.
Not decent; unfit to be seen or heard; offensive to modesty anddelicacy; as, indecent language. Cowper.

Absence or want of experience; lack of personal andexperimental knowledge; as, the inexperience of youth.Failings which are incident to youth and inexperience. Dryden.Prejudice and self-sufficiency naturally proceed from inexperience ofthe world, and ignorance of mankind. Addison.
Not audible; incapable of being heard; silent.-- In*au"di*ble*ness, n.-- In*au"di*bly, adv.
A depression, or inward sinking of parts.
Equal law or right; equal distribution of rights andprivileges; similarity.
Want of success. [R.] Feltham.
Infatuated. Bp. Hall.
The operation of finding the primitive function which has agiven function for its differential coefficient. See Integral.

The direction in which a body, or a ray of light or heat, fallson any surface.In equal incidences there is a considerable inequality ofrefractions. Sir I. Newton.Angle of incidence, the angle which a ray of light, or the line ofincidence of a body, falling on any surface, makes with aperpendicular to that surface; also formerly, the complement of thisangle.-- Line of incidence, the line in the direction of which a surfaceis struck by a body, ray of light, and the like.
. A form of the prefix in- not, and in- in. See In-. Im- alsooccurs in composition with some words not of Latin origin; as,imbank, imbitter.
Not eligible; not qualified to be chos Burke.
Internal; interior; secret.Didst thou but know the inly touch of love. Shak.
The quality of being impressible; susceptibility.
Not capable of being transmitted.
The quality or state of not being defensible. Walsh.
See Indecency. [Obs.] "An indecence of barbarity." Bp. Burnet.
The groin.
A magnificent species of palm (Mauritia flexuosa), growing nearthe Orinoco. The natives eat its fruit and buds, drink its sap, andmake thread and cord from its fiber.
A reddish resinous substance, obtained from indican.
Immeasurable. [Obs.] Davies.
Hardened; as, indurated clay; an indurated heart. Goldsmith.
The development of a disease from its causes, or its period ofincubation. (See below.)
Uncontaminated. [Obs.] Wood.
Not punctuate or dotted.
Not capable of being healed; incurable; irremediable.
To light up in token or rejoicing.
Admitting no return; as, an irremeable way. [Obs.] Dryden.
To clasp; to inclose.Whate'er the ocean pales, or sky inclips. Shak.
To seize; to clutch; to grapple. [Obs.] Drayton.
Between peduncles; esp., between the peduncles, or crura, ofthe cerebrum.
Incorporeality. [Obs.] Bailey.
Want of discipline or instruction. [R.]
The act or process of imbibing, or absorbing; as, the post-mortem imbibition of poisons. Bacon.

Pertaining to, or noting, equal angles. Isogonic lines(Magnetism), lines traced on the surface of the globe, or upon achart, connecting places at which the deviation of the magneticneedle from the meridian or true north is the same.
The quality or state of being incompatible; inconsistency;irreconcilableness.

Bold, with contempt or disregard; unblushingly forward;impertinent; wanting modesty; shameless; saucy.More than impudent sauciness. Shak.When we behold an angel, not to fear Is to be impudent. Dryden.
Not auspicious; ill-omened; unfortunate; unlucky; unfavorable."Inauspicious stars." Shak. "Inauspicious love." Dryden.-- In`aus*pi"cious*ly, adv.-- In`aus*pi"cious*ness, n.
The act of imperiling, or the state of being imperiled.
To wall in; to inclose. [Obs.] Ford.
Below the clavicle; as, the infraclavicular fossa.
Interest. [Obs.] Spenser.
One who intromits.
The quality of being impalpable. Jortin.

Not expedient; not tending to promote a purpose; not tending tothe end desired; inadvisable; unfit; improper; unsuitable to time andplace; as, what is expedient at one time may be inexpedient atanother.If it was not unlawful, yet it was highly inexpedient to use thoseceremonies. Bp. Burnet.
The space between two modillions.
Serving to show or make known; showing; indicative; signifying;implying.
The condition or quality of being interesting. A. Smith.
Of or pertaining to Iberia.

A short piece of instrumental music played between the parts ofa song or cantata, or the acts of a drama; especially, in churchmusic, a short passage played by the organist between the stanzas ofa hymn, or in German chorals after each line.
Hostility to images as objects of worship. [R.]
Special activity excited in any part of the nervous system orin any organ of sense or motion; the nervous influence necessary forthe maintenance of life,and the functions of the various organs.
In an competent manner; inadequately; unsuitably.
The privilege granted to lords of certain manors to judgethieves taken within the seigniory of such lords. Cowell.
Immaterial. [Obs.] Bacon.
Undivided. [R.] Bp. Patrick.
Not edited; unpublished; as, an inedited manuscript. T. Warton.
Not vendible or salable. Jefferson.-- In*vend"i*ble*ness, n.
Mutual action or influence; interaction; as, the interplay ofaffection.

That portion of the cell protoplasm which is the seat of allactive changes, and which carries on the function of hereditarytransmission; -- distinguished from the other portion, which istermed nutritive plasma. See Hygroplasm.
See Y-.
Not controvertible; too clear or certain to admit of dispute;indisputable. Sir T. Browne.-- In*con`tro*ver"ti*ble*ness, n.-- In*con`tro*ver"ti*bly, adv.
Capable of being infused.Doctrines being infusible into all. Hammond.
Something done in the meantime; interlude. [Obs.] B. Jonson.

Want of gratitude; insensibility to, forgetfulness of, or illreturn for, kindness or favors received; unthankfulness;ungratefulness.Ingratitude, thou marble-hearted fiend. Shak.Ingratitude is abhorred both by God and man. L'Estrange.
Of or pertaining to, or in the region of, the inguen or groin;as, an inguinal canal or ligament; inguinal hernia. Inguinal ring.See Abdominal ring, under Abdominal.

One who informs a magistrate of violations of law; one whoinforms against another for violation of some law or penal statute.Common informer (Law), one who habitually gives information of theviolation of penal statutes, with a view to a prosecution therefor.Bouvier. Wharton.
Not formidable; not to be feared or dreaded. [Obs.] "Foe notinformidable." Milton.

Unsearchable; incapable of being searched into and understoodby inquiry or study; impossible or difficult to be explained oraccounted for satisfactorily; obscure; incomprehensible; as, aninscrutable design or event.'T is not in man To yield a reason for the will of Heaven Which isinscrutable. Beau. & Fl.Waiving a question so inscrutable as this. De Quincey.

One who interlopes; one who interlopes; one who unlawfullyintrudes upon a property, a station, or an office; one who interfereswrongfully or officiously.The untrained man, . . . the interloper as to the professions. I.Taylor.
To plead against each other, or go to trial between themselves,as the claimants in an in an interpleader. See Interpleader. [Writtenalso enterplead.]
The office or function of an internuncio. Richardson.
Cleaving or sticking like wax. Cotgrave.
Offhand; without previous study; extemporaneous; extempore; as,an impromptu verse.
One who lies in ambush. [Obs.] Barrow.
A movement in tactics by which the order of companies in lineis inverted, the right being on the left, the left on the right, andso on.
Not sensitive; wanting sensation, or wanting acute sensibility.Tillotson. Ruskin.
Pertaining to, of the nature of, or characterized by,intercession; interceding; as, intercessory prayer.
Quartation.
See Emboss.
To work in or within.
See Embargo.
Done by intention or design; intended; designed; as, the actwas intentional, not accidental.
. See Iso-.

One who lives in the same house or apartment with another; afellow lodger; esp.,one of the occupants of an asylum, hospital, orprison; by extension, one who occupies or lodges in any place ordwelling.So spake the enemy of mankind, inclos'd In serpent, inmate bad.Milton.
In an intentional manner; with intention; by design; ofpurpose.
Between the metatarsal bones.
Deficient in manhood; unmanly; effeminate. Lowell.
Not fertile; not productive; barren; sterile; as, an infertilesoil.
To move or affect strongly with passion. [Archaic] Chapman.
Intercalary.
One of the Insecta; esp., one of the Hexapoda. See Insecta.
Same as Involute.
The melting or dissolving of one thing into another.
To converse. [Obs.] Carew.
Unable to restrain natural evacuations.
Weakening; annulling, or tending to make void. [Obs.]
An instrument for measuring small movements, distances, ordisplacements by means of the interference of two beams of light; --called also refractometer.
Not producing fruit; unfruitful; unprofitable. [R.] T. Adams.
One who, or that which, impoverishes.
Admitting judicial inquiry. [Obs.] Sir M. Hale.
Insatiably. [Obs.] Sandys.
Not permissible.
Unfitness; ineptitude.The feebleness and miserable ineptness of infancy. Dr. H. More.

The quality or state of being unable; lack of ability; want ofsufficient power, strength, resources, or capacity.It is not from an inability to discover what they ought to do, thatmen err in practice. Blair.
The state of being incomplete; imperfectness; defectiveness.Boyle.
The quality or state of being insuperable; insuperableness.

The abnormal reception or slipping of a part of a tube, byinversion and descent, within a contiguous part of it; specifically,the reception or slipping of the upper part of the small intestineinto the lower; introsusception; invagination. Dunglison.
Incapable of holding or containing. [Obs.]This captious and intenible sieve. Shak.
The act by which a third person, to protect his own interest,interposes and becomes a party to a suit pending between otherparties.
In a idle manner; ineffectually; vainly; lazily; carelessly;(Obs.) foolishly.
The act or practice of maliciously setting fires; arson.
Spangled with ice.Mounting up in icy-pearled car. Milton.

Not combustible; not capable of being burned, decomposed, orconsumed by fire; uninflammable; as, asbestus is an incombustiblesubstance; carbon dioxide is an incombustible gas. Incombustiblecloth, a tissue of amianthus or asbestus; also, a fabric imbued withan incombustible substance.-- In`com*bus"ti*ble*ness, n.-- In`com*bus"ti*bly, adv.
Increasing the force or intensity of; intensive; as, theintensitive words of a sentence. H. Sweet.
Formed by implosion.-- n.
Freedom from disturbance; calmness; repose; apathy;indifference.
Issuing or coming up; -- a term used to express a charge orbearing rising or coming out of another.

Wanting the legal or constitutional qualifications;inadmissible; as, a person professedly wanting in religious belief isan incompetent witness in a court of law or equity; incompetentevidence.Richard III. had a resolution, out of hatred to his brethren, todisable their issues, upon false and incompetent pretexts, the one ofattainder, the other of illegitimation. Bacon.
Contaminating with illegality; exposing to seizure andforfeiture.Contraband articles are said to be of an infectious nature. Kent.
Making an incursion; invasive; aggressive; hostile.
The doctrine that the ideas of right and wrong are intuitive.J. Grote.
In an inarticulate manner. Hammond.

To become connected by marriage between their members; to giveand take mutually in marriage; -- said of families, ranks, castes,etc.About the middle of the fourth century from the building of Rome, itwas declared lawful for nobles and plebeians to intermarry. Swift.
Burnt in; ineffaceable.Her inburnt, shamefaced thoughts. P. Fletcher.
The condition of being indigent; want of estate, or means ofcomfortable subsistence; penury; poverty; as, helpless, indigence.Cowper.
The doctrine that the soul is preexistent to the body, and isinfused into it at conception or birth; -- opposed to tradicianismand creationism.
Not to be remedied, corrected, or redressed; incurable; as, anirremediable disease or evil.
A state of being not divided; oneness. [Obs.] Bp. Hall.
Not ductile; incapable of being drawn into threads, as a metal;inelastic; tough.
To put or insert between other strata.
Of or pertaining to the region between the rectum and ishialtuberosity.
To mingle or mix together; to intermix. Hooker.
Unhealthfulness; unwholesomeness; as, the insalubrity of air,water, or climate. Boyle.
A prefix signifying Indian (i. e., East Indian); of orpertaining of India.
Imperceptible. [R.] South.-- Im`per*ceiv"a*ble*ness, n. Sharp.
Steel cast in ingots from the Bessemer converter or open-hearthfurnace.
Not apprehensible; unintelligible; inconceivable. Milton.
One who prosecutes or sues another.
One of a series of compounds containing iodine, and analogousto the chlorhydrins.
A following after; close pursuit. [Obs.] Chapman.
Not literal. [R.] B. Dawson.
The act of infracting or breaking; breach; violation;nonobservance; infringement; as, an infraction of a treaty, compact,rule, or law. I. Watts.
Prone to anger; easily provoked or inflamed to anger; choleric;irritable; as, an irascible man; an irascible temper or mood.-- I*ras"ci*ble*ness, n.-- I*ras"ci*bly, adv.
Instance; urgency. [Obs.]Those heavenly precepts which our Lord and Savior with so greatinstancy gave. Hooker.
Not stable; not standing fast or firm; unstable; prone tochange or recede from a purpose; mutable; inconstant.
The quality of being irresolvable; irresolvableness.
To make lord or master; as, to impatronize one's self of aseigniory. [R.] Bacon.
Placed between, or containing, laminæ or plates.
Confinement in, or as in, cage. [Obs.] Shelton.
The act or practice of communicating a disease to a person inhealth, by inserting contagious matter in his skin or flesh.
The act iif immuring, or the state of being immured;imprsonment.
Illiberality. [R.]
Pertaining to, having the nature of, or illustrating, anisocryme; as, an isocrymal line; an isocrymal chart.
The quality or state of being imponderable.
Internal. [Obs.] Howell.
To inclose in a hoop, or as in a hoop. [R.] Shak.
Iniquitous. [Obs.] Sir T. Browne.
Not approachable; unapproachable; inaccessible; unequaled.-- In`ap*proach"a*bly, adv.
Capable of being insulted or affronted. [R.] Emerson.
Indexical. [R.] Fuller.
Want of animation; lifeless; dullness.
Crude; unformed; unorganized; undigested. [Obs.] "A chaos rudeand indigest." W. Browne. "Monsters and things indigest." Shak.
Containing, or characterized by, insult or abuse; tending toinsult or affront; as, insulting language, treatment, etc.-- In*sult"ing*ly, adv.
Not teachable; indisposed to be taught, trained, ordisciplined; not easily instructed or governed; dull; intractable.
Between sesamoid bones; as, intersesamoid ligaments.

In Roman dwellings, a cistern or tank, set in the atrium orperistyle to recieve the water from the roof, by means of thecompluvium; generally made ornamental with flowers and works of artaround its birm.
The practice of eating, or living upon, fish.
Inexistent; not existing. [Obs.] Gudworth.
Opposed to pictures or images as objects of worship. [R.] SirT. Browne.
One who, or that which, produces ignition; especially, acontrivance for igniting the powder in a torpedo or the like.[Written also igniter.]
Capable of being increased. Sherwood.-- In*creas"a*ble*ness, n.An indefinite increasableness of some of our ideas. Bp. Law.
An identical equation.
Not convertible; not capable of being transmuted, changed into,or exchanged for, something else; as, one metal is inconvertible intoanother; bank notes are sometimes inconvertible into specie. Walsh.
In a iambic manner; after the manner of iambics.
Not organic; without the organs necessary for life; devoid ofan organized structure; unorganized; lifeness; inanimate; as, allchemical compounds are inorganic substances.
Interposition; intervention. Derham.
The quality of being invendible; invendibleness; unsalableness.
Having exactly as many stamens as petals.

The act of imprisoning, or the state of being imprisoned;confinement; restraint.His sinews waxen weak and raw Through long imprisonment and hardconstraint. Spenser.Every confinement of the person is an imprisonment, whether it be ina common prison, or in a private house, or even by foreibly detainingone in the public streets. Blackstone.False imprisonment. (Law) See under False.
Between or among continents; subsisting or carried on betweencontinents; as, intercontinental relations or commerce.
Enchanting. [Obs.] Sir T. Herbert.
To inveigh. [Obs.] Beau. & Fl.
To sprinkle or moisten with dew; to bedew. [Obs.]

Continuing or following without interruption; unceasing;unitermitted; uninterrupted; continual; as, incessant clamors;incessant pain, etc.Against the castle gate, . . . Which with incessant force and endlesshate, They batter'd day and night and entrance did await. Spenser.
The act of naturalizing; endenization. [R.] Evelyn.
One who, or that which, intercepts. Shak.
To animate. [Obs.] Donne.

Making part of a whole; necessary to constitute an entirething; integral. Boyle.All these are integrant parts of the republic. Burke.Integrant parts, or particles, of bodies, those smaller particlesinto which a body may be reduced without loss of its originalconstitution, as by mechanical division.
The state of being illiberal; illiberality.
To invoke; to call on, or for, in supplication; to implore.If Dagon be thy god, Go to his temple, invocate his aid. Milton.
The thickness of the layer or body of pigment applied by thepainter to his canvas with especial reference to the juxtaposition ofdifferent colors and tints in forming a harmonious whole. Fairholt.
To bend; to cause to become curved; to make crooked; todeflect. J. Philips.
The process of repairing broken feathers or a deficient wing.
The act or process of cutting out a portion of the iris inorder to form an artificial pupil.
In an inconsiderate manner.
Azure-colored; of a bright blue color. [Obs.] Rom. of R.
Want of susceptibility, or of capacity to feel or perceive.
An institutor. [R.]
Subjected to equal pressure from every side; being inhydrostatic equilibrium, as a body submerged in a liquid at rest;pertaining to, or characterized by, isostasy.
Having deep and sharp notches, as a leaf or a petal.

Such a mental condition, as, either from the existence ofdelusions, or from incapacity to distinguish between right and wrong,with regard to any matter under action, does away with individualresponsibility.
Having the power to prohibit; as, an interdictive sentence.Milton.
To cause to become or appear vulgar. [Obs.] Daniel.
Not in the flesh; spiritual. [Obs.]I fear nothing . . . that devil carnate or incarnate can fairly do.Richardson.
The quality of being inappellable; finality.The inappellability of the councils. Coleridge.
Flexed or bent inward.

Incapable of being passed over or surmounted; insurmountable;as, insuperable difficulties.And middle natures, how they long to join, Yet never pass theinsuperable line Pope.The difficulty is enhanced, or is . . . insuperable. I. Taylor.
A formal question or inquiry; esp. (Law), a question asked inwriting. Macaulay.
In an invisible manner, Denham.
Intermediate. [R.] Cudworth.
Not well judged; unwise.
Same as Knock-knee.

Not conclusive; leading to no conclusion; not closing orsettling a point in debate, or a doubtful question; as, evidence isinconclusive when it does not exhibit the truth of a disputed case insuch a manner as to satisfy the mind, and put an end to debate ordoubt.Arguments . . . inconclusive and impertinent. South.-- In`con*clu"sive*ly, adv.-- In`con*clu"sive*ness, n.
An impertinent person. [R.]
Indefatigable quality; unweariedness; persistency. Parnell.
Angry; incensed; enraged. [Recent]The irate colonel . . . stood speechless. Thackeray.Mr. Jaggers suddenly became most irate. Dickens.
Infected with the itch, or with an itching sensation. Cowper.
A powerful and warlike confederacy of Indian tribes, formerlyinhabiting Central New York and constituting most of the FiveNations. Also, any Indian of the Iroquois tribes.
Having the property of preventing any other substance fromoccupying the same space at the same time.
Neglect of execution; nonperformance; as, the inexecution of atreaty. Spence.
Inconsumable. [Obs.] Sir K. Digby.
The act of imbruting, or the state of being imbruted. [R.]Brydges.
One who intends. Feltham.
Sacrifices offered to the souls of deceased heroes or friends.
Without repentance.
The act of interceding; intercession; intervention. [R.] Bp.Reynolds.
A small fresh-water cyprinoid fish (Leuciscus idus or Idusidus) of Europe. A domesticated variety, colored like the goldfish,is called orfe in Germany.
Any one of a series of artificial blue dyes, in appearanceresembling indigo, for which they are often used as substitutes.
Between the cavernous sinuses; as, the intercavernous sinusesconnecting the cavernous sinuses at the base of the brain.
Want of perception.
Having little or no knowledge; ignorant; stupid; silly. [R.] N.Bacon.
Irradiating or illuminating; as, the irradiant moon. Boyse.
To glut. [R.] Ascham.
To ingratiate. [Obs.] G. Fletcher.

Anything made of iron; -- a general name of such parts orpieces of a building, vessel, carriage, etc., as consist of iron.
That which causes inhibitory action; esp., an inhibitory nerve.
To infuse by breathing; to inspire. Coleridge.
The state or quality of being imperturbable.[1913 Webster]
Want of cultivation. [Obs.] Berington.
In an irreparable manner.
The state of being involved.
Want of discovery. [Obs.]
The entrance of the moon into the shadow of the earth ineclipses, the sun's entrance into a sign, etc.
The quality or state of being inscrutable; inscrutableness.
Pinnate with a single terminal leaflet.
A state of being bent or curved; incurvation; a bendinginwards. Sir T. Browne.
Able and apt to invent; quick at contrivance; ready atexpedients; as, an inventive head or genius. Dryden.-- In*vent"ive*ly, adv.-- In*vent"ive*ness, n.
Insipidity; stupidity; dullness. [Obs.]The insulsity of mortal tongues. Milton.
To thunder. [Obs.] Bailey.
The third person singular of the substantive verb be, in theindicative mood, present tense; as, he is; he is a man. See Be.
The state of being inconsequential.
To pierce, as with a dart.
An order of birds, including only the penguins, in which thewings are without quills, and not suited for flight.
To act reciprocally, so as to augment, diminish, or otherwiseaffect one another; -- said of waves, rays of light, heat, etc. SeeInterference, 2.

Apperaing in distinct crystals; -- said of the mineralconstituents of a rock.

A bishop, who, during a vacancy of the see, administers thebishopric till a successor is installed.
Situated between hills; -- applied especially to valleys lyingbetween volcanic cones.
Act of involving, or state of being involved; involution.
An interval. [R.]And a' shall laugh without intervallums. Shak.In one of these intervalla. Chillingworth.
To make an interchange; to alternate. Sir P. Sidney.
An idealist.
The same as Isocheimal.
Covered with ivy.
Pertaining to, or designating, an acid obtained by theoxidation of convolvulin (obtained from jalap, the tubers of Ipomoeapurga), and identical in most of its properties with sebacic acid.
Tasteless; unsavory. [R.] Sir T. Herbert.
In an ineligible manner.
One of the small bones in the tympanum of the ear; the anvilbone. See Ear.
A fossil footprint; as, the ichnites in the Triassic sandstone.Page.
Pert. to the Indo-Aryans, or designating, or of, the Aryanlanguages of India.
The search for the traces of anything. [R.]
Not removable; immovable; inflexible. Shak.-- Ir`re*mov"a*bly, adv.

Not capable of being imitated, copied, or counterfeited; beyondimitation; surpassingly excellent; matchless; unrivaled; exceptional;unique; as, an inimitable style; inimitable eloquence. "Inimitableforce." Dryden.Performing such inimitable feats. Cowper.-- In*im"i*ta*ble*ness, n.-- In*im"i*ta*bly, adv.
Want of effect, or of power to produce the effect; inefficacy.
An Arctic sea bird, as the Arctic fulmar.
One versed in, or who studies, ichthyology.
One governed by indifferentism.
To introduce. [Obs.]
To fasten or bind, as with a knot; to knot together. Fuller.
Pertaining to, or having the nature of, insects. Bacon.
To thwart; to obstruct. [Obs.] Chapman.
To clear of outlawry or attainder; to place under theprotection of the law. Burrill.
To compose; to write, as a poem.Wounded I sing, tormented I indite. Herbert.
Cheat; deception. [Obs.] Sir T. Brown.
Not erratic or wandering; fixed; settled; established.
Act of entering; entrance. Sir K. Digby.
The state or quality of being irretrievable.
A variety of sugar, found in certain plants. It is opticallyinactive.
The state or quality of being infertile; unproductiveness;barrenness.The infertility or noxiousness of the soil. Sir M. Hale.

Chemistry applied to, or used in, medicine; -- used especiallywith reference to the doctrines in the school of physicians inFlanders, in the 17th century, who held that health depends upon theproper chemical relations of the fluids of the body, and whoendeavored to explain the conditions of health or disease by chemicalprinciples.
An intermediate act or decree before final decision. Ayliffe.
The quality of being importunate; importunateness.
Not artificial; not made or elaborated by art; natural; simple;artless; as, an inartificial argument; an inartificial character.-- In*ar`ti*fi"cial*ly, adv.-- In*ar`ti*fi"cial*ness, n.
The state or quality of being null and void; invalidity;forfeiture. Burrill.
Clouded; having a cloudy appearance.
An Eskimo.
To make illiberal.
One who invests.
Incapable of being mad perfect. [R.]
In an inverted order. Derham.
The state or quality of being irreducible.
The quality of being inheritable or descendible to heirs.Jefferson.
Uncivil; unpolished; rude. M. Arnold.-- In`ur*bane"ly, adv.-- In`ur*bane"ness, n.
To produce inanition in; to exhaust for want of nourishment.[R.]
Between oceans; connecting oceans; as, interoceaniccommunication; an interoceanic canal.
To prevent or hinder oxidation, rust, or decay; as, inoxidizingoils or varnishes.

Included wholly within an organ or limb, as certain groups ofmuscles; -- opposed to extrinsic. Intrinsic energy of a body(Physics), the work it can do in virtue of its actual condition,without any supply of energy from without.-- Intrinsic equation of a curve (Geom.), the equation whichexpresses the relation which the length of a curve, measured from agiven point of it, to a movable point, has to the angle which thetangent to the curve at the movable point makes with a fixed line.-- Intrinsic value. See the Note under Value, n.
To throng or collect together. [R.] Fairfax.
Capable of being inscribed, -- used specif. (Math.) of solidsor plane figures capable of being inscribed in other solids orfigures.
Not tamed; untamed; savage; wild. [Obs.] J. Salkeld.
State of being interior.
An introducer. [Obs.]
The quality or state of being intangible; intangibleness.
Of or pertaining to the iris or rainbow.
The true meaning, understanding, or intention of a law, or ofany legal instrument.
Not delicate; wanting delicacy; offensive to good manners, orto purity of mind; coarse; rude; as, an indelicate word orsuggestion; indelicate behavior. Macaulay.-- In*del"i*cate*ly, adv.
Having no issue or progeny; childless. "The heavens . . . haveleft me issueless." Shak.
To form into a band or bands. "Imbanded nations." J. Barlow.
See Enjoin.
To mention as a case or example; to refer to; to cite; as, toinstance a fact. H. Spenser.I shall not instance an abstruse author. Milton.
A line connecting places on the earth having the same meanwinter temperature. Cf. Isothere.
Fossil dung of fishes.
Not concussible; that cannot be shaken.
Hollow and distended, as a perianth, corolla, nectary, orpericarp. Martyn.

to, or containing, iodine; specif., denoting those compounds inwhich it has a relatively high valence; as, iodic acid. Iodic acid, amonobasic acid, consisting of iodine with three parts of oxygen andone of hydrogen.
Ischial. [R.] Ischiadic passion or disease (Med.), a rheumaticor neuralgic affection of some part about the hip joint; -- calledalso sciatica.
Branded with infamy by conviction of a crime; as, at commonlaw, an infamous person can not be a witness.
Not diligent; idle; slothful. [Obs.] Feltham.-- In*dil"i*gent*ly, adv. [Obs.]
See Enhance.
Quality of being immovable.
Not reflective. De Quincey.
Of or pertaining to isography.
Without corruption.To demean themselves incorruptly. Milton.
Capable of being impugned; that may be gainsaid.
To inter. [R.] Southey.
Having the two webs equal in breath; -- said of feathers.
Insinuative.
Having the quality of isodimorphism.
The variation or change which words undergo to mark case,gender, number, comparison, tense, person, mood, voice, etc.

The entrance of an enemy into a country with purposes ofhostility; a sudden or desultory incursion or invasion; raid;encroachment.The loss of Shrewsbury exposed all North Wales to the daily inroadsof the enemy. Clarendon.With perpetual inroads to alarm, Though inaccessible, his fatalthrone. Milton.
Uncivil; rude. [Obs.] Shak.
Embodied in, or changed into, water. [Obs.] Cranmer.

One who inspects, views, or oversees; one to whom thesupervision of any work is committed; one who makes an official viewor examination, as a military or civil officer; a superintendent; asupervisor; an overseer. Inspector general (Mil.), a staff officer ofan army, whose duties are those of inspection, and embrace everythingrelative to organization, recruiting, discharge, administration,accountability for money and property, instruction, police, anddiscipline.
The quality or state of being irresolvable; irresolvability.
Situated below the point where a leaf joins the stem.
To wet or moisten; to soak; to drench, especially in blood.While Darwen stream, will blood of Scots imbrued. Milton.
Want of expertness or skill.
Not possibly. Sir. T. North.
One who idolizes or loves to the point of reverence; anidolater.
One who inaugurates.
A wall; an inclosure. [Obs.] Shak.
Entering; penetrating.
By infinitesimals; in infinitely small quantities; in aninfinitesimal degree.

A commander; a leader; an emperor; -- originally an appellationof honor by which Roman soldiers saluted their general after animportant victory. Subsequently the title was conferred as arecognition of great military achievements by the senate, whence itcarried wiht it some special privileges. After the downfall of theRepublic it was assumed by Augustus and his successors, and came tohave the meaning now attached to the word emperor.
Want of locality or place. [R.] Cudworth.

To invade; to encroach; to infringe or trespass; to enter on,and take possession of, that which belongs to another; -- usuallyfollowed by on or upon; as, the king was charged with intrenching onthe rights of the nobles, and the nobles were accused of intrenchingon the prerogative of the crown.We are not to intrench upon truth in any conversation, but least ofall with children. Locke.

The part or faculty of the human soul by which it knows, asdistinguished from the power to feel and to will; sometimes, thecapacity for higher forms of knowledge, as distinguished from thepower to perceive objects in their relations; the power to judge andcomprehend; the thinking faculty; the understanding.
The quality or state of being irrepealable.
To make, or tend to make (the motion of a moving body), uniformin rate of rotation, or in frequency of vibration.
One who inquires or examines; questioner; investigator. Locke.Expert inquirers after truth. Cowper.
Insolence. [R.] Evelyn.
Inimical; unfriendly. [R.] Sterne.
Intercepting or tending to intercept.
One who imprisons.
Use; practice; discipline; habit; custom.
Natural gift or talent; ability; wit; ingenuity. [Obs.][Written also ingenie.] Becon.

A writ or process, granted by a court of equity, and, insomecases, under statutes, by a court of law,whereby a party is requiredto do or to refrain from doing certain acts, according to theexigency of the writ.
To link together; to unite closely or firmly, as by a chain.Two bosoms interchained with an oath. Shak.
Incapable of being divided by cutting; indivisible.

Embodiment in bread; the supposed real presence and union ofChrist's material body and blood with the substance of the elementsof the eucharist without a change in their nature; -- distinguishedfrom transubstantiation, which supposes a miraculous change of thesubstance of the elements. It is akin to consubstantiation.
To form into fire. [R.] Stukeley.
A South African bulbous plant of the Iris family, remarkablefor the brilliancy of its flowers.
By implication. Sir G. Buck.
The division of a shield palewise, or by a vertical line, esp.for the purpose of putting side by side the arms of husband and wife.See Impale, 3.
One who implores.
Admitting of interpretation; capable of being interpreted orexplained.
Adding intensity; intensifying.
Lying between walls; inclosed by walls.

To fix and settle by long continuance. [Obs.] Bacon.
A mania or infatuation for icons, whether as objects ofdevotion, bric-a-brac, or curios.
The representation of ideas independently of sounds, or in anideographic manner, as sometimes is done in shorthand writing, etc.

The doctrine that external bodies may be reduced to mind andideas in a mind; any doctrine opposed to materialism orphenomenalism, esp. a system that maintains the immateriality of thesoul; idealism; esp., Bishop Berkeley's theory of idealism.
The space between two nodes or points of the stem from whichthe leaves properly arise. H. Spenser.
To make irregular; to disorder. [Obs.] Sir T. Browne.
A native of Ireland who has become an American citizen; also, achild or descendant of such a person.
One who is insolvent; as insolvent debtor; -- in England,before 1861, especially applied to persons not traders. Bouvier.
To incorporate. [R.] Shak.

An account, catalogue, or schedule, made by an executor oradministrator, of all the goods and chattels, and sometimes of thereal estate, of a deceased person; a list of the property of which aperson or estate is found to be possessed; hence, an itemized list ofgoods or valuables, with their estimated worth; specifically, theannual account of stock taken in any business.There take an inventory of all I have. Shak.
The act of smearing or covering with wax. B. Jonson.

A genus of Asiatic and American magnoliaceous trees, havingstar-shaped fruit; star anise. The fruit of Illicium anisatum is usedas a spice in India, and its oil is largely used in Europe forflavoring cordials, being almost identical with true oil of anise.
Mutual comparison of corresponding parts.
The duykerbok.

Pertaining to, derived from, or designating, an acid,HO.C2H4.SO3H, obtained as an oily or crystalline substance, by theaction of sulphur trioxide on alcohol or ether. It is derivative ofsulphuric acid.
One who inveigles.
Incapable of error in defining doctrines touching faith ormorals. See Papal infallibility, under Infallibility.
See Invalid, n.
Unlearned; artless; pretty; delicate. [Obs.]Most sweet jests! most incony vulgar wit! Shak.
The quality of being importunate; pressing or pertinacioussolicitation; urgent request; incessant or frequent application;troublesome pertinacity.O'ercome with importunity and tears. Milton.

Of or pertaining to Italy, or to its people or language.Italian cloth a light material of cotton and worsted; -- called alsofarmer's satin.-- Italian iron, a heater for fluting frills.-- Italian juice, Calabrian liquorice.
See Entail, v. t.
Broken; interrupted. [Obs.] Milton.
Act or state of intermitting; intermission. Tyndall.

One of the principal means of securing unity and consistency inpolyphonic composition; the repetition of essentially the samemelodic theme, phrase, or motive, on different degrees of pitch, byone or more of the other parts of voises. Cf. Canon.
Not expensive; cheap.
To communicative ideas by the fingers; to show or compute bythe fingers. [Obs.]
Not contiguous; not adjoining or in contact; separate. Boyle.-- In`con*tig"u*ous*ly, adv.
To make odious or hateful. [Obs.] South.
Of or pertaining to Ionia or the Ionians; Ionic.-- n.
Pertaining to, or consisting of, images, pictures, orrepresentations of any kind.

Inferable.
Not capable of being transmuted or changed into anothersubstance.

Not corresponding; disagreeing. [R.] Coleridge.
To accuse; to charge with a crime or fault; to criminate.

Capable of being incinerated or reduced to ashes. Sir T.Browne.
The state or quality of being irrevocable; irrevocableness.
One who images or forms likenesses; a sculptor. [Obs.]Praxiteles was ennobled for a rare imager. Holland.
Incapable of being explained; inexplicable.

Belonging to the Infusoria; composed of, or containing,Infusoria; as, infusorial earth. Infusorial earth (Geol.), a depositof fine, usually white, siliceous material, composed mainly of theshells of the microscopic plants called diatoms. It is used inpolishing powder, and in the manufacture of dynamite.
Becoming hoary or gray; canescent.
To filter or sift in.
Not coincident; not agreeing in time, in place, or principle.
Capable of being broken.[R.]

Teeth; as, to show one's ivories. [Slang] Ivory black. Seeunder Black, n.-- Ivory gull (Zoöl.), a white Arctic gull (Larus eburneus).-- Ivory nut (Bot.), the nut of a species of palm, the Phytephasmacroarpa, often as large as a hen's egg. When young the seedcontains a fluid, which gradually hardness into a whitish, close-grained, albuminous substance, resembling the finest ivory in textureand color, whence it is called vegetable ivory. It is wrought intovarious articles, as buttons, chessmen, etc. The palm is found in NewGrenada. A smaller kind is the fruit of the Phytephas microarpa. Thenuts are known in commerce as Corosso nuts.-- Ivory palm (Bot.), the palm tree which produces ivory nuts.-- Ivory shell (Zoöl.), any species of Eburna, a genus of marinegastropod shells, having a smooth surface, usually white with red orbrown spots.-- Vegetable ivory, the meat of the ivory nut. See Ivory nut(above).
Interposition. [Obs.]
To impoverish. [Obs.]
Shown; denoted; registered; measured. Indicated power. SeeIndicated horse power, under Horse power.
A name given to each of three compromises made by the emperorCharles V. of Germany for the sake of harmonizing the connectingopinions of Protestants and Catholics.
Using or containing invitations.The "Venite" [Psalm xcv.], which is also called the invitatory psalm.Hook.
Quality of being inexpiable.
A gallfly which deposits its eggs in galls formed by otherinsects.
Want of compassion or pity. [Obs.] Bp. Sanderson.
The act of inditing. Craig.
An interlude; an intermede. See Intermede.
Pertaining to, or promoting, instruction; educational.

A line connecting or marking places upon the surface of theearth where height of the barometer reduced to sea level is the sameeither at a given time, or for a certain period (mean height), as fora year; an isopiestic line. [Written also isobare.]
Having no image. Shelley.
Between the ventricles; as, the interventricular partition ofthe heart.
Of or pertaining to an inspector or to inspection. [R.]
In a illiberal manner, ungenerously; uncharitably;parsimoniously.
The quality or state of being irreparable; irreparableness.Sterne.
Between two lives. [R.]Through all its [the spirit's] intervital gloom. Tennyson.
Uncontracted. [Obs.] Blackwall.
The open space between the inner and outer shells of a dome orcupola of masonry.
Same as Intuitionalist. Bain.
Below a trochlea, or pulley; -- applied esp. to one of thesubdivisions of the trigeminal nerve.
To pledge. Sir W. Scott.
Resembling iron, as in taste. Wood.
The quality of being incorruptible; incapability of corruption.Holland.
In an inactive manner. Locke.
Between the pubic bones or cartilages; as, the interpubic disk.
Applied to breeding from a male and female of the sameparentage. See under Breeding.
A binary compound of iodine, or one which may be regarded asbinary; as, potassium iodide.
Making no difference; indiscriminative; impartial; as,indistinguishing liberalities. [Obs.] Johnson.
Not to be subdued; untamable; invincible; as, an indomitablewill, courage, animal.
To disapprove of; to disallow. [Obs.]
The first letter of a word or a name.
A brown amorphous powder, obtained from indican.
Making or containing invocation; invoking.
By interpretation. Ray.
Misfortune. [Obs.] Chaucer.
Incapable or undeserving of being deprecated. Cockeram.
Tending to excite or provoke; inflammatory. Barrow.
One who impounds.
A nitrogenous base C10H9N, extracted from coal-tar naphtha, asan oily liquid. It is a member of the quinoline series, and isprobably identical with lepidine.
In an imperturbable manner; calmly. C. Bronté.
See Knock-kneed.
Incapable of extermination. Rush.
One who impeaches.
To render Italian, or conformable to Italian customs; toItalianize. [R.] Ascham.
A house-warming; especially, a reception, party, orentertainment given by a newly married couple, or by the husband uponreceiving the wife to his house. [Written also infair.] [Scot., &Local, U. S.]
Capability of being infused, pouredin, or instilled.
The quality or state of being incommutable.
Not to be entreated; inexorable.
Illuminative.
A person untaught or uninformed; one unlettered or unskilled;an ignoramous.Did I for this take pains to teach Our zealous ignorants to preachDenham.
By way of illustration or elucidation. [R.] Sir T. Browne.
One who, or that which, impairs.
Inconsistency.
Incapable of being transgressed; not to be passes over orcrossed. Holland.
A substance resembling indigo blue, obtained artificially fromcertain isatogen compounds.
A fossil footprint; an ichnite.
The state of being irreligious; want of religion; impiety.
In an issuable manner; by way of issue; as, to plead issuably.
In a illusive manner; falsely.
Without weariness; without yielding to fatigue; persistently.Dryden.
The nominative case of the pronoun of the first person; theword with which a speaker or writer denotes himself.
A frozen waterfall, or mass of ice resembling a frozenwaterfall. Coleridge.
The quality or state of being intelligible; intelligibility.Locke.
Tending to interrupt; interrupting. "Interruptive forces." H.Bushnell.-- In`ter*rupt"ive*ly, adv.
Between globules; -- applied esp. to certain small spaces,surrounded by minute globules, in dentine.
Correction or alteration by writing between the lines;interlineation. Bp. Burnet.

The act of surrounding, blocking up, or besieging by an armedforce, or the state of being so surrounded.The capitulation was signed by the commander of the fort within sixdays after its investments. Marshall.
The ichneumon flies.
By or with interference.
Serving to point out, as a remedy; indicating.
One who, or that which, imbibes.

An acute disease, almost exclusively infantile, characterizedby inflammation of the anterior horns of the gray substance of thespinal cord. It is attended with febrile symptoms, motor paralysis,and muscular atrophy, often producing permanent deformities. Calledalso acute anterior poliomyelitis.
To weaken; to enfeeble. [Obs.] Sir W. Raleigh.
The act of ingulfing, or the state of being ingulfed.
Pertaining to, or characterized by, implements or their use;mechanical.
Fury; rage; heat; exasperation; as, implacable incensement.Shak.
One who is impartial. [R.] Boyle.
Not discreet; wanting in discretion.So drunken, and so indiscreet an officer. Shak.
Spiritual inspiration at separate times, or at intervals.[Obs.] Bp. Hall.
The quality of being impenetrable; impenetrability.
Intemperate. [Obs.]Such as be intemperant, that is, followers of their naughty appetitesand lusts. Udall.
Lawless. [Obs.] Shak.
Between the trochanters of the femur.
Not injurious; harmless. [R.]
Ir
Characterized by short wings covered with feathers resemblingscales, as the penguins.-- n.
Of or pertaining to lines connecting places on the earth'ssurface which have a mean annual rainfall.-- n.
Incredibility.
An extra exercise enjoined on students as a punishment. T.Warton.
Burning; esp., the act of burning a dead body; cremation.
In an inflexible manner.
The quality or state of being inseparable; inseparability. Bp.Burnet.
To inclose completely, as in a membrane.
An imitatress.
The neuter pronoun of the third person, corresponding to themasculine pronoun he and the feminine she, and having the same plural(they, their of theirs, them).
Alike. [Obs.] Chaucer.

Of or pertaining to instinct; derived from, or prompted by,instinct; of the nature of instinct; determined by natural impulse orpropensity; acting or produced without reasoning, deliberation,instruction, or experience; spontaneous. "Instinctive motion."Milton. "Instinctive dread." Cowper.With taste instinctive give Each grace appropriate. Mason.Have we had instinctive intimations of the death of some absentfriends Bp. Hall.
Persistent portions of a calyx or corolla; also, leaves whichdo not disarticulate from the stem, and hence remain for a long time.
By inherence; inseparably.Matter hath inherently and essentially such an internal energy.Bentley.
In an intimate manner.
To weave into a wreath; to intertwine. [R.] Lovelace.

Designating an acid isomeric with cyanic acid. Isocyanic acid,an acid metameric with cyanic acid, and resembling it in its salts.It is obtained as a colorless, mobile, unstable liquid by the heatingcyanuric acid. Called technically carbimide.
Not conspicuous or noticeable; hardly discernible.-- In`con*spic"u*ous*ly, adv.-- In`con*spic"u*ous*ness, n. Boyle.
Quality of being inorganic. [Obs.] "The inorganity of thesoul." Sir T. Browne.
To initiate the doctrines or principles of the Illuminati.
The special communication of knowledge to the mind by God;inspiration.Hymns and psalms . . . are framed by meditation beforehand, or byprophetical illumination are inspired. Hooker.
One who favors innovation.
Not opportunely; unseasonably; inconveniently.
Between crura; -- applied especially to the interneural platesin the vertebral column of many cartilaginous fishes.
The state of being impecunious. Thackeray. Sir W. Scott.

Act of beginning; commencement; inception.The setting on foot some of those arts, in those parts, would belooked on as the first inchoation of them. Sir M. Hale.It is now in actual progress, from the rudest inchoation to the mostelaborate finishing. I. Taylor.
The quality of being inaudible; inaudibleness.
A duty levied on all importations.
A pursuer; a persecutor; a censorious critic. [Obs.] Bailey.
Of or pertaining to the imperative mood.
The state or quality of being immane; barbarity. [R.] Shak.
A body or compound which is isomeric with another body orcompound; a member of an isomeric series.
Incapble of being engendered or produced; original. Holland.
An imbuing. [Obs.]
An inhabitant of the infernal regions; also, the place itself.[Obs.] Drayton.
Uncorrupted. [Obs.]Breathed into their incorrupted breasts. Sir J. Davies.
To shock mutually. [R.]
Relating to inquiry or inquisition; inquisitorial; also, of orpertaining to, or characteristic of, the Inquisition.All the inquisitional rigor . . . executed upon books. Milton.

Not susceptible of pain or suffering; apathetic; impassible;unmoved.Impassive as the marble in the quarry. De Quincey.On the impassive ice the lightings play. Pope.-- Im*pas"sive*ly, adv.-- Im*pas"sive*ness, n.
Of or pertaining to intrusion.
A pole for supporting a scaffold.
Reciprocal migration; interchange of dwelling place bymigration. [R.] Sir M. Hale.
Without sincerity.
Unfortunate. [Obs.]I, woeful wretch and infortuned wight. Chaucer.

The root of a Brazilian rubiaceous herb (CephaëlisIpecacuanha), largely employed as an emetic; also, the plant itself;also, a medicinal extract of the root. Many other plants are used asa substitutes; among them are the black or Peruvian ipecac(Psychotria emetica), the white ipecac (Ionidium Ipecacuanha), thebastard or wild ipecac (Asclepias Curassavica), and the undulatedipecac (Richardsonia scabra).
Covering; clothing. [R.] Woodward.
Abounding in islands. [R.]
Engraved. Glover.
One who incarcerates.
Want of abstinence; indulgence. [Obs.] "The inabstinence ofEve." Milton.
A flowing in; infusion. [R.] Bacon.
Interposition. [Obs.]
Literally, those who are enlightened; -- variously applied asfollows: -
A bruise; a contusion. [Obs.] Spenser.
Failure to cognize, apprehended, or notice.This incognizance may be explained. Sir W. Hamilton.
A bursting in or into.
To enter by penetrating the pores or interstices of asubstance; to filter into or through something.The water infiltrates through the porous rock. Addison.
In an insecure manner.

To make bitter; hence, to make distressing or more distressing;to make sad, morose, sour, or malignant.Is there anything that more imbitters the enjoyment of this life thanshame South.Imbittered against each other by former contests. Bancroft.
Incapable of being explored, searched out, or discovered. SirG. Buck.

A stopping or checking of an already present action; arestraining of the function of an organ, or an agent, as a digestivefluid or ferment, etc.; as, the inhibition of the respiratory centerby the pneumogastric nerve; the inhibition of reflexes, etc.
Idolatrous. [Obs.] Milton.
Instinct; incitement; inspiration. [Obs.] Sir T. Elyot.
To illuminate; to light up; to adorn.
To conform, or cause to conform, to the religion of Islam.
Appropriate; suitable; proper; fit; adequate. [R.]An ecclesiastical benefice . . . ought to be conferred on an idoneousperson. Ayliffe.
Situated between the external and internal carotid arteries;as, an intercarotid ganglion.
Same as Indentation, 4.
To receive between or within.
Capable of being ignited.
Impolite; rude.

A proceeding devised to enable a person, of whom the same debt,duty, or thing is claimed adversely by two or more parties, to compelthem to litigate the right or title between themselves, and therebyto relieve himself from the suits which they might otherwise bringagainst him.
Capable of being obtained or moved by petition. [Obs.] Bailey.
Anointed. [Obs.] Cockeram.
Not reverent; showing a want of reverence; expressive of a wantof veneration; as, an irreverent babbler; an irreverent jest.
In an inquisitive manner.The occasion that made him afterwards so inquisitively apply himselfto the study of physic. Boyle.
An old game played with four dice. In signified a doublet, ortwo dice alike; in-and-in, either two doubles, or the four dicealike.
See Emblazon.
To pledge or pawn. [Obs.] Laing.
Incrusted. Bacon.
Reduced to ashes by burning; thoroughly consumed. [Obs.] Bacon.
One who, or that which, inclines; specifically, an inclineddial.
Not tolerated.
Disturbance. [Obs.] Sir T. Elyot.
A female intriguer.
An introduction. [Obs.] Harris.
Want of affability or sociability; reticence.

Of or pertaining to the ischium or hip; ischiac; ischiadic;ischiatic. Ischial callosity (Zoöl.), one of the patches of thickenedhairless, and often bright-colored skin, on the buttocks of manyapes, as the drill.

Not conceivable; incapable of being conceived by the mind; notexplicable by the human intellect, or by any known principles oragencies; incomprehensible; as, it is inconceivable to us how thewill acts in producing muscular motion.It is inconceivable to me that a spiritual substance should representan extended figure. Locke.-- In`con*ceiv"a*ble*ness, n.-- In`con*ceiv"a*bly, adv.The inconceivableness of a quality existing without any subject topossess it. A. Tucker.
A substance from the yolk of salmon's egg.
The jaundice.
Belonging to, or composed of, integuments.
Incapable of being rebutted. Coleridge.
Incapable of being narrated; indescribable; ineffable. [Obs.]"Inenarrable goodness." Bp. Fisher.
Between the ribs; pertaining to, or produced by, the partsbetween the ribs; as, intercostal respiration, in which the chest isalternately enlarged and contracted by the intercostal muscles.

Recently, or just, begun; beginning; partially but not fully inexistence or operation; existing in its elements; incomplete.-- In"cho*ate*ly, adv.Neither a substance perfect, nor a substance inchoate. Raleigh.
Capable of being imported.

The quality of being impudent; assurance, accompanied with adisregard of the presence or opinions of others; shamelessness;forwardness; want of modesty.Clear truths that their own evidence forces us to admit, or commonexperience makes it impudence to deny. Locke.Where pride and impudence (in fashion knit) Usurp the chair of wit.B. Jonson.
The person to whom a note or bill is indorsed, or assigned byindorsement.
To overwhelm with water; to drench; to drown. [Obs.] Shak.
The quality of being immensurable.
Strongly affected. Smart.
The state or quality of being irredeemable; irredeemableness.
The union of the second person of the Godhead with manhood inChrist.
The quality or state of being impregnable; invincibility.
Not contestable; not to be disputed; that cannot be called inquestion or controverted; incontrovertible; indisputable; as,incontestable evidence, truth, or facts. Locke.

To call upon, or for, in supplication; to beseech; to prey to,or for, earnestly; to petition with urency; to entreat; to beg; --followed directly by the word expressing the thing sought, or theperson from whom it is sought.Imploring all the gods that reign above. Pope.I kneel, and then implore her blessing. Shak.
Imaginative. [Obs.] Holland.
The state of being uncurable; irremediableness. Harvey.
An actor who performs in an interlude. B. Jonson.
The quality or state of being inconvertible; not capable ofbeing exchanged for, or converted into, something else; as, theinconvertibility of an irredeemable currency, or of lead, into gold.
Incorrigibility. Dr. H. More.
One who inters.
Not conditioned; not limited; absolute. [Obs.] Boyle.
Want of nutrition; failure of nourishment. E. Darwin.
. An ideal personification of the typical Russian or of theRussian people; -- used as "John Bull" is used for the typicalEnglishman.
Imperfectly digested, matured, or ripened. [Obs.] Bacon.
The quality of being indelible. Bp. Horsley.
In an irreverent manner.
Capable of being inspired or drawn into the lungs; inhalable;respirable; admitting inspiration. Harvey.
act of imbowing; an arch; a vault. Bacon.
Attention; consideration; knowledge; understanding. [Obs.]Spenser.
Instantly. [Poetic]Instant he flew with hospitable haste. Pope.

Not active; inert; esp., not exhibiting any action or activityon polarized light; optically neutral; -- said of isomeric forms ofcertain substances, in distinction from other forms which areoptically active; as, racemic acid is an inactive tartaric acid.
Unspeakable. [Obs.]
A term applied to certain nerve centers which govern orrestrain subsidiary centers, from which motor impressions issue.McKendrick.
An invariable quantity; specifically, a function of thecoefficients of one or more forms, which remains unaltered, whenthese undergo suitable linear transformations. J. J. Sylvester.
To embark. [Obs.] Shak.
The offering of incense. [R.] Encyc. Brit.
The quality of being impolitic.
One of the classes of Protozoa, including a large number ofspecies, all of minute size.
Want of exertion; want of effort; defect of action; indolence;laziness.
An officer in the Greek empire having functions correspondingto those of a justice of the peace. [Written also eirenarch.]
The worship of idols. [Obs.]
To communicate a disease to ( a person ) by insertinginfectious matter in the skin or flesh; as, to inoculate a personwith the virus of smallpox,rabies, etc. See Vaccinate.
An innholder.
The quality of being incombustible.
Not prolific. [Obs.] E. Waterhouse.
To render immethodical; to destroy the method of; to confuse.[R.]
The quality or state of being irreproachable; integrity;innocence.
To inculcate. [Obs.] Sir T. More.
A worshiper of idols. [Obs.] Milton.
Not irritable; esp. (Physiol.), incapable of being stimulatedto action, as a muscle.-- In*ir`ri*ta*bil"i*ty, n.
Within the sides of; in the interior; contained within; as,inside a house, book, bottle, etc.
By influxion. [R.]
To draw in; to swallow. [Obs.] Evelyn.

Free from bias or prejudice; impartial; unbiased;disinterested.In choice of committees for ripening business for the counsel, it isbetter indifferent persons than to make an indifferency by putting inthose that are strong on both sides. Bacon.Indifferent tissue (Anat.), the primitive, embryonic,undifferentiated tissue, before conversion into connective, muscular,nervous, or other definite tissue.
Refusal of pardon.
One of the Iulidæ, a family of myriapods, of which the genusIulus is the type. See Iulus.
Serving to introduce; introductory.-- In`tro*duc"tive*ly, adv.
In an ingenuous manner; openly; fairly; candidly; artlessly.Being required to explane himself, he ingeniously confessed. Ludlow.
Impenitence. Milton.

Entangled; involved; perplexed; complicated; difficult tounderstand, follow, arrange, or adjust; as, intricate machinery,labyrinths, accounts, plots, etc.His style was fit to convey the most intricate business to theunderstanding with the utmost clearness. Addison.The nature of man is intricate. Burke.
Having no backbone; invertebrate.

A method of moving a fleet from one formation to another, thedirection usually being changed eight points (90º), by means of pathsof equal length for each ship. It is prohibited in the United Statesnavy.
The act of imbruing or state of being imbrued.

A small closed receptacle or set of receptacles of hardmaterial, as lacquered wood, iron, bronze, or ivory, used by theJapanese to hold medicines, perfumes, and the like, and carried inthe girdle. It is usually secured by a silk cord by which the wearermay grasp it, which cord passes through an ornamental button or knobcalled a netsuke.
Not to be persuaded; obstinate; unyielding; impersuasible.-- Im`per*suad"a*ble*ness, n.
Not escapable.
In an iniquitous manner; unjustly; wickedly.
To raise to any assigned power; to multiply, as a quantity,into itself a given number of times; as, a quantity involved to thethird or fourth power.
Covered with induviæ, as the upper part of the trunk of a palmtree.
To flash or shine between or among. [R.] Blount.
Below; beneath; under; after; -- often used as a prefix.
Existence without a body or material form; immateriality.Cudworth.
A flowing or entering in; -- opposed to emanation. [R.] Good.
In an impotent manner.
To inclose in a box.
The state of being imperfect.
Formed by implosion. Ellis.
Internecine. [R.] Sydney Smith.
Represented as enraged, as any wild creature depicted with fireissuing from mouth and eyes.
The act of soaking or moistening; maceration; solution in thejuice of herbs. [Obs.] Coxe.The medicating and insuccation of seeds. Evelyn.
The interscapular feathers of a bird.
The state of being inglorious.

Of, pertaining to, having, or denoting, equality of force.Isodynamic foods (Physiol.), those foods that produce a similaramount of heat.-- Isodynamic lines (Magnetism), lines on the earth's surfaceconnecting places at which the magnetic intensity is the same.
Capable of being isolated, or of being obtained in a purestate; as, gold is isolable.

Not excusable; not admitting excuse or justification; as,inexcusable folly.Therefore thou art inexcusable, O man, whosoever thou art thatjudgest; for wherein thou judgest another, thou condemnest thyself;for thou that judgest doest the same things. Rom. ii. 1.
To inaugurate. [Obs.] Latimer.
Relating to the indulgences of the Roman Catholic Church.Brevint.
In an ineffective manner; without effect; inefficiently;ineffectually.

To move to action; to stir up; to rouse; to spur or urge on.Anthiochus, when he incited Prusias to join in war, set before himthe greatness of the Romans. Bacon.No blown ambition doth our arms incite. Shak.
To put into a chest.
That may be inflated.
The quality or state of being ineffable; ineffableness;unspeakableness.
To embark; to go or put into a barge. [Obs.] Drayton.
Not questioned or doubtful; evident; certain. [Obs.] Bacon.
Not coagulable.
The quality or state of being equal in weight, especially inatmospheric pressure. Also, the theory, method, or application ofisobaric science.
One who, or that which, impresses. Boyle.
Indispensableness.

Of or pertaining to Ireland or to its inhabitants; produced inIreland. Irish elk. (Zoöl.) See under Elk.-- Irish moss. (a) (Bot.) Carrageen. (b) A preparation of the samemade into a blanc mange.-- Irish poplin. See Poplin.-- Irish potato, the ordinary white potato, so called because it isa favorite article of food in Ireland.-- Irish reef, or Irishman's reef (Naut.), the head of a sail tiedup.-- Irish stew, meat, potatoes, and onions, cut in small pieces andstewed.

To give, cause, or produce by striking, or as if by striking;to apply forcibly; to lay or impose; to send; to cause to bear, feel,or suffer; as, to inflict blows; to inflict a wound with a dagger; toinflict severe pain by ingratitude; to inflict punishment on anoffender; to inflict the penalty of death on a criminal.What heart could wish, what hand inflict, this dire disgrace Drygen.The persecution and the pain That man inflicts on infero-ior kinds.Cowper.

Difference in pitch between any two tones. At intervals, comingor happening with intervals between; now and then. "And Miriamwatch'd and dozed at intervals." Tennyson.-- Augmented interval (Mus.), an interval increased by half a stepor half a tone.

A rare metallic element, discovered in certain ores of zinc, bymeans of its characteristic spectrum of two indigo blue lines; hence,its name. In appearance it resembles zinc, being white or lead gray,soft, malleable and easily fusible, but in its chemical relation itresembles aluminium or gallium. Symbol In. Atomic weight, 113.4.
Indebtedness. [R.] Bp. Hall.
Impassibility.
Indenture. [Obs.]
Not descriptive.
In an insipid manner; without taste, life, or spirit; flatly.Locke. Sharp.
To set, place, or establish, as in a rank, office, orcondition; to install; to invest; as, to instate a person ingreatness or in favor. Shak.
A person who is inquisitive; one curious in research. Sir W.Temple.
The aperture in a mold for pouring in the metal; the gate.Simmonds.
A situation or position beneath. Kane.
An ideo-motor movement.
See Empower.
To institute and prosecute a suit against, in court; to sue orprosecute at law; hence, to accuse; to impeach.

The act of anointing, or the state of being anointed; unction;specifically (Med.), the rubbing of ointments into the pores of theskin, by which medicinal agents contained in them, such as mercury,iodide of potash, etc., are absorbed.
To cloud. [R.] Daniel.
Not ceasing; perpetual. [Obs.] Baxter.-- In*des"i*nent*ly, adv. [Obs.] Ray.
Not guilty. [Obs.] Bp. Hall.
One of a number of persons who gets a company incorporated; oneof the original members of a corporation.
Seldom happening or occurring; rare; uncommon; unusual.The act whereof is at this day infrequent or out of use among allsorts of men. Sir T. Elyot.
One born in a country; an aboriginal animal or plant; anautochthon. Evelyn. Tylor.
The act of impeaching, or the state of being impeached; as:(a) Hindrance; impediment; obstruction. [Obs.]Willing to march on to Calais, Without impeachment. Shak.
Majestically. [R.] C. Bronté.
In an impure manner.
A mode of speaking peculiar to the Irish; an Hibernicism.
Want of correction, restraint, or discipline. [Obs.] Arnway.
A combining form used in anatomy to denote connection with, orrelation to, the ilium; as, ilio-femoral, ilio-lumbar, ilio-psoas,etc.
Any gastropod of the genus Ianthina, of which various speciesare found living in mid ocean; -- called also purple shell, andviolet snail. [Written also janthina.]
Uncivilly. [Obs.] Shak.
Having the same tint or color throughout; uniformly or evenlycolored.
To make search after; to investigate or examine; to ensearch.[Obs.]
Same as Inkle.
Full of increase; abundant in produce. "Increaseful crops."[R.] Shak.
Transmission and reception by animal or plant generation.
To throw in between; to insert; to interpose. Sir H. Wotton.
See Instructor.
The state or quality of being insurmountable.
A bad state; as, the intemperament of an ulcerated part. [R.]Harvey.
Instability; unstableness.
Included between two plane surfaces or faces; as, aninterfacial angle.
The person or thing that inflames. Addison.
