Not corrigible; incapable of being corrected or amended; badbeyond correction; irreclaimable; as, incorrigible error."Incorrigible fools." Dryden.
To advance on loan. Burke.
The act of impinging.
The state or quality of being immature or not fully developed;unripeness; incompleteness.When the world has outgrown its intellectual immaturity. Caird.
The interior part of a country. Shak.
A placing or coming between; interposition.
A picture, example, or illustration, often taken from sensibleobjects, and used to illustrate a subject; usually, an extendedmetaphor. Brande & C.
The state or quality of being improvable; improvableness.
Pertaining, or ascribed, to Isidore; as, the Isidoriandecretals, a spurious collection of decretals published in the ninthcentury.
Imponderable. [Obs.] Sir T. Browne.-- Im*pon"der*ous*ness, n. [Obs.]
Mutual transfer; exchange. [Obs.] Shak.
Of or pertaining to a part of the columella of the ear, whichin many animals projects below the connection with the stapes.-- n.
Want of reconciliation; disagreement.
To make into a snarl or knot; to entangle; to snarl. [Obs.]Cotgrave.
Not fragrant.
One who is irregular. Baxter.
In an inorganic manner.
In an incumbent manner; so as to be incumbent.
An exclamation of joy or triumph; -- often interjectional.
To have inherent; to contain in itself; to possess. [Obs.] SirW. Raleigh.
Indissolubility. Sir M. Hale.
One who, or that which, impels.
To state in items, or by particulars; as, to itemize the costof a railroad. [Local, U. S.]
The state of being without organization.
Want of sobriety, moderation, or calmness; intemperance;drunkenness.
Without an object following; in the manner of an intransitiveverb.
The state of being itchy.
The state of being intoxicated; intoxication; drunkenness. [R.]
Furnished with involucels.
To vary, as a noun or a verb in its terminations; to decline,as a noun or adjective, or to conjugate, as a verb.
One skilled in ichthyotomy.
One who impugns.
Pertaining to, or employed in, imitation; as, imitationalpropensities.
A female intruder.

A word or form of speech thrown in to express emotion orfeeling, as O! Alas! Ha ha! Begone! etc. Compare Exclamation.An interjection implies a meaning which it would require a wholegrammatical sentence to expound, and it may be regarded as therudiment of such a sentence. But it is a confusion of thought to rankit among the parts of speech. Earle.How now! interjections Why, then, some be of laughing, as, ah, ha,he! Shak.
The doctrine taught by Schelling, that matter and mind, andsubject and object, are identical in the Absolute; -- called also thesystem or doctrine of identity.
Not censurable. Dr. T. Dwight.-- In*cen"sur*a*bly, adv.

The crime of cohabitation or sexual commerce between personsrelated within the degrees wherein marriage is prohibited by law.Shak. Spiritual incest. (Eccl. Law) (a) The crime of cohabitationcommitted between persons who have a spiritual alliance by means ofbaptism or confirmation. (b) The act of a vicar, or otherbeneficiary, who holds two benefices, the one depending on thecollation of the other.
The act or process of drying in.
The act of making fat, or the state of being fat or fattened.[Obs.]
Sinless; impeccable. Byron.
Unformed or ill-formed; deformed; shapeless. [Obs.] Spenser.Informed stars. See under Unformed.
Having two legs or sides that are equal; -- said of a triangle.
Interchange; mutual or reciprocal change.
Like an infant. Shak.
Not reprehensible; blameless; innocent.-- Ir*rep`re*hen"si*ble*ness, n.-- Ir*rep`re*hen"si*bly, adv.
Not to be discerned; imperceptible; not discoverable orvisible.Secret and indiscernible ways. Jer. Taylor.-- In`dis*cern"i*ble*ness, n.-- In`dis*cern"i*bly, adv.
The act of inhaling; also, that which is inhaled.
The quality of being undefeasible.
Incapable of being retraced; not retraceable.
A person diseased beyond cure.
An intermission. [R.]
Want of preparation. [Obs.] Hooker.
Lying or being between or among; intervening; as, interjacentisles. Sir W. Raleigh.
Endowed with irritability; susceptible of irritation; capableof being excited to action by the application of certain stimuli.
Done or being within doors; within a house or institution;domestic; as, indoor work.
The state of being interlaminated.

The pressure of the type on the paper, or the result of suchpressure, as regards its appearance; as, a heavy impression; a clear,or a poor, impression; also, a single copy as the result of printing,or the whole edition printed at a given time.Ten impressions which his books have had. Dryden.
Not pervious; impervious. [R.] -- Im*per"vi*a*ble*ness, n. [R.]
Intemperateness. [Obs.] Boyle.
Internuncio.
An infirmary. [Obs.]
Within the tropics.
Having the quality of isomorphism.
Breeches; trousers. [Colloq. or Slang] Ld. Lytton.
One who is in favor of itacism.
A flowing between; intervening water. [Obs.] Sir M. Hale.
Recital or performance a second time; repetition. Bacon.What needs this iteration, woman Shak.
Want of ceremonial purity; defilement.

A yellow, crystalline, volatile substance, CI3H, having anoffensive odor and sweetish taste, and analogous to chloroform. It isused in medicine as a healing and antiseptic dressing for wounds andsores.
Within the territory of a state. Story.
To cover or overspread with, or as with, leaves. [R.] Howell.
To disorder. [Obs.]
To people; to give a population to. [Obs.]Thou hast helped to impeople hell. Beaumont.
One who inflicts.Godis the sole and immadiate inflicter of such strokes. South.
In. [Obs.]And eke in what array that they were inne. Chaucer.
To interleave. [Obs.] Evelyn.
A person dwelling in, or having charge of, an infirmary, esp.in a monastic institution.
That which naturally invests or covers another thing, as thetesta or the tegmen of a seed; specifically (Anat.), a covering whichinvests the body, as the skin, or a membrane that invests aparticular.
The quality of being improvident; want of foresight or thrift.The improvidence of my neighbor must not make me inhuman. L'Estrange.
To dry in, or to expose to, the sun's rays; to ripen or prepareby such exposure. Johnson.
In an involuntary manner; not voluntarily; not intentionally orwillingly.
One who infracts or infringes; a violator; a breaker.
Intercepting; stopping.-- n.
Born in or with; implanted by nature; innate; as, inbornpassions. Cowper.
Not acquiescent or acquiescing.
Wrathfulness. Wyclif.
To envelop as in clouds; to darken; to obscure. Milton.
Not congealable; incapable of being congealed.-- In`con*geal"a*ble*ness, n.
Isodimorphous.

To plant, or infix, for the purpose of growth; to fix deeply;to instill; to inculate; to introduce; as, to implant the seeds ofvirtue, or the principles of knowledge, in the minds of youth.Minds well implanted with solid . . . breeding. Milton.
Want of vigilance; neglect of watching; carelessness.
Darkened with a blackish tinge.
Not effervescing, or not susceptible of effervescence;quiescent.
Badly educated or brought up; impolite; incivil; rude. See Noteunder Ill, adv.
Not progressive. De Quincey.-- Im"pro*gress"ive*ly, adv.
Interwoven. [R.] Shak.
Having icicles attached.
Valuable beyond estimation; inestimable; priceless; precious.
A large vessel in the India trade. Macaulay.

Wanting sensibility; destitute of sense; stupid; foolish.The silence and the calm Of mute, insensate things. Wordsworth.The meddling folly or insensate ambition of statesmen. Buckle.-- In*sen"sate*ly, adv.-- In*sen"sate*ness, n.

Want of power to produce the desired or proper effect;inefficiency; ineffectualness; futility; uselessness; fruitlessness;as, the inefficacy of medicines or means.The seeming inefficacy of censures. Bp. Hall.The inefficacy was soon proved, like that of many similar medicines.James Gregory.
To have the character of, or to lie between, two distinctgroups.
The quality of being indefectible. Barrow.
Below the sternum; as, the infrasternal depression, or pit ofthe stomach.

Not liable to be removed; permanent in place or tenure; fixed;as, an immovable estate. See Immovable, n. Blackstone. Immovableapparatus (Med.), an appliance, like the plaster of paris bandage,which keeps fractured parts firmly in place.-- Immovable feasts (Eccl.), feasts which occur on a certain day ofthe year and do not depend on the date of Easter; as, Christmas, theEpiphany, etc.

An orange-red crystalline substance, C8H5NO2, obtained by theoxidation of indigo blue. It is also produced from certainderivatives of benzoic acid, and is one important source ofartificial indigo. [Written also, less properly, isatine.]
Irregular; -- said of any arrangement whose symmetry isdestroyed by local causes, as when leaflets are interposed among theleaves in a pinnate leaf.
Irascible; passionate. [Obs.] Chaucer.
An oily liquid, Cl3.CHO, analogous to chloral and bromal.
Worship of fishes, or of fish-shaped idols. Layard.
A twenty-four-sided solid; a tetragonal trisoctahedron ortrapezohedron.
A newly formed shoot, or the annually produced addition to thestems of many mosses.
A prefix signifying among, between, amid; as, interact,interarticular, intermit.
In immense manner or degree.
Below the margin; submarginal; as, an inframarginal convolutionof the brain.
A current due to variation in the magnetic field surroundingits conductor.
A person who ingrafts.
In an inconvertible manner.
To put in between other things; to insert. [Obs.] Brerewood.
To cover, as with a vail. W. Browne.
An artist's way of expressing his thought or embodying hisconception of nature.
Entreaty. [Obs.] Holland.
See Incumbent.
The state of being indocible; indocibleness; indocility.
Of or pertaining to the indulges or crop of birds.
See Embezzle.
Imposture; cheating. [R.] Jer. Taylor.
Unpropitious; unfavorable. [Obs.] "Dreams were impropitious."Sir H. Wotton.

A supernatural divine influence on the prophets, apostles, orsacred writers, by which they were qualified to communicate moral orreligious truth with authority; a supernatural influence whichqualifies men to receive and communicate divine truth; also, thetruth communicated.All Scripture is given by inspiration of God. 2 Tim. iii. 16.The age which we now live in is not an age of inspiration andimpulses. Sharp.Plenary inspiration (Theol.), that kind of inspiration which excludesall defect in the utterance of the inspired message.-- Verbal inspiration (Theol.), that kind of inspiration whichextends to the very words and forms of expression of the divinemessage.
Want of vision or of the power of seeing. [Obs.] Sir T. Browne.
Having inflections; capable of, or subject to, inflection;inflective. Inflected cycloid (Geom.), a prolate cycloid. SeeCycloid.
Huge. [Obs.] Herrick.
To daub or catch with glue or birdlime; to entangle withglutinous matter. [R.] Sir T. Browne.
Closeness of attention or application of mind; attentiveness.[Obs.] W. Montagu.
Not accurate; not according to truth; inexact; incorrect;erroneous; as, in inaccurate man, narration, copy, judgment,calculation, etc.The expression is plainly inaccurate. Bp. Hurd.
Capable of being inferred or deduced from premises. [Writtenalso inferrible.] H. Spencer.A sufficient argument . . . is inferable from these premises. Burke.

In reality; in truth; in fact; verily; truly; -- used in avariety of sense. Esp.: (a) Denoting emphasis; as, indeed it is so.(b) Denoting concession or admission; as, indeed, you are right. (c)Denoting surprise; as, indeed, is it you Its meaning is not intrinsicor fixed, but depends largely on the form of expression which itaccompanies.
To cover with plates; to sheathe; as, to implate a ship withiron.

A court or tribunal for the examination and punishment ofheretics, fully established by Pope Gregory IX. in 1235. Itsoperations were chiefly confined to Spain, Portugal, and theirdependencies, and a part of Italy.
Not connected; disconnected. [R.] Bp. Warburton.
The state or condition of being incontrovertible.
To worship idols; to pay idolatrous worship.
Inanition. [R.]
The act of infolding; the state of being infolded.
Situated between joints or articulations; as, interarticularcartilages and ligaments.
Coming between the equinoxes.Summer and winter I have called interequinoctial intervals. F.Balfour.
See Ischial.
The state or quality of being unaccustomed; absence of use orhabit.Absurdities are great or small in proportion to custom or insuetude.Landor.
Imitation of another's handwriting,
Illegality, unlawfulness.
Entomology. [Obs.]
Incredulity.
In an immortal manner.

The quality or state of being inquisitive; the disposition toseek explanation and information; curiosity to learn what is unknown;esp., uncontrolled and impertinent curiosity.Mr. Boswell, whose inquisitiveness is seconded by great activity,scrambled in at a high window. Johnson.Curiosity in children nature has provided, to remove that ignorancethey were born with; which, without this busy inquisitiveness, willmake them dull. Locke.
To entangle; to intertwine. "Moss and intertangled vines."Longfellow.
Unconcernedness; incuriosity.Sordid incuriousness and slovenly neglect. Bp. Hall.
Want of learning; illiteracy. [R.] Ayliffe. Southey.
To mix together; to intermingle.In yonder spring of roses, intermixed With myrtle, find what toredress till noon. Milton.
One who adheres to the theory or method of impressionism, socalled.
Promoting faction or contention; seditious; inflammatory.[Obs.] Bacon.-- In*cen"di*ous*ly, adv. [Obs.]
To inclose, as a field. [R.]
The condition or quality of being idle (in the various sensesof that word); uselessness; fruitlessness; triviality; inactivity;laziness.

A type of alternating-current motor comprising two woundmembers, one stationary, called the stator, and the other rotating,called the rotor, these two members corresponding to a certain extentto the field and armature of a direct-current motor.
Want of method.
An East Indian barbet (Megalaima faber), inhabiting the Islandof Hainan. The name alludes to its note, which resembles the soundsmade by a smith.
An intolerant person; a bigot.
The state or quality of being irreversible.
To render turbid; to darken; to confuse. [R.]The confusion of ideas and conceptions under the same term painfullyinturbidates his theology. Coleridge.

We are ignorant; we ignore; -- being the word formerly writtenon a bill of indictment by a grand jury when there was not sufficientevidence to warrant them in finding it a true bill. The phrase nowused is, "No bill," "No true bill," or "Not found," though in somejurisdictions "Ignored" is still used. Wharton (Law Dict. ). Burn.

The faculty or capacity of the mind for forming ideas; theexercise of this capacity; the act of the mind by which objects ofsense are apprehended and retained as objects of thought.The whole mass of residua which have been accumulated . . . all enternow into the process of ideation. J. D. Morell.
Provided with interstices; having interstices between; situatedat intervals.
Of or relating to ideology.
Capable of being impeded or hindered. [R.] Jer. Taylor.
Incapable of being deprived, or of being taken away.
Without method; confusedly; unsystematically.
One who indicts. Bacon.

Incorporating or tending to incorporate; as, the incorporativelanguages (as of the Basques, North American Indians, etc. ) whichrun a whole phrase into one word.History demonstrates that incorporative unions are solid andpermanent; but that a federal union is weak. W. Belsham.
In conformity with an institution. Harrington.
The state or quality of being inarticulate.
Quality or state of being invulnerable.
To cause to germinate.
An intervening period of time; interval. [Obs.] Gower.
One of the Inferobranchiata.
Of or pertaining to the iris of the eye.
To make infamous; to defame. [R.] Coleridge.
A method of ingrafting. See Inarch.
The method or operation of finding from a few given terms of aseries, as of numbers or observations, other intermediate terms inconformity with the law of the series.
Having no mirth; not festive or merry; dull; cheerless; gloomy;forlorn. [R.]
Of or pertaining to an isobathytherm; possessing or indicatingthe same temperature at the same depth.
Freedom from confusion; distinctness. [Obs.] Bacon.
To inclose as in a trunk; to incase. [R.] Ford.
Infusion. [Obs.] Spenser.
Presented, instituted, and inducted into a rectory, and in fullpossession.-- n.

To apply in use; to train; to discipline; to use or accustomtill use gives little or no pain or inconvenience; to harden; tohabituate; to practice habitually. "To inure our prompt obedience."Milton.He . . . did inure them to speak little. Sir T. North.Inured and exercised in learning. Robynson (More's Utopia).The poor, inured to drudgery and distress. Cowper.
To sow between or among. [R.]
The act of twinning, or the state of being intwined.
, and Gray.] (Bot.) A genus of twining plants with showymonopetalous flowers, including the morning-glory, the sweet potato,and the cypress vine.
United in one body; formed into a corporation; made a legalentity.
Greediness of appetite that can not be satisfied or appeased;insatiability.The eye of the covetous hath a more particular insatiableness. Bp.Hall.
Repeating. Cotgrave.-- It"er*a*tive*ly, adv.
Articles made of iron, as household utensils, tools, and thelike.
Not having a distinctive margin or border. Grey.
Having, or indicating, an equal amount of cloudiness for agiven period; as, isonephelic regions; an isonephelic line.
Of or pertaining to the interambulacra.
Impartiality. Sir W. Temple.

To indulge one's self; to gratify one's tastes or desires;esp., to give one's self up (to); to practice a forbidden orquestionable act without restraint; -- followed by in, but formerly,also, by to. "Willing to indulge in easy vices." Johnson.
In an impudent manner; with unbecoming assurance; shamelessly.At once assail With open mouths, and impudently rail. Sandys.
Ironical. Sir T. Herbert.

In an indifferent manner; without distinction or preference;impartially; without concern, wish, affection, or aversion;tolerably; passably.That they may truly and indifferently minister justice, to thepunishment of wickedness and vice, and to the maintenance of thy truereligion, and virtue. Book of Com. Prayer [Eng. Ed. ]Set honor in one eye and death i' the other, And I will look on bothindifferently. Shak.I hope it may indifferently entertain your lordship at an unbendinghour. Rowe.
Without regular form; shapeless; ugly; deformed. Cotton.
A doctrine or theory; especially, a wild or visionary theory.E. Everett.The world grew light-headed, and forth came a spawn of isms which noman can number. S. G. Goodrich.
Not nutritious; not furnishing nourishment.
A piece an inch long. By inchmeal, by small degrees; by inches.Shak.
Incapble of being measured; indefinitely extensive;illimitable; immensurable; vast.Of depth immeasurable. Milton.
Not alterable; incapable of being altered or changed;unalterable.-- In*al"ter*a*ble*ness, n.-- In*al"ter*a*bly, adv.
One of the spiny plates foundon the back and tail of certainskates.
To sow; to impregnate. [Obs.]
In an intelligible manner; so as to be understood; clearly;plainly; as, to write or speak intelligibly.
A sensation originated by some external object, but so modifiedas in any way to lead to an erroneous perception; as when the rollingof a wagon is mistaken for thunder.
Incrustation. [R.]

A similarity of crystalline form between substances of similarcomposition, as between the sulphates of barium (BaSO4) and strontium(SrSO4). It is sometimes extended to include similarity of formbetween substances of unlike composition, which is more properlycalled homoeomorphism.
Between the carpal bone; as, intercarpal articulations,ligaments.
To put in pawn; to pledge. Shak.
Faultless; blameless; innocent. South.An innocent and incupable piece of ignorance. Killingbeck.
Incapable of being passed; not admitting a passage; as, animpassable road, mountain, or gulf. Milton.-- Im*pass"a*ble*ness, n.-- Im*pass"a*bly, adv.
Between the fingers or toes; as, interdigital space.
Having a bad look; threatening; ugly. See Note under Ill, adv.
The act of interserting, or that which is interserted. [Obs.]Hammond.
The state or quality of being insurmountable;insurmountability.
Without variation of termination.
See Embower.
To accuse. [Obs.] Donne.
Below the lower lip; -- said of certain scales of reptiles andfishes.
A salt of isosulphocyanic acid.
Between or among constellations or stars; interstellar.
In an inexpressible manner or degree; unspeakably; unutterably.Spectator.
Want or absence of divine power or of divinity. [Obs.] Sir T.Browne.
To unite, embrace, communicate with, or flow into, one another;to be connected in one system; to lock into one another; to interlacefirmly.
To be of use to an end; to serve. [Obs.]
Incapable of erring; infallible; unerring. "Inerabble andrequisite conditions." Sir T. Browne. "Not an inerrable text."Gladstone.
One who will never cease to be; one exempt from death, decay,or annihilation. Bunyan.
In an intensive manner; by increase of degree. Abp. Bramhall.
Not plumed; without plumes or feathers; featherless. [R.]Drayton.
A line drawn through points of equal temperature in a verticalsection of the ocean.
To grow hard; to harden, or become hard; as, clay indurates bydrying, and by heat.
The fifteenth day of March, May, July, and October, and thethirteenth day of the other months.The ides of March remember. Shak.
Inconsistent. [Obs.]
Invested with office; inaugurated. Drayton.

Incapable of being reduced to a simpler form of expression; as,an irreducible formula. Irreducible case (Alg.), a particular case inthe solution of a cubic equation, in which the formula commonlyemployed contains an imaginary quantity, and therefore fails in itsapplication.-- Ir`re*du"ci*ble*ness, n.-- -- Ir`re*du"ci*bly, adv.
The quality or state of being irremovable; immovableness.
To fatten; to make fat. [Obs.] Bacon.
In a manner, or to a degree, above estimation; as, thingsinestimably excellent.
To become corporeal; to assume the qualities of a materialbody. See Embody.The soul grows clotted by contagion, Imbodies, and imbrutes. Milton.
Incomprehensible. [Obs.] "Incomprehense in virtue." Marston.

Accompanied with, or tending to cause, preternatural heat andexcitement of arterial action; as, an inflammatory disease.Inflammatory crust. (Med.) Same as Buffy coat, under Buffy.-- Inflammatory fever, a variety of fever due to inflammation.
See Izard.
Imperial. [R.] Gauden.
To place in a hive; to hive.
The state of being unavoidable; certainty to happen. Prideaux.

A plant (Mesembryanthemum crystallinum), sprinkled withpellucid, watery vesicles, which glisten like ice. It is native alongthe Mediterranean, in the Canaries, and in South Africa. Its juice issaid to be demulcent and diuretic; its ashes are used in Spain inmaking glass. Ice-skater = one who skates on ice wearing an iceskate; esp. an athlete who performs athletic or artistic movements ona sheet of ice, wearing ice skates; including speed skater and figureskater
Between the times of sleeping; in an interval of wakefulness.[R.]
To cut off. [R.]
Making inquiry; inquiring; questioning. [Obs.] Shenstone.
Absence of expectation. Feltham.
See Embowel.

Pertaining to, made by, or prepared for, an instrument, esp. amusical instrument; as, instrumental music, distinguished from vocalmusic. "He defended the use of instrumental music in public worship."Macaulay.Sweet voices mix'd with instrumental sounds. Dryden.
To require; to demand. [Obs.]We shall write to you, As time and our concernings shall importune.Shak.
The state or quality of being irremediable.
Invariably attached to some word, stem, or root; as, theinseparable particle un-.

That which moves or influences the mind, or operates on thepassions; that which incites, or has a tendency to incite, todetermination or action; that which prompts to good or ill; motive;spur; as, the love of money, and the desire of promotion, are twopowerful incentives to action.The greatest obstacles, the greatest terrors that come in their way,are so far from making them quit the work they had begun, that theyrather prove incentives to them to go on in it. South.
In an interesting manner.
The discussion or description of portraiture or ofrepresentative images. Cf. Iconography.
Pertaining to the Iguanidæ.
Matchless; peerless. [Obs.] Holland.
See Entitle.
A nitrogenous substance resembling vitellin, present in the eggyolk of cartilaginous fishes.
Agency; influence; production of effects. [Obs.] Bp. Hall.
Incapable of falling or erring; infalliable. [Obs.] --Il`la*bil"i*ty, n. [Obs.]
Deceiving by false show; deceitful; deceptive; false; illusory;unreal.Truth from illusive falsehood to command. Thomson.
One who individualizes.
The vessel in which incense is burned and offered; a censer; athurible. [R.] Evelyn.
Investiture; investment. [Obs.] Bp. Burnet.
The text of a book. [R.] Herrick.

A blue dyestuff obtained from several plants belonging to verydifferent genera and orders; as, the woad, Isatis tinctoria,Indigofera tinctoria, I. Anil, Nereum tinctorium, etc. It is a darkblue earthy substance, tasteless and odorless, with a copper-violetluster when rubbed. Indigo does not exist in the plants as such, butis obtained by decomposition of the glycoside indican.
Electric by virtue of its own peculiar properties; capable ofbecoming electrified by friction; -- opposed to anelectric.-- n.
Impervious to heat; adiathermic.
Quality of being inventible.
Unparalleled. [Obs.]
An inhabitant. [Obs.] Spenser.
Sinlessness. Bp. Hall.
To strengthen, as with sinews; to invigorate. [Obs.]All members of our cause, . . . That are insinewed to this action.Shak.
The infernal regions; hell. Also used fig.
Not capable of being pierced; impenetrable. [Obs.] Spenser.
In an incogitant manner.
In an interjectional manner. G. Eliot.
Incapable of being justly reproved; irreproachable; blameless;upright.-- Ir`re*prov"a*ble*ness, n.-- Ir`re*prov"a*bly, adv.
The quality or state of being inadequate or insufficient;defectiveness; insufficiency; inadequateness.The inadequacy and consequent inefficacy of the alleged causes. Dr.T. Dwight.
The quality of being insociable; want of sociability;unsociability. [R.] Bp. Warburton.
The condition of being impenitent; failure or refusal torepent; hardness of heart.He will advance from one degree of wickedness and impenitence toanother. Rogers.
To confine in, or as in, a cage; to coop up. [Written alsoencage.] "Incaged birds." Shak.
Inclosed; confined. Included stamens (Bot.), such as areshorter than the floral envelopes, or are concealed within them.
Indicating equal barometric pressure.
The quality or state of being identical; sameness.
Act of impugning; opposition; attack. [Obs.]A perpetual impugnation and self-conflict. Bp. Hall.
Inspectorship. [R.]
The science which treats of the origin of ideas.
In an infallible manner; certainly; unfailingly; unerringly.Blair.
Done by imposture. [Obs.]
To make to understand; to instruct. [Prov. Eng.] Halliwell.
Mutual knowledge or acquaintance. [Obs.] Bacon.
Inestimable. [R.] Drayton.

To live or dwell in; to occupy, as a place of settledresidence; as, wild beasts inhabit the forest; men inhabit cities andhouses.The high and lofty One, that inhabiteth eternity. Is. lvii. 15.O, who would inhabit This bleak world alone Moore.
The act of coming between; intervention; interference. [Obs.]
A writ of prohibition against proceeding in the spiritual courtin certain cases, when the suit belongs to the common-law courts.Wharton (Law Dict. ).
The quality of being imposing.
The state or quality of being incorrigible.The ingratitude, the incorrigibility, the strange perverseness . . .of mankind. Barrow.
Inward sense; mind; understanding; conscience. [Obs.] Wyclif.
A iodide of quinine obtained as a brown substance,. It is thebase of herapathite. See Herapathite.
Engraved in intaglio; as, an intagliated stone. T. Warton.
Want of attention, or failure to pay attention; disregard;heedlessness; neglect.Novel lays attract our ravished ears; But old, the mind inattentionhears. Pope.
A treatise on fishes.
The act of working in together; interweaving. Milton.
Disobedience. [Obs.] Wyclif. Chaucer.
In an immoral manner; wickedly.
Search; inquiry; investigation. [Obs.]

The act of imposing the columns of a page, or the pages of asheet. See Impose, v. t., 4. Imposing stone (Print.), the stone onwhich the pages or columns of types are imposed or made into forms; -- called also imposing table.
One who, or that which, isolates.
To render vile. [Obs.] Daniel.
Of or pertaining to the iconoclasts, or to image breaking.Milman.
Incurable. [Obs.]
Without abuse.
An apparatus to determine the inclination of the earth'smagnetic force to the plane of the horizon; -- called alsoinclination compass, and dip circle.
Not cognizable by a judge. [Obs.] Bailey.
The act of burying vessels in warm earth in order to exposetheir contents to a steady moderate heat; the state of being thusexposed.
The native name of Persia.
To inclose in limits; to shut in. [Obs.] Shak.
Incapable of being supported or borne; unendurable;insufferable; intolerable; as, insupportable burdens; insupportablepain.-- In`sup*port"a*ble*ness, n.-- In`sup*port"a*bly, adv.
To insulate. See Insulate.
Producing but one kind of spore, as the ferns.
Not capable of exact division, as one quantity by another;incommensurable.
Informing; giving information; talebearing. [Obs.] Shak.That sad intelligencing tyrant. Milton.
In an inferior manner, or on the inferior part.
To impregnate. [Obs.] Fuller.
Having exponents which are radical quantities; -- said ofcertain powers; as, xsq. root2, or xsq. roota. Interscedent series, aseries whose terms are interscendent quantities. Hutton.
Not comprehensive; not capable of including or ofunderstanding; not extensive; limited.-- In*com`pre*hen"sive*ly, a. Sir W. Hamilton.-- In*com`pre*hen"sive*ness, n. T. Warton.
A dark yellow, crystalline substance, obtained by the action ofammonia on isatin.
The conceptive faculty.
Without harmony.
Not concrete. [R.] L. Andrews.
Want or neglect of observance. Bacon.
Inextinguishable. [Obs.] Sir T. More.

Not felicitous; unhappy; unfortunate; not fortunate orappropriate in application; not well said, expressed, or done; as, aninfelicitous condition; an infelicitous remark; an infelicitousdescription; infelicitous words.
Cumbersome; troublesome. [Written also encombrous.] [Obs.]Chaucer.
A line connecting places on the earth's surface at which thereis the same mean frequency of auroras.
Ingrateful. [Obs. or Poetic] Bacon.
Ungracious; unkind. [Obs.] Holland.
Naturally.
Within lobules; as, the intralobular branches of the hepaticveins.
The doctrine, belief, or principles of the Inralapsarians.
Worn, wrought, or stamped in. [R.] Milton.
See Pester. [Obs.]
The stress of voice laid upon accented syllable of a word. Cf.Arsis.
A genus of leguminous plants having many species, mostly intropical countries, several of them yielding indigo, esp. Indigoferatinctoria, and I. Anil.
Arts or practice of intrigue.
Capable of being inoculated; capable of communicating disease,or of being communicated, by inoculation.
Unceasing; continual. [Obs.] Shelton.-- In*ces"sa*bly, adv. [Obs.]
The act or conduct of an impostor; deception practiced under afalse or assumed character; fraud or imposition; cheating.From new legends And fill the world with follies and impostures.Johnson.
Within the uterus or womb; as, intrauterine hemorrhage.
Of or pertaining to an inventory.-- In`ven*to"ri*al*ly, adv. Shak.
Cloudless. [Obs.] Blount.
Without punishment; with impunity. [Obs.] J. Ellis.
A man born in Ireland or of the Irish race; an Hibernian.Irishman's hurricane (Naut.), a dead calm.-- Irishman's reef. (Naut.) See Irish reef, under Irish, a.
Anger; wrath. [Poet.]

Guilty of incest; involving, or pertaining to, the crime ofincest; as, an incestuous person or connection. Shak.Ere you reach to this incestuous love, You must divine and humanrights remove. Dryden.-- In*cest"tu*ous*ly, adv.-- In*cest"tu*ous*ness, n.
To separate (a compound) into ions, esp. by dissolving inwater. --I`on*i*za"tion (#), n.
To inter with funeral rites; to bury. [Obs.] G. Fletcher.
In a illegitimate manner; unlawfully.
Having equal density, as different regions of a medium; passingthrough points at which the density is equal; as, an isopycnic lineor surface.
The state of not coexisting. [Obs.] Locke.
Turning or facing inward, or toward the axis of the part towhich it belongs. Gray.
A dark brown resinous substance obtained from indican.
Not capable or susceptible of effervescence.
In an irreligious manner.
To water, as land, by causing a stream to flow upon, over, orthrough it, as in artificial channels.

That which is taken into the body as food; the ingesta; --sometimes restricted to the nutritive, or digestible, portion of thefood. See Food. Opposed to output. Income bond, a bond issued on theincome of the corporation or company issuing it, and the interest ofwhich is to be paid from the earnings of the company before anydividends are made to stockholders; -- issued chiefly or exclusivelyby railroad companies.-- Income tax, a tax upon a person's incomes, emoluments, profits,etc., or upon the excess beyond a certain amount.
To bring into debt; to place under obligation; -- chiefly usedin the participle indebted.Thy fortune hath indebted thee to none. Daniel.
The act of incriminating; crimination.

Not reaching the end aimed at by the most plain and directmethod; as, an indirect proof, demonstration, etc. Indirect claims,claims for remote or consequential damage. Such claims were presentedto and thrown out by the commissioners who arbitrated the damageinflicted on the United States by the Confederate States cruisersbuilt and supplied by Great Britain.-- Indirect demonstration, a mode of demonstration in which proof isgiven by showing that any other supposition involves an absurdity(reductio ad absurdum), or an impossibility; thus, one quantity maybe proved equal to another by showing that it can be neither greaternor less.-- Indirect discourse. (Gram.) See Direct discourse, under Direct.-- Indirect evidence, evidence or testimony which is circumstantialor inferential, but without witness; -- opposed to direct evidence.-- Indirect tax, a tax, such as customs, excises, etc., exacteddirectly from the merchant, but paid indirectly by the consumer inthe higher price demanded for the articles of merchandise.
Causing incoherence. [R.]
Not appreciable; too small to be perceived; incapable of beingduly valued or estimated. Hallam.
One who, or that which, impels; an inciter. [R.] Sir T. Browne.
The quality or state of being ineffable or unutterable;unspeakableness.
To cover, as with a mask; to disguise or conceal. [R.] Shak.
The act or operation of smearing the body with mud, especiallywith the sediment from mineral springs; a mud bath.
Having no wings, as some insects.
In a idolatrous manner.
Of or pertaining to an isothermobath; possessing or indicatingequal temperatures in a vertical section, as of the ocean.
Drawn in.

To set within something; to put or thrust in; to introduce; tocause to enter, or be included, or contained; as, to insert a scionin a stock; to insert a letter, word, or passage in a composition; toinsert an advertisement in a newspaper.These words were very weakly inserted where they will be so liable tomisconstruction. Bp. Stillingfleet.
To change the position of; -- said of tones which form a chord,or parts which compose harmony.
Pertaining to the ilium and femur; as, iliofemoral ligaments.
Intricate. [Obs.] Shak.
Having the pallial line entire, or without a sinus, as certainbivalve shells.
A primary division of the Mammalia, including the monotremesand marsupials, in which no placenta is formed.
The reedbuck of South Africa. [Written also ingali.]
Feeding or subsisting on insects; carnivorous. The term isapplied: (a) to
The bitter principle of the holly.
Having a border or outline composed of semicircles with theconvexity outward; -- the opposite of engrailed.
A clock that is designed to keep very accurate time.
Absence of removal.
The state or quality of being infallible; infallibility. Bp.Hall.
A philosophical toy for exhibiting the prismatic tints by meansof thin films.

Whatever is impressed or imprinted; the impress or mark left bysomething; specifically, the name of the printer or publisher(usually) with the time and place of issue, in the title-page of abook, or on any printed sheet. "That imprint of their hands." Buckle.
In an incised manner.
Imbricate.
The act of impoverishing, or the state of being impoverished;reduction to poverty. Sir W. Scott.
To take lodging; to lodge. [R.] Addison.
Restless; sleepless. Blount.
Unimaginable; inconceivable. [R.] Bp. Pearson.
A cuttlefish. See Cuttlefish.
Untilled; uncultivated; crude; rude; uncivilized.Germany then, says Tacitus, was incult and horrid, now full ofmagnificent cities. Burton.His style is diffuse and incult. M. W. Shelley.
An implosive sound. Ellis.
Not turned or changed about. [R.] Sir T. Browne.
Raw; indigestible. [Obs.] Bp. Hall.
One who holds Kent.
To bring within meshes, as of a net; to enmesh.
Incapable of being defined or described; inexplicable. Bp.Reynolds.
See Addorsed.
Between rami or branches; esp., between the mandibles, or ramiof the lower jaw; intermandibular.
Inciting to motion; -- applied to that action which, in thecase of muscular motion, commences in the nerve centers, and excitesthe muscles to contraction. Opposed to excito-motor.
Want of apprehension.
Actuated or characterized by passion or zeal; showing warmth offeeling; ardent; animated; excited; as, an impassioned orator ordiscourse.
Uselessness; the quality of being unprofitable;unprofitableness; as, the inutility of vain speculations andvisionary projects.
In an imprescriptible manner; obviously.
Irreverent. [Obs.]Immodest speech, or irreverend gesture. Strype.
Defilement; obscuration. [Obs.] Bp. Hall.
The gorilla.
In an independent manner; without control.
To lodge in a chamber. [R.] Sherwood.
The mutual right to civic privileges, in the different States.Bancroft.
Penetrating among or between other substances; penetrating eachthe other; mutually penetrative.
Not penitent; not repenting of sin; not contrite; of a hardheart. "They . . . died impenitent." Milton. "A careless andimpenitent heart." Bp. Hall.
A variety of tourmaline of an indigo-blue color.
To weaken, as to the body or the mind; to enfeeble. [R.] A.Wilson.
The act of kindling, or the state of being kindled or on fire.Bacon.
Not admitting of being vitrified, or converted into glass.Kirwan.
To conceal, as in bushes; to hide. [Obs.] Shelton.
Weak; impotent; feeble.
Too odious to be expressed or mentioned. [Obs.] Howell.
To convert into, or to use as, an interjection. Earle.
Want of charity. [Obs.] Evelyn.
Being or coming between; intercedent; interposed. [Obs.] Bacon.

Not prudent; wanting in prudence or discretion; indiscreet;injudicious; not attentive to consequence; improper.-- Im*pru"dent*ly, adv.Her majesty took a great dislike at the imprudent behavior of many ofthe ministers and readers. Strype.
See Enlighten.

Capable of taking by inheritance, or of receiving by descent;capable of succeeding to, as an heir.By attainder . . . the blood of the person attainted is so corruptedas to be rendered no longer inheritable. Blackstone.The eldest daughter of the king is also alone inheritable to thecrown on failure of issue male. Blackstone.Inheritable blood, blood or relationship by which a person becomesqualified to be an heir, or to transmit possessions by inheritance.
In a manner, or to a degree, that precludes remedy, cure, orcorrection.
Not preventable; invitable.
One of the contestants in interference before the PatentOffice. [U.S.]
The top member of a pillar, pier, wall, etc., upon which theweight of an arch rests.
See Enable.

The collective attributes, qualities, or marks that make up acomplex general notion; the comprehension, content, or connotation; -- opposed to extension, extent, or sphere.This law is, that the intension of our knowledge is in the inverseratio of its extension. Sir W. Hamilton.
Pertaining to, or characterized by, ideation.Certain sensational or ideational stimuli. Blackw. Mag.
To signify; to purport; to be of moment. "For that . . .importeth to the work." Bacon.
One who, or that which, inflates; as, the inflaters of thestock exchange.
Not capable of being mixed or mingled.A chaos of immiscible and conflicting particles. Cudworth.
Matter stated by way of explanatory preamble or introduction tothe main allegations of a pleading; a leading to.
Serving for incubation.
An Indian crested pheasant of the genus Lophophorus. Severalspecies are known. Called also monaul, monal.
The eland. [Written also impoofoo.]
Undeserving. [Obs.] Milton.
To intermeddle; to intermix. [Obs.] Bp. Fisher.
Not deciduous or falling, as the leaves of trees in autumn;lasting; evergreen; persistent; permanent; perennial.The indeciduous and unshaven locks of Apollo. Sir T. Browne.
The quality of being impermeable.
Applied to a semipermanent contraction of a muscle, produced bya mechanical irritant.
Placed or standing alone; detached; separated from others.Isolated point of a curve. (Geom.) See Acnode.
Not admissible; not proper to be admitted, allowed, orreceived; as, inadmissible testimony; an inadmissible proposition, orexplanation.-- In`ad*mis"si*bly, adv.
Not attentive; not fixing the mind on an object; heedless;careless; negligent; regardless; as, an inattentive spectator orhearer; an inattentive habit. I. Watts.
Pertaining to, or resulting from, the process of growth; as,the incremental lines in the dentine of teeth.
Not remissible; unpardonable; as, irremissible crimes. Burke.-- Ir`re*mis"si*ble, n.-- Ir`re*mis"si*bly, adv.
The state of quality of being infeasible; infeasibility. W.Montagu.
Same as Improvisate.
The state or quality of being immaterial or incorporeal; as,the immateriality of the soul.
A title given to every one of sons of the kings of Spain andPortugal, except the eldest or heir apparent.
A variety of the chamois found in the Pyrenees.
An anthem or psalm sung before the Communion service.

An averment employed in pleading, to point the application ofmatter otherwise unintelligible; an interpretative parenthesis throwninto quoted matter to explain an obscure word or words; -- as, theplaintiff avers that the defendant said that he (innuendo theplaintiff) was a thief. Wharton.
A kind of injector for forcing water by steam. See Injector,n., 2.
A lodging house for Mohammedan pilgrims. Moore.
The act of imbittering; bitter feeling; embitterment.
Used in copulation; -- said of the external reproductive organsof the males of many animals, and sometimes of those of the females.
Immersed; buried; hid; sunk. [Obs.] "Things immerse in matter."Bacon.
Incapable of being executed or performed; impracticable;infeasible.
Incapable of being oxidized; as, gold and platinum areinoxidizable in the air.
Not salubrious or healthful; unwholesome; as, an insalubriousair or climate.

The principal goddess worshiped by the Egyptians. She wasregarded as the mother of Horus, and the sister and wife of Osiris.The Egyptians adored her as the goddess of fecundity, and as thegreat benefactress of their country, who instructed their ancestorsin the art of agriculture.
Turned into, or reduced to, a village. [Obs.] W. Browne.
See Involucre.
The act of intercepting; as, interception of a letter;interception of the enemy.
The faith, doctrines, or religious system of the Mohammedans;Mohammedanism; Islam.
One who, or that which, inspirer. "Inspirer of that holyflame." Cowper.
the quality of being impeccable; exemption from sin, error, oroffense.Infallibility and impeccability are two of his attributes. Pope.
Not expectant. C. Bronté.
See Emmew.
The act of putting one in possession of an estate in fee. SirM. Hale.
In an international manner; from an international point ofview.
Having equal, or almost equal, authority with the apostles oftheir teachings.
Incapable of being held; untenable; not defensible; as, anintenable opinion; an intenable fortress. [Obs.] Bp. Warburton.
The state of being undigested; unripeness; immaturity. [Obs.]Bacon.
Incapable of being reformed; incorrigible. Joseph Cook.
Not admitting dispensation; not subject to release orexemption. [R.]The law was moral and indispensable. Bp. Burnet.
One who worships images.
A white heat, or the glowing or luminous whiteness of a bodycaused by intense heat.
A token, mark, or explanation. [Obs.] Sir T. Elyot.
The whole of a system of machines, apparatus, and accessories,when set up and arranged for practical working, as in electriclighting, transmission of power, etc.
Things which impede or hinder progress; incumbrances; baggage;specif. (Mil.),

The exercise of the imagination in selecting and treating atheme, or more commonly in contriving the arrangement of a piece, orthe method of presenting its parts. Invention of the cross (Eccl.), afestival celebrated May 3d, in honor of the finding of our Savior'scross by St. Helena.
Not compliable; not conformable.
Not dubitable or doubtful; too evident to admit of doubt;unquestionable; evident; apparently certain; as, an indubitableconclusion.-- n.
The state or quality of being imaginary; unreality.
An herb of the Mint family (Sideritis), supposed to heal swordcuts; also, a species of Galeopsis.
In an indissoluble manner.On they move, indissolubly firm. Milton.
Incongruous. Sir T. Elyot.
The quality of being incorrect; want of conformity to truth orto a standard; inaccuracy; inexactness; as incorrectness may indefect or in redundance.
Enamored. Chapman.-- In*am"o*rate*ly, adv. [R.]
Not capable of being extinguished; extinguishable;unquenchable; as, inextinguishable flame, light, thirst, desire,feuds. "Inextinguishable rage." Milton.
A comprehensive division of the animal kingdom, including allexcept the Vertebrata.
To prevent the transfer o Insulating stool (Elec.), a stoolwith legs of glass or some other nonconductor of electricity, usedfor insulating a person or any object placed upon it.
Immoderateness. [R.] Sir T. Browne.
Not cognizant; failing to apprehended or notice.Of the several operations themselves, as acts of volition, we arewholly incognizant. Sir W. Hamilton.
Destitute of a backbone; having no vertebræ; of or pertainingto the Invertebrata.-- n.
The quality of being impartible; communicability. Blackstone.
The act of inavlidating, or the state of being invalidated.So many invalidations of their right. Burke.
A dealer in iron or hardware.
A descendant of Israel, or Jacob; a Hebrew; a Jew.
Embodied in bread, esp. in the bread of the eucharist. [Obs.]Cranmer.
In an impersonal manner.
Emitting sparks of fire when struck with steel; scintillating;as, ignescent stones.
Gluttonous. [Obs.] Blount.

The specific signification of in is situation or place withrespect to surrounding, environment, encompassment, etc. It is usedwith verbs signifying being, resting, or moving within limits, orwithin circumstances or conditions of any kind conceived of aslimiting, confining, or investing, either wholly or in part. In itsdifferent applications, it approaches some of the meanings of, andsometimes is interchangeable with, within, into, on, at, of, andamong. It is used: --
The loon. See Ember-goose.
In an ideal manner; by means of ideals; mentally.
The act of pawning or pledging; the state of being pawned.[Obs.] Bailey.
Exciting; producing irritation; irritating. [R.] Hales.
Striking against or upon.
Immeasurable; unlimited. In commonest use: Very great; vast;huge. "Immense the power" Pope. "Immense and boundless ocean."Daniel.O Goodness infinite! Goodness immense! Milton.
Incapable of being disturbed or disconcerted; as, imperturbablegravity.
Developed alike in the directions of the several lateral axes;-- said of crystals of both the tetragonal and hexagonal systems.
Deviation from correct orthography; bad spelling. [Obs.]Feltham.
A tree unusually hard, strong, or heavy wood.
Set; fast; fixed. Dr. John Smith.

Not compressible; incapable of being reduced by force orpressure into a smaller compass or volume; resisting compression; as,many liquids and solids appear to be almost incompressible.-- In`com*press"i*ble*ness, n.
Quality of being irrestible.

Want of resolution; want of decision in purpose; a fluctuationof mind, as in doubt, or between hope and fear; irresoluteness;indecision; vacillation.Irresolution on the schemes of life which offer themselves to ourchoice, and inconstancy in pursuing them, are the greatest causes ofall unhappiness. Addison.
Inarticulateness. Chesterfield.

The act of turning the mind toward an object; hence, a design;a purpose; intention; meaning; drift; aim.Be thy intents wicked or charitable. Shak.The principal intent of Scripture is to deliver the Hooker.To all intents, and purposes, in all applications or senses;practically; really; virtually; essentially. "He was miserable to allintents and purpose." L'Estrange.
Between muscles; as, intermuscular septa.
Having the same color; connecting parts having the same color,as lines drawn through certain points in experiments on the chromaticeffects of polarized light in crystals.
One who, or that which, insinuates. De Foe.
The Waldenses; -- so called from their peculiary cut or markedsabots, or shoes.
Without exhaustion.
A license to print or publish a book, paper, etc.; also, incountries subjected to the censorship of the press, approval of thatwhich is published.
The state or quality of being inexhaustible; abundance.
To make thirsty. [Obs.]
One who invents or finds out something new; a contriver;especially, one who invents mechanical devices.
Blown in or into. [Obs.]
Distinguishing. [Obs.] Wallis.
Pertaining to, possessing, or like, an involucrum.
The quality of being incogitative; want of thought or of thepower of thinking. Wollaston.
The quality or state of being inviolable; inviolableness.
To shut in; to inclose. [Obs.]
Blamelessly. South.

The quality of being insincere; want of sincerity, or of beingin reality what one appears to be; dissimulation; hypocritical;deceitfulness; hollowness; untrustworthiness; as, the insincerity ofa professed friend; the insincerity of professions of regard.What men call policy and knowledge of the world, is commonly no otherthing than dissimulation and insincerity. Blair.
Insuppressible. [Obs.] "The insuppressive mettle of ourspirits." Shak.
Internodal. [R.]
A little island.
In an infamous manner or degree; scandalously; disgracefully;shamefully.The sealed fountain of royal bounty which had been infamouslymonopolized and huckstered. Burke.

The quality of being incomprehensible, or beyond the reach ofhuman intellect; incomprehensibleness; inconceivability;inexplicability.The constant, universal sense of all antiquity unanimously confessingan incomprehensibility in many of the articles of the Christianfaith. South.
Full of meaning. [Obs.] Shak.
A tribe of bivalve mollusks, characterized by the closed stateof the mantle which envelops the body. The ship borer (Teredonavalis) is an example.
An iambus or iambic. [R.]
The edible viscera of animals, as the heart, liver, etc.
A brown amorphous substance resembling humin, and obtained fromindican.
To be incapable of combining; to disagree; to differ. [Obs.]Milton.
Same as Enthrone.
The state or quality of being intent; close application;attention.Extreme solicitude or intentness upon business. South.
One who favors an increased or very large issue of paper money.[U.S.]
Leaning or resting; -- said of anthers when lying on the innerside of the filament, or of cotyledons when the radicle lies againstthe back of one of them. Gray.
Imputing blame; criminatory; compromising; implicating.
An instiller. [R.]
An imaginary line, or a line on a chart, marking thesimultaneous development of a thunderstorm, as noted by observing thetime when the thunder is heard at different places.
A forked exlpansion or divergence; a bifurcation; a branching.Craig.
Stratification among or between other layers or strata; also,that which is interstratified.
Ungratefully. [Obs.]
One of the elements which appear at the respective poles when abody is subjected to electro-chemical decomposition. Cf. Anion,Cation.
To invigorate. [Obs.]
Incapable of expansion, enlargement, or extension. Tyndall.
A physician who explained or treated diseases upon chemicalprinciples; one who practiced iatrochemistry.
Between or among the stars; as, interstellar space. Bacon.
Having an involucre, as umbels, heads, etc. Martyn.
Endowed with intellect; having intellectual powers orcapacities. [R.]In body, and in bristles, they became As swine, yet intellected asbefore. Cowper.
Between the nasal cavities; as, the internasal cartilage.
The mark as an individual, or to distinguish from others bypeculiar properties; to invest with individuality.The peculiarities which individualize and distinguish the humor ofAddison. N. Drake.
The quality or state of being indissoluble.
Not quenched; not extinct.
In a improvident manner. "Improvidently rash." Drayton.
Without decision.
To intertwine; to weave or bind together. [Obs.] B. Jonson.
The quality or state of being inconstant; want of constancy;mutability; fickleness; variableness.For unto knight there was no greater shame, Than lightness andinconstancie in love. Spenser.
Involving, or accompanied by, mutual slaughter; mutuallydestructive.Internecine quarrels, horrible tumults, stain the streets with blood.Motley.
Want of perspicuity or clearness; vaguness; ambiguity.
See Isle, n., 2. Islands of the blessed (Myth.), islandssupposed to lie in the Western Ocean, where the favorites of the godsare conveyed at death, and dwell in everlasting joy.
The amount or degree of energy with which a force operates or acause acts; effectiveness, as estimated by results produced.
The quality of being insubordinate; disobedience to lawfulauthority.
To ally, or form an alliance witgh; to unite; to combine.With a willingness inleague our blood With his, for purchase of fullgrowth in friendship. Ford.
To inclose in a case; to inclose; to cover or surround withsomething solid.Rich plates of gold the folding doors incase. Pope.
Having equal perimeters of circumferences; as, isoperimetricalfigures or bodies.
Insanity. [Obs.] Shak.
The state or quality of being undigested; crudeness. Bp.Burnet.
The act or process of covering with integuments; the state ormanner of being thus covered.
Not to be diverted or turned aside. [R.] Lamb.

To charge with a crime, in due form of law, by the finding orpresentment of a grand jury; to find an indictment against; as, toindict a man for arson. It is the peculiar province of a grand juryto indict, as it is of a house of representatives to impeach.
; sing. Iowa. (Ethnol.) A tribe of Indians which formerlyoccupied the region now included in the State of Iowa.
In an indecent manner.
To mix; to mingle. [R.]Amongst her tears immixing prayers meek. Spenser.
By inference; as an illative; in an illative manner.
An intervening or inserted chapter.
Belonging to instillation. [R.]
In an imperative manner.
Alluring; tempting; as, an inviting amusement or prospect.Nothing is so easy and inviting as the retort of abuse and sarcasm.W. Irving.-- In*vit"ing*ly, adv.-- In*vit"ing*ness, n. Jer. Taylor.
Not capable of making a will; not legally qualified orcompetent to make a testament. Blackstone.
To be inherent; to stick (in); to be fixed or permanentlyincorporated with something; to cleave (to); to belong, as attributesor qualities.They do but inhere in the subject that supports them. Digby.
The property of remaining invariable under prescribed orimplied conditions. J. J. Sylvester.
An instrument for measuring or ascertaining the degree or rateof electrical induction.
Within the territory or a territory.
Incitingly; temptingly.
To make like a bow; to curve; to arch; to vault; to embow."Imbowed windows." Bacon.
One of the Ichthyosaura.

To cut into or between; to cut or cross mutually; to divideinto parts; as, any two diameters of a circle intersect each other atthe center.Lands intersected by a narrow frith Abhor each other. Cowper.
A peculiar strong soup or broth, made in Scotland. [Writtenalso imrich.]
Not limited; interminable. Bp. Hall.-- Il*lim"it*ed*ness, n.The absoluteness and illimitedness of his commission was generallymuch spoken of. Clarendon.
Not inferring a conclusion or consequence; not conclusive.[Obs.]
A burden or charge upon property; a claim or lien upon anestate, which may diminish its value.
The quality or state of being inexplicable. H. Spencer.
In an impalpable manner.
Pertaining to, or containing, iodine. See -ous (chemicalsuffix). Iodous acid, a hypothetical acid, analogous to chlorousacid.
One who eats, or subsists on, fish.
Shining between.
Animating; cheering; moving; exhilarating; as, an inspiring orscene.
Want of solidity; weakness; as, the insolidity of an argument.[R.] Dr. H. More.
State of being illimitable; want of, or freedom from,limitation. Bp. Hall.
Not computable.
In an inclement manner.
Existing between royal courts. [R.] "Interaulic politics."Motley.
An engraving or other picture or illustration for a book.
A mutual joining. [R.]
Nonresistance; passive submission.
One who imports; the merchant who brings goods into a countryor state; -- opposed to exporter.
Want of intelligence; stupidity; folly. [R.] Blount.
To pave. [Poetic]Impaved with rude fidelity Of art mosaic. Wordsworth.

In an indistinct manner; not clearly; confusedly; dimly; as,certain ideas are indistinctly comprehended.In its sides it was bounded distinctly, but on its ends confusedly anindistinctly. Sir I. Newton.
Same as Ichthus.
The state of being pregnant or impregnated. [Obs.]
Deviation from custom, rule, or right; irregularity;inordinacy. [Obs.] South.Every inordination of religion that is not in defect, is properlycalled superstition. Jer. Taylor.
Of irregular form; shapeless. [Obs.] Sir T. Browne.
To fill (a vessel, cavity, or tissue) with a fluid or othersubstance; as, to inject the blood vessels.
Inherence; inherent existence. I. Watts.
The crash or concussion attending the breaking up of masses ofice, -- often due to contraction from extreme cold.
To alter or vary between; to change. [Obs.] Rush.
Want of action or activity; forbearance from labor; idleness;rest; inertness. Berkeley.
Not sensuous; not pertaining to, affecting, or addressing, thesenses.That intermediate door Betwixt the different planes of sensuous formAnd form insensuous. Mrs. Browning.
Of or pertaining to the interval or zone along the sea bottom,at the depth of between fifty and one hundred fathoms. E. Forbes.

The state or quality of being intricate or entangled;perplexity; involution; complication; complexity; that which isintricate or involved; as, the intricacy of a knot; the intricacy ofaccounts; the intricacy of a cause in controversy; the intricacy of aplot.Freed from intricacies, taught to live The easiest way. Milton.
To cut; to separate and remove; to resolve or break up, as bymedicines. [Obs.] Arbuthnot.
Not discussed. [Obs.] Donne.
Overgrown with ivy.
A supposed element claimed to have been discovered byR.Harmann.
An expression consisting of two unequal quantities, with thesign of inequality (> or <) between them; as, the inequality 2 < 3,or 4 > 1.
Of or pertaining to incubation, or to the period of incubation.
The clear space between two columns, measured at the bottom oftheir shafts. Gwilt.
. A combining form from the Greek private, personal, peculiar,distinct.
Disreputable. [Obs.]
Supplicatory; entreating. [R.] Carlyle.
In an impatient manner.
Intention. [Obs.]
In an intent manner; as, the eyes intently fixed.
The angle made by two lines or planes; as, the inclination ofthe plane of the earth's equator to the plane of the ecliptic isabout 23º 28'; the inclination of two rays of light.
To shut up or inclose, as in a pen. Feltham.
The penetrating of one rock, while in a plastic or metal state,into the cavities of another.
Pertaining to, or formed by, intersections.
Mutual slaughter or destruction; massacre. [Obs.] Sir M. Hale.
Serving to illustrate.
In an incorrigible manner.
Injury; invasion of another's rights.
A morphological unit, consisting of two or more plastids, whichdoes not possess the positive character of the person or stock, indistinction from the physiological organ or biorgan. See Morphon.
Not directed; aimless. [Obs.]
Not recognizable. Carlyle.
The temporary cessation or subsidence of a fever; the space oftime between the paroxysms of a disease. Intermission is an entirecessation, as distinguished from remission, or abatement of fever.
A body of Kaffir warriors; a body of native armed men. [SouthAfrica]
Hard-hearted; unfeeling; cruel; as, an iron-hearted master.Cowper.
Impending; threatening.Impendent horrors, threatening hideous fall. Milton.
The quality of being indestructible.
Unexpectedness. [Obs.]
Immature.
Wanting wisdom; stupid; foolish. [R.] Clarendon.-- n.
Between atoms; situated, or acting, between the atoms ofbodies; as, interatomic forces.
See Intorsion.

Of or pertaining to, or producing, inhibition; consisting ininhibition; tending or serving to inhibit; as, the inhibitory actionof the pneumogastric on the respiratory center.I would not have you consider these criticisms as inhibitory. Lamb.Inhibitory nerves (Physiol.), those nerves which modify, inhibit, orsuppress a motor or secretory act already in progress.
Tending toinfluence; influential.
Interposition. [Obs.] Sir H. Blount.
The Urodela.
Want of veracity.

That which fulfills or supplies a want or use; esp., aninstrument, toll, or utensil, as supplying a requisite to an end; as,the implements of trade, of husbandry, or of war.Genius must have talent as its complement and implement. Coleridge.
Intemperance. [Obs.]
An intimate friend or associate; a confidant. Gov. of theTongue.

Not mutable; not capable or susceptible of change;unchangeable; unalterable.That by two immutable things, in which it was impossible for God tolie, we might have a strong consolation. Heb. vi. 18.Immutable, immortal, infinite, Eternal King. Milton.-- Im*mu"ta*ble*ness, n.-- Im*mu"ta*bly, adv.
To produce, or cause, by proximity without contact ortransmission, as a particular electric or magnetic condition in abody, by the approach of another body in an opposite electric ormagnetic state.
Iridescent.
Capable of being immersed.
Situated within or between the axils of leaves.

Incapable of being exhausted, emptied, or used up; unfailing;not to be wasted or spent; as, inexhaustible stores of provisions; aninexhaustible stock of elegant words. Dryden.An inexhaustible store of anecdotes. Macaulay.-- In`ex*haust"i*ble*ness, n.-- In`ex*haust"i*bly, adv.
A raised work like a bench. [Obs.] Parkhurst.
The insertion of points between word or sentences; punctuation.

Incapable of being passed over, surmounted, or overcome;insuperable; as, insurmountable difficulty or obstacle. Locke.Hope thinks nothing difficult; despair tells us that difficulty isinsurmountable. I. Watts.
In an inimical manner.
One who is impatient. [R.]
To satirize in iambics; to lampoon. [R.]
Not communicated or imparted. [Obs.] Dr. H. More.
Separated from other bodies by means of nonconductors of heator electricity.
Not to be appeased or quieted. [Obs.] Spenser.-- Im*pa"ca*bly, adv.
Making strict inquiry; inquisitorial. [Obs.] Milton.
Having the two ends unequal, as in the clam, quahaug, and mostlamellibranch shells.
Implicitness. [Obs.] Cotgrave.

Of or pertaining to an isthmus, especially to the Isthmus ofCorinth, in Greece. Isthmian games (Gr. Antiq.), one of the fourgreat national festivals of Greece, celebrated on the Isthmus ofCorinth in the spring of every alternate year. They consisted of allkinds of athletic sports, wrestling, boxing, racing on foot and inchariots, and also contests in music and poetry. The prize was agarland of pine leaves.
See Embalm.
Want of curiosity or interest; inattentiveness; indifference.Sir H. Wotton.
See Ingeny.
Closefisted; stingy; mean.
The quality or state of being inexorable. Chillingworth.
Isomorphous.
Not-officiously.
Pertaining to the ileum. [Written also iliac.]
The quality or state of being irrestible, irresistibleness.

Incapable of being recalled or revoked; unchangeable;irreversible; unalterable; as, an irrevocable promise or decree;irrevocable fate.Firm and irrevocable is my doom. Shak.-- Ir*rev"o*ca*ble*ness, n.-- Ir*rev"o*ca*bly, adv.
Causing little or no pain or annoyance; as, an indolent tumor.
See Involucel.
Of or pertaining to internodes; intervening between nodes orjoints.

Not partial; not favoring one more than another; treating allalike; unprejudiced; unbiased; disinterested; equitable; fair; just.Shak.Jove is impartial, and to both the same. Dryden.A comprehensive and impartial view. Macaulay.
Indisputableness.
One who, or that which, induces or incites.
An inflammation of the iris of the eye.

To call on for aid or protection; to invite earnestly orsolemnly; to summon; to address in prayer; to solicit or demand byinvocation; to implore; as, to invoke the Supreme Being, or to invokeHis and blessing.Go, my dread lord, to your great grandsire's tomb, . . . Invoke hiswarlike spirit. Shak.
To inlay into, as a piece of carving or other ornamentalobject.
The quality or state of being incapable; incapability.
Idolatrous. [Obs.]
Interstratified.
Between the parietal bones or cartilages; as, the interparietalsuture.-- n.
To draw within so as to meet yet not cut the boundaries.
Neglect of, or failure in, punctuality. [R.] A. Hamilton.
Indorsement. [Obs.]
To change or alter. [Obs.] J. Salkeld.
Characterized by, or introducing, innovations. Fitzed. Hall.
A short act or piece between others, as in a play; aninterlude; hence, intermediate employment or time. Chesterfield.
Not articulated; not jointed or connected by a joint.
Not having experience unskilled. "Inexperienced youth." Cowper.
To work in, as lace; to embellish with work resembling lace;also, to lace or enlace. P. Fletcher.
A composition resembling ivory in appearance and used as asubstitute for it.
Beginning; expressing or indicating beginning; as, an inceptiveproposition; an inceptive verb, which expresses the beginning ofaction; -- called also inchoative.-- In*cep"tive*ly, adv.
One who keeps an inn.
The doctrine that the perception or recognition of primarytruth is intuitive, or direct and immediate; -- opposed tosensationalism, and experientialism.

To graft with new feathers, as a wing; to splice a brokenfeather. Hence, Fig.: To repair; to extend; to increase; tostrengthen to equip. [Archaic]Imp out our drooping country's broken wing. Shak.Who lazily imp their wings with other men's plumes. Fuller. Here nofrail Muse shall imp her crippled wing. Holmes.Help, ye tart satirists, to imp my rage With all the scorpions thatshould whip this age. Cleveland.
See Episternum.
A sort of fillet worn by dignitaries, priests, and others amongthe ancient Romans. It was generally white.
The bending or twining of any part of a plant toward one sideor the other, or in any direction from the vertical.

Conveying knowledge; serving to instruct or inform; as,experience furnishes very instructive lessons. Addison.In various talk the instructive hours they past. Pope.-- In*struct"ive*ly, adv.-- In*struct"ive*ness, n.The pregnant instructiveness of the Scripture. Boyle.
Stratified among or between other bodies; as, interstratifiedrocks.
To inclose or fortify as with a wall. Spenser.
To rail in; to inclose or surround, as with rails. Hooker.
To dash between or among; to intersperse. Cowper.
India. [Poetical] Shak. Milton.
To flow in. [R.] Holland.
Immeasurable. [R.] Spenser.
Not eloquent; not fluent, graceful, or pathetic; notpersuasive; as, ineloquent language.Nor are thy lips ungraceful, sire of men, Nor tongue ineloquent.Milton.
Of or pertaining to infanticide; engaged in, or guilty of,child murder.
Inauspicious [Obs.] Sir G. Buck.
To inclose or defend with a bank or banks. See Embank.
Not luxurious. [R.] Orrery.
Combat. [Obs.] Daniel.
Exclamation. [Obs.] Bp. Hall.
A breaker of idols; an iconoclast.
See Saint Ignatius's bean, under Saint.
The state or quality of being insatiable; insatiableness.Eagerness for increase of possession deluges the soul, and we sinkinto the gulfs of insatiability. Rambler.
The state of being intervolved or coiled up; a convolution; as,the intervolutions of a snake. Hawthorne.
Influential. [Obs.]
The center of the circle inscribed in a triangle.
The lapse or interval of time between two events. [R.] Harvey.

In an direct manner; not in a straight line or course; not inexpress terms; obliquely; not by direct means; hence, unfairly;wrongly.To tax it indirectly by taxing their expense. A. Smith.Your crown and kingdom indirectly held. Shak.
Allurement. [R.] T. Brown.

The act of interceding; mediation; interposition betweenparties at variance, with a view to reconcilation; prayer, petition,or entreaty in favor of, or (less often) against, another or others.But the Spirit itself maketh intercession for us with groanings whichcan not be uttered. Rom. viii. 26.
Not to be healed; incurable. "Wounds immedicable." Milton.

A kind of lichen (Cetraria Icelandica) found from the Arcticregions to the North Temperate zone. It furnishes a nutritious jellyand other forms of food, and is used in pulmonary complaints as ademulcent.
The state or quality of being infamous; infamy.

Not to be stormed, or taken by assault; incapable of beingsubdued; able to resist attack; unconquerable; as, an impregnablefortress; impregnable virtue.The man's affection remains wholly unconcerned and impregnable.South.-- Im*preg"na*ble*ness, n.-- Im*preg"na*bly, adv.

Unsuitable. [Obs.] -- In*suit`a*bil"i*ty, n. [Obs.]
Same as Wootz.
Rolled inward from the edges; -- said of leaves in vernation,or of the petals of flowers in æstivation. Gray.

An artificial nitrogenous base, isomeric with urea, and forminga white crystalline substance; -- called also isuretine.

A cutting or engraving; a figure cut into something, as a gem,so as to make a design depressed below the surface of the material;hence, anything so carved or impressed, as a gem, matrix, etc.; --opposed to cameo. Also used adjectively.

Not admitting of appeal; not appealable. Coleridge.

In an indefinite manner or degree; without any settledlimitation; vaguely; not with certainty or exactness; as, to use aword indefinitely.If the world be indefinitely extended, that is, so far as no humanintellect can fancy any bound of it. Ray.

Titanic iron. See Menaccanite.
The act of painting or staining, especially of painting theface.

A plant of the genus Hedera (H. helix), common in Europe. Itsleaves are evergreen, dark, smooth, shining, and mostly five-pointed;the flowers yellowish and small; the berries black or yellow. Thestem clings to walls and trees by rootlike fibers.Direct The clasping ivy where to climb. Milton.Ye myrtles brown, with ivy never sere. Milton.American ivy. (Bot.) See Virginia creeper.-- English ivy (Bot.), a popular name in America for the ivy proper(Hedera helix).-- German ivy (Bot.), a creeping plant, with smooth, succulentstems, and fleshy, light-green leaves; a species of Senecio (S.scandens).-- Ground ivy. (Bot.) Gill (Nepeta Glechoma).-- Ivy bush. (Bot.) See Mountain laurel, under Mountain.-- Ivy owl (Zoöl.), the barn owl.-- Ivy tod (Bot.), the ivy plant. Tennyson.-- Japanese ivy (Bot.), a climbing plant (Ampelopsis tricuspidata),closely related to the Virginia creeper.-- Poison ivy (Bot.), an American woody creeper (RhusToxicodendron), with trifoliate leaves, and greenish-white berries.It is exceedingly poisonous to the touch for most persons.-- To pipe in an ivy leaf, to console one's self as best one can.[Obs.] Chaucer.-- West Indian ivy, a climbing plant of the genus Marcgravia.
To mention among other things, or casually or incidentally.[Obs.]
Want of adaptation; unsuitableness.
The yard adjoining an inn.
Not
In an inseparable manner or condition; so as not to beseparable. Bacon.And cleaves through life inseparably close. Cowper.

Not commensurable; having no common measure or standard ofcomparison; as, quantities are incommensurable when no third quantitycan be found that is an aliquot part of both; the side and diagonalof a square are incommensurable with each other; the diameter andcircumference of a circle are incommensurable.They are quantities incommensurable. Burke.-- In`com*men"su*ra*ble*ness, n.-- In`com*men"su*ra*bly, adv.
Of the nature of, or containing, imprecation; invokingevil; as,the imprecatory psalms.
Not methodical; without method or systematic arrangement;without order or regularity; confused. Addison.

Pertaining to ancient Ilium, or Troy. Gladstone.

Not capable of being submerged; buoyant. [R.]

The act of individualizing; the state of being individualized;individuation.

Not curious or inquisitive; without care for or interest in;inattentive; careless; negligent; heedless.Carelessnesses and incurious deportments toward their children. Jer.Taylor.

Tending to incommode; not commodious; not affording ease oradvantage; unsuitable; giving trouble; inconvenient; annoying; as, anincommodious seat; an incommodious arrangement.-- In`com*mo"di*ous*ly, adv.-- In`com*mo"di*ous*ness, n.
Oblique course or means; dishonest practices; indirectness. "Byindirections find directions out." Shak.
Of or pertaining to infancy, or to an infant; similar to, orcharacteristic of, an infant; childish; as, infantile behavior.
To weary; to give pain; to annoy; -- used only impersonally atpresent.To see this sight, it irks my very soul. Shak.It irketh him to be here. M. Arnold.

Want of legal ability or competency to do, give, transmit, orreceive something; inability; disqualification; as, the inacapacityof minors to make binding contracts, etc.
The quality or state of being ingenious; ingenuity.
Infectious. Beau. & Fl.True love . . . hath an infective power. Sir P. Sidney.

Liable or subject to impression; capable of being molded;susceptible; impressible.He was too impressionable; he had too much of the temperament ofgenius. Motley.A pretty face and an impressionable disposition. T. Hook.
Done by express direction; not involuntary; communded. [Obs.]Those imperate acts, wherein we see the empire of the soul. Sir M.Hale.
Want of prosperity. [Obs.]
Ingenuity; skill; cunning. [Obs.] Cudworth.

Regardless of natural obligation; contrary to natural duty;unkind; -- commonly said of a testament made without regard tonatural obligation, or by which a child is unjustly deprived ofinheritance. "The inofficious testament." Blackstone. "An inofficiousdisposition of his fortune." Paley.
To lose or spend time in inaction, or without being employed inbusiness. Shak.
In any framed work, a horizontal tie other than sill and plateor other principal ties, securing uprights to one another.
A dark red crystalline substance, isomeric with and resemblingindigo blue, and obtained from isatide and dioxindol.
In an indolent manner.Calm and serene you indolently sit. Addison.
Not controllable; uncontrollable.-- In`con*trol"la*bly, adv. South.

To join, as two coats of arms on one shield, palewise; hence,to join in honorable mention.Ordered the admission of St. Patrick to the same to be matched andimpaled with the blessed Virgin in the honor thereof. Fuller.
Cased or covered with iron, as a vessel; ironclad.
The principles of the Illuminati.
A written account of the particulars of merchandise shipped orsent to a purchaser, consignee, factor, etc., with the value orprices and charges annexed. Wharton.
Interpretative. [R.]
A line connecting points on the earth's surface having the samemean temperature in the coldest month of the year.
Innumerable. [Archaic] Milton.
Of or pertaining to Indo-China (i. e., Farther India, or Indiabeyond the Ganges).
Pertaining to, of the nature of, or characterized by,intercession or entreaty.
Not cogitable; inconceivable. Sir T. More.
The act or the place of entrance; an inlet. Tennyson.
Not having arrived at puberty; immature.In impuberal animals the cerebellum is, in proportion to the brainproper, greatly less than in adults. Sir W. Hamilton.
The quality of being inapplicable; unfitness; inapplicableness.
To include between; as, that part of the intercepted betweenthe points A and B.
With breaks or interruptions; discontinuously. Interruptedlypinnate (Bot.), pinnate with small leaflets intermixed with largeones. Gray.
Useless; unprofitable. [Obs.] Bacon.

One who composes and sings or recites rhymes and short poemsextemporaneously. [Written also improvisatore.]

The quality or condition of being imperfect; want ofperfection; incompleteness; deficiency; fault or blemish.Sent to my account With all my imperfections on my head. Shak.

Not capable of being searched out; inscrutable. [Obs.] --Im`per*scru"ta*ble*ness, n. [Obs.]

A large, handsome, North American woodpecker (Campephilusprincipalis), having a large, sharp, ivory-colored beak. Its generalcolor is glossy black, with white secondaries, and a white dorsalstripe. The male has a large, scarlet crest. It is now rare, andfound only in the Gulf States.

A large and handsome American moth (Hyperchiria Io), having alarge, bright-colored spot on each hind wing, resembling the spots onthe tail of a peacock. The larva is covered with prickly hairs, whichsting like nettles.
Below the temple; below the temporal bone.
Interpelling; interrupting.-- n.
A transparent variety of calcite, the best of which is obtainedin Iceland. It is used for the prisms of the polariscope, because ofits strong double refraction. Cf. Calcite.
Between tubes or tubules; as, intertubular cells; intertubularsubstance.

Making no distinction; not discriminating.
Of equal value. Isorropic line (in a diagram) (Geom.), thelocus of all the points for which a specified function has a constantvalue. Newcomb.

Not cautious; not circumspect; not attending to thecircumstances on which safety and interest depend; heedless;careless; as, an incautious step; an incautious remark.

Pertaining to the iliac and lumbar regions; as, the iliolumbarartery.

The point or part by which a muscle or tendon is attached tothe part to be moved; -- in contradistinction to its origin.Epigynous insertion (Bot.), the insertion of stamens upon the ovary.-- Hypogynous insertion (Bot.), insertion beneath the ovary.

Not resilient; not recoiling or rebounding; inelastic.
