A natural susceptibility, characteristic of all livingorganisms, tissues, and cells, to the influence of certain stimuli,response being manifested in a variety of ways, -- as that quality inplants by which they exhibit motion under suitable stimulation; esp.,the property which living muscle processes, of responding either to adirect stimulus of its substance, or to the stimulating influence ofits nerve fibers, the response being indicated by a change of form,or contraction; contractility.
A silicate of iron and lime occurring in black prismaticcrystals and columnar masses.
To pass; to enter. [Obs.]Light is discerned by itself because by itself it incurs into theeye. South.
Inseparably. [Obs.] Cranmer.
To render illegitimate; to bastardize.
The step, or socket, in which the lower end of a millstonespindle runs.
In an inexpiable manner of degree; to a degree that admits ofno atonement.

Not determinate; not certain or fixed; indefinite; not precise;as, an indeterminate number of years. Paley. Indeterminate analysis(Math.), that branch of analysis which has for its object thesolution of indeterminate problems.-- Indeterminate coefficients (Math.), coefficients arbitrarilyassumed for convenience of calculation, or to facilitate someartifice of analysis. Their values are subsequently determined.-- Indeterminate equation (Math.), an equation in which the unknownquantities admit of an infinite number of values, or sets of values.A group of equations is indeterminate when it contains more unknownquantities than there are equations.-- Indeterminate inflorescence (Bot.), a mode of inflorescence inwhich the flowers all arise from axillary buds, the terminal budgoing on to grow and sometimes continuing the stem indefinitely; --called also acropetal, botryose, centripetal, and indefiniteinflorescence. Gray.-- Indeterminate problem (Math.), a problem which admits of aninfinite number of solutions, or one in which there are fewer imposedconditions than there are unknown or required results.-- Indeterminate quantity (Math.), a quantity which has no fixedvalue, but which may be varied in accordance with any proposedcondition.-- Indeterminate series (Math.), a series whose terms proceed by thepowers of an indeterminate quantity, sometimes also withindeterminate exponents, or indeterminate coefficients.-- In`de*ter"mi*nate*ly adv.-- In`de*ter"mi*nate*ness, n.

A rare metallic element, of the same group as platinum, whichit much resembles, being silver-white, but harder, and brittle, andindifferent to most corrosive agents. With the exception of osmium,it is the heaviest substance known, its specific gravity being 22.4.Symbol Ir. Atomic weight 192.5.
To treat in an ideal manner. See Idealization, 2.
The state or quality of being indubitable.
To be, to come, or to pass, between; to separate. [Obs.] Sir I.Newton.
Unamiable. [Obs.] -- In*a"mi*a*ble*ness, n. [Obs.]
In a illustrious manner; conspicuously; eminently; famously.Milton.
Between, or within, the eyes; as, the interocular distance;situated between the eyes, as the antennæ of some insects.
To steep or soak; to drench. [R.] "In gore he lay insteeped."Shak.
A hint; an intimation.The least inkling or glimpse of this island. Bacon.They had some inkling of secret messages. Clarendon.
Designating, or pertaining to, an acid isomeric with cyanuricacid, and called also fulminuric acid. See under Fulminuric.
Between the neural arches or neural spines.-- n.
That implores; beseeching; entreating.-- Im*plor"ing*ly, adv.
Having the same properties in all directions; specifically,equally elastic in all directions.
The state or quality of being immeasurable.Eternity and immeasurableness belong to thought alone. F. W.Robertson.
Not vitiated. Lowell.
That has no finite period of revolution; not revolving. [R.]The dateless and irrevocable circle of eternity. Milton.
Want of effect, or of power to produce it; inefficacy.The ineffectualness of some men's devotion. Wake.

Not extended.
To shade; to darken. [Obs.]
One who indites. Smart.

Want of dexterity or readiness, especially in the use of thehands; clumsiness; awkwardness. Harvey.
The state or quality of being unreconciled; disagreement.

Not commiscible; not mixable.

Not destructible; incapable of decomposition or of beingdestroyed.-- In`de*struc"ti*ble*ness, n.-- In`de*struc"ti*bly, adv.
The formation of a figure, representation, or semblance; adelineation or description.Some kind of apish imitations, counterfeit iconisms. Cudworth.
Incapable of being exhaled. [Obs.] Sir T. Browne.

Not decimable, or liable to be decimated; not liable to thepayment of tithes. Cowell.
Without luster. [Obs. & R.]
Wanting health; valetudinary. [R.]
Unfadingly. [Obs.] Bp. Hall.
Driven together or close. Impacted fracture (Surg.), a fracturein which the fragments are driven into each other so as to beimmovable.
Not according to, or authorized by, law; specif., contrary to,or in violation of, human law; unlawful; illicit; hence, immoral; as,an illegal act; illegal trade; illegal love. Bp. Burnet.
Doubtful; not of definite form. Opus incertum (Anc. Arch.), akind of masonry employed in building walls, in which the stones werenot squared nor laid in courses; rubblework.

Not constant; not stable or uniform; subject to change ofcharacter, appearance, opinion, inclination, or purpose, etc.; notfirm; unsteady; fickle; changeable; variable; -- said of persons orthings; as, inconstant in love or friendship. "The inconstant moon."Shak.While we, inquiring phantoms of a day, Inconstant as the shadows wesurvey! Boyse.
Capacity for induction; the coefficient of self-induction.
That which illuminates or affords light; as, gas and petroleumare illuminants. Boyle.
Not turning the mind to a matter; heedless; careless;negligent; inattentive.An inadvertent step may crush the snail That crawls at evening in thepublic path. Cowper.-- In`ad*vert"ent*ly, adv.
An engraving, carving, or inscription. [Obs.]On his gravestone this insculpture. Shak.
One who holds the doctrine of intuitionalism.
Like or pertaining to the genus Iguanodon.
The quality of being immoderate; excess; extravagance. Puller.
Established; organized; founded. [Obs.]They have but few laws. For to a people so instruct and institute,very few to suffice. Robynson (More's Utopia).
Between follicles; as, the interfollicular septa in a lymphaticgland.

One of a school of physicians in Italy, about the middle of the17th century, who tried to apply the laws of mechanics andmathematics to the human body, and hence were eager student ofanatomy; -- opposed to the iatrochemists.
Consisting of, or resembling, ink; soiled with ink; black."Inky blots." Shak. "Its inky blackness." Boyle.

To emit rays; to shine.

In an irritable manner.

Not regular; not conforming to a law, method, or usagerecognized as the general rule; not according to common form; notconformable to nature, to the rules of moral rectitude, or toestablished principles; not normal; unnatural; immethodical;unsymmetrical; erratic; no straight; not uniform; as, an irregularline; an irregular figure; an irregular verse; an irregularphysician; an irregular proceeding; irregular motion; irregularconduct, etc. Cf. Regular.Mazes intricate, Eccentric, intervolved, yet regular Then most whenmost irregular they seem. Milton.Leading the men of Herefordshire to fight Against the irregular andwild Glendower. Shak.A flowery meadow through which a clear stream murmured in manyirregular meanders. Jones.
Within a cell; as, the intracellular movements seen in thepigment cells, the salivary cells, and in the protoplasm of somevegetable cells.
Lack of sanitation; careless or dangerous hygienic conditions.
The introduction of a tube into an organ to keep it open, asinto the larynx in croup.

Lack of power; inability. Bacon.Their own impuissance and weakness. Holland.

Not moral; inconsistent with rectitude, purity, or good morals;contrary to conscience or the divine law; wicked; unjust; dishonest;vicious; licentious; as, an immoral man; an immoral deed.

Of or pertaining to inflection; having, or characterized by,inflection. Max Müller.
A foot consisting of a short syllable followed by a long one,as in âmans, or of an unaccented syllable followed by an accentedone, as invent; an iambic. See the Couplet under Iambic, n.
Not prosperous. [Obs.] Dryden.-- Im*pros"per*ous*ly, adv. [Obs.] -- Im*pros"per*ous*ness, n.[Obs.]
The quality of being unalterable or unchangeable; permanence.

Not reproachable; above reproach; not deserving reproach;blameless.He [Berkely] erred, -- and who is free from error -- but hisintentions were irreproachable. Beattie.
The act of swallowing greedily or immoderately; that which isso swallowed. E. Darwin.He drowned his stomach and senses with a large draught andingurgitation of wine. Bacon.

To drop in; to pour in drop by drop; hence, to impartgradually; to infuse slowly; to cause to be imbibed.That starlight dews All silently their tears of love instill. Byron.How hast thou instilled Thy malice into thousands. Milton.
A genus of parasitic Acarina, which includes various species ofticks. See Tick, the insect.

Producing intoxication; as, intoxicating liquors.

The state of existing, of being inherent, in something;inherence. A. Baxter.Constant inhesion and habitual abode. South.

To question formally; to question; to examine by askingquestions; as, to interrogate a witness.Wilt thou, uncalled, interrogate, Talker! the unreplying FateEmerson.

Lying between cells or cellules; as, intercellular substance,space, or fluids; intercellular blood channels.

Any carnivorous mammal of the genus Herpestes, and familyViverridæ. Numerous species are found in Asia and Africa. TheEgyptian species(H. ichneumon), which ranges to Spain and Palestine,is noted for destroying the eggs and young of the crocodile as wellas various snakes and lizards, and hence was considered sacred by theancient Egyptians. The common species of India (H. griseus), known asthe mongoose, has similar habits and is often domesticated. It isnoted for killing the cobra.
Same as Idioplasma.
One who imputes.
The state of being incurable; incurability. Boyle.
Without end or limit.

To render more intense; as, to intensify heat or cold; tointensify colors; to intensify a photographic negative; to intensifyanimosity. Bacon.How piercing is the sting of pride By want embittered andintensified. Longfellow.
A writing, as the means of giving formal expression to someact; a writing expressive of some act, contract, process, as a deed,contract, writ, etc. Burrill.

In an irregular manner.
A student, or lover of the study, of iconography.
. See Caoutchouc.
To wander without a settled habitation; to travel from place oron a circuit, particularly for the purpose of preaching, lecturing,etc.
Of or pertaining to the iris or rainbow; prismatic; as, theiridal colors. Whewell.

Not sentient; not having perception, or the power ofperception.The . . . attributes of an insentient, inert substance. Reid.But there can be nothing like to this sensation in the rose, becauseit is insentient. Sir W. Hamilton.
Occurring between or among, or common to, differentdenominations; as, interdenominational fellowship or belief.

Also; as an additional article.
Mutual. [Obs.] Daniel.-- In`ter*mu"tu*al*ly, adv. [Obs.]

Not tangible; incapable of being touched; not perceptible tothe touch; impalpable; imperceptible. Bp. Wilkins.A corporation is an artificial, invisible, intangible being.Marshall.-- In*tan"gi*ble*ness, n.-- In*tan"gi*bly, adv.

A line connecting or marking points on the earth's surfacehaving the same temperature. This may be the temperature for a giventime of observation, or the mean temperature for a year or otherperiod. Also, a similar line based on the distribution of temperaturein the ocean.

To prevent from being reconciled; to alienate or disaffect.[Obs.]
In an intrepid manner; courageously; resolutely.
Same as Isochronal.
In a ignorant manner; without knowledge; inadvertently.Whom therefoer ye ignorantly worship, him declare I unto you. Actsxvii. 23.
A cavity, or excavation, made in the snow by a seal, over itsbreathing hole in the ice.
To make great; to enlarge; to magnify. [Obs.] Fotherby.
Unforeseen; unexpected; not provided against; unprepared.[Obs.]All improvided for dread of death. E. Hall.
To make tender or sensitive; to soften.

Pertaining to the Ionic order of architecture, one of the threeorders invented by the Greeks, and one of the five recognized by theItalian writers of the sixteenth century. Its distinguishing featureis a capital with spiral volutes. See Illust. of Capital. Ionicdialect (Gr. Gram.), a dialect of the Greek language, used in Ionia.The Homeric poems are written in what is designated old Ionic, asdistinguished from new Ionic, or Attic, the dialect of all cultivatedGreeks in the period of Athenian prosperity and glory.-- Ionic foot. (Pros.) See Ionic, n., 1.-- Ionic, or Ionian, mode (Mus.), an ancient mode, supposed tocorrespond with the modern major scale of C.-- Ionic sect, a sect of philosophers founded by Thales of Miletus,in Ionia. Their distinguishing tenet was, that water is the originalprinciple of all things.-- Ionic type, a kind of heavy-faced type (as that of the followingline).
One who injures or wrongs.
Not metrical or rhythmical. [R.] Chapman.
The quality or state of being inhospitable; inhospitableness;lack of hospitality. Bp. Hall.
Want of acquaintance. Good.
A poisoning, as by a spirituous or a narcotic substance.
In an indivisible manner.
A setting of something to the account of; the attribution ofpersonal guilt or personal righteousness of another; as, theimputation of the sin of Adam, or the righteousness of Christ.
The act of identifying, or proving to be the same; also, thestate of being identified.
One who impropriates; specifically, a layman in possession ofchurch property.

Dependent upon, or appertaining to, another thing, called theprincipal. Incident proposition (Logic), a proposition subordinate toanother, and introduced by who, which, whose, whom, etc.; as, Julius,whose surname was Cæsar, overcame Pompey. I. Watts.
Not elastic.
Lying, coming, or done, between; intermediate; as, anintermediary project. Intermediary amputation (Surg.), an amputationfor injury, performed after inflammation has set in.
Infirmity; feebleness. Boyle.

A sudden compression of the air in the mouth, simultaneouslywith and affecting the sound made by the closure of the organs inuttering p, t, or k, at the end of a syllable (see Guide toPronunciation, §§159, 189); also, a similar compression made by anupward thrust of the larynx without any accompanying explosiveaction, as in the peculiar sound of b, d, and g, heard in SouthernGermany. H. Sweet.

Supplying or covering with ink. Inking roller, a somewhatelastic roller,used to spread ink over forms of type, copperplates,etc.-- Inking trough or table, a trough or table from which the inkingroller receives its ink.
Of or pertaining to a segment sometimes present at the proximalend of the hyoidean arch.-- n.
The act or practice of itinerating; itinerancy.
Unknown. [Obs.] Sir E. Sandys.-- n.
A substance from the egg yolk of osseous fishes.
A female inhabitant. [R.]
To bind out by indenture or contract; to indenture; toapprentice; as, to indent a young man to a shoemaker; to indent aservant.
To lay on, as the hands, in the religious rites of confirmationand ordination.
Of the nature of impetration; getting, or tending to get, byentreaty. [Obs.] Bp. Hall.
Between valves.
An image or representation; a portrait or pretended portrait.Netherlands whose names and icons are published. Hakewill.

A genus of gigantic herbivorous dinosaurs having a birdlikepelvis and large hind legs with three-toed feet capable of supportingthe entire body. Its teeth resemble those of the iguana, whence itsname. Several species are known, mostly from the Wealden of Englandand Europe. See Illustration in Appendix.
The state or quality of being inky; blackness.

Infinitely or indefinitely small; less than any assignablequantity or value; very small. Infinitesimal calculus, the differentand the integral calculus, when developed according to the methodused by Leibnitz, who regarded the increments given to variables asinfinitesimal.
The state of being uncivilized; want of civilization;barbarism.
An intermediate agent.

A peculiarity of physical or mental constitution ortemperament; a characteristic belonging to, and distinguishing, anindividual; characteristic susceptibility; idiocrasy; eccentricity.The individual mind . . . takes its tone from the idiosyncrasies ofthe body. I. Taylor.
The state or quality of being imperceptible.
Situated within the margin. Loudon.
One who effects insurance; an insurer; an underwriter. [Obs.]Dryden.hose bold insurancers of deathless fame. Blair.
In an indicative manner; in a way to show or signify.
Lying between; intervening; intermediate. "Intermedial colors."Evelyn.
An overlapping of the edges, like that of tiles or shingles;hence, intricacy of structure; also, a pattern or decorationrepresenting such a structure.
To twine or twist into, or together; to wreathe; as, a wreathof flowers intwined. [Written also entwine.]
One who insults. Shak.
Situated between vowels; immediately preceded and followed byvowel sounds, as, p in occupy, d in idea, etc.
Without activity; sluggishly. Pope.
One who, or that which, introduces.
Not congenial; uncongenial. [R.] -- In`con*ge`ni*al"i*ty. [R.]
Having a mutual or reciprocal relation or parallelism;correlative.
Pertaining to, or caused by, a blow; sudden; abrupt. [R.] H.Bushnell.
The act of chilling or causing to become cold; a chilling;coldness; congelation. [Obs.] Boyle.
Not circumspect; heedless; careless; reckless; impolitic.Tyndale.
Dealing by enchantment; magical. Sir T. Browne.
In an inelegant manner.
Failure to mortify the passions. [R.] Jer. Taylor.
Any one of the derivatives of indogen, which contain that groupas a nucleus.
The quality or state of being inseparable; inseparableness.Locke.
Of or pertaining to Iceland; relating to, or resembling, theIcelanders.
To set a soul in; reflexively, to fix one's strongestaffections on. [Obs.] Jer. Taylor.[He] could not but insoul himself in her. Feltham.
In an incorporeal manner. Bacon.
Inconceivable. [Obs.] Sir M. Hale.
To twist into or together; to interweave. [Written alsoentwist.]
Between columns or pillars; as, the intercolumnar fibers ofPoupart's ligament; an intercolumnar statue.
That which integrates; esp., an instrument by means of whichthe area of a figure can be measured directly, or its moment ofinertia, or statical moment, etc., be determined.
An inveighing against; invective. [Obs.] Fulke.
In an injurious or hurtful manner; wrongfully; hurtfully;mischievously.
An involucel.
A French fop or dandy of the time of the Directory; hence, anyfop.
Pertaining to, or derived from, inosite; as, inosinic acid.

The act of investigating; the process of inquiring into orfollowing up; research; study; inquiry, esp. patient or thoroughinquiry or examination; as, the investigations of the philosopher andthe mathematician; the investigations of the judge, the moralist.
Ignorant of letters or books; unlettered; uninstructed;uneducated; as, an illiterate man, or people.
To place in a pasture; to foster. [R.] T. Adams.
In an immoderate manner; excessively.
Obtained by entreaty. [Obs.] Ld. Herbert.
To put under a ban. [R.] Barlow.
A crystallized substance of the composition C4I4NH, technicallytetra-iodo-pyrrol, used like iodoform.
Not determinable; impossible to be determined; not to bedefinitely known, ascertained, defined, or limited.-- In`de*ter"mi*na*bly, adv.

One of an Oriental religious sect which worships Satan or theDevil.The Izedis or Yezdis, the so-called Devil worshipers, still remain anumerous though oppressed people in Mesopotamia and adjacentcountries. Tylor.
See Inhearse.
To place under or beneath. [R.]
Growing or appearing to grow into some other substance.Ingrowing nail, one whose edges are becoming imbedded in the adjacentflesh.
In an imperial manner.
Unconformable. [Obs.]
One who favors, or takes part in, insurrection; an insurgent.
The peculiar dress worn by pilgrims to Mecca.
Incognizable.-- In`cog*nos"ci*bil"i*ty, n.
To infuse new life or spirit into; to animate; to encourage; toinvigorate.The courage of Agamemnon is inspirited by the love of empire andambition. Pope.
Interception; a stopping

Happening, as an occasional event, without regularity; comingwithout design; casual; accidental; hence, not of prime concern;subordinate; collateral; as, an incidental conversation; anincidental occurrence; incidental expenses.By some, religious duties . . . appear to be regarded . . . as anincidental business. Rogers.
To libel mutually.
Of a tint resembling that produced by jaundice; yellow; as, anicteroid tint or complexion.
Crowned. [R.] Longfellow.
Unapt; not apt; unsuitable; inept.-- In*apt"ly, adv.-- In*apt"ness, n.
Incapable of being perforated, or bored through.

To resemble (another species of animal, or a plant, orinanimate object) in form, color, ornamentation, or instinctivehabits, so as to derive an advantage thereby; sa, when a harmlesssnake imitates a venomous one in color and manner, or when anodorless insect imitates, in color, one having secretion offensive tobirds.
Impolitic. [Obs.] -- Im`po*lit"i*cal*ly, adv. [Obs.] Bacon.
To sit, as on eggs for hatching; to brood; to brood upon, orkeep warm, as eggs, for the purpose of hatching.
The act of coming between; intervention; interposition. Burke.
The quality of insisting, or being urgent or pressing; the actof dwelling upon as of special importance; persistence; urgency.
The quality or state of being incalculable.
Interlinear.-- n.
Characterized by iniquity; unjust; wicked; as, an iniquitousbargain; an iniquitous proceeding.Demagogues . . . bribed to this iniquitous service. Burke.
To engrave. [R.] "Whose gleaming rind ingrav'n." Tennyson.
To give vigor to; to strengthen; to animate; to give life andenergy to.Christian graces and virtues they can not be, unless fed,invigorated, and animated by universal charity. Atterbury.
One who accepts or maintains the dogma of papal infallibility.

To render illegitimate; to declare or prove to be born out ofwedlock; to bastardize; to illegitimatize.The marriage should only be dissolved for the future, withoutillegitimating the issue. Bp. Burnet.

Of, pertaining to, or designating, one of the principallinguistic stocks of the North American Indians. The territory of thenorthern Iroquoian tribes, of whom the Five Nations, or Iroquoisproper, were the chief, extended from the shores of the St. Lawrenceand of Lakes Huron, Ontario, and Erie south, through easternPennsylvania, to Maryland; that of the southern tribes, of whom theCherokees were chief, formed part of Virginia, the Carolinas,Georgia, Tennessee, and Kentucky. All of the tribes wereagricultural, and they were noted for large, communal houses,palisaded towns, and ability to organize, as well as for skill inwar. --n.
The laying on of colors to produce impasto.
Capable of being identified.
Pertaining to the ileum and cæcum.
Repulsive by itself; as, the idiorepulsive power of heat.
The quality or state of being inflammable; inflammability.Boyle.
See Encircle.
To furnish or inclose with a border; to form a border of.Milton.

Not limited to rules prescribed, or to usual bounds; irregular;excessive; immoderate; as, an inordinate love of the world."Inordinate desires." Milton. "Inordinate vanity." Burke.-- In*or"di*nate*ly, adv.-- In*or"di*nate*ness, n.
A person who discharges the royal functions during aninterregnum. Holland.
By inheritance. Sherwood.
The quality of being indecorous; want of decorum.
By way of introduction.
Incapable of being tasted; tasteless; unsavory. [R.] Grew.
Given to inquiry; disposed to investigate causes; curious; as,an inquiring mind.
Having or indicating, equal tones, or tension. Isotonic system(Mus.), a system consisting of intervals, in which each concord isalike tempered, and in which there are twelve equal semitones.
Infected. Cf. Enfect. [Obs.] Shak.
Having the ironwork loose or corroded; -- said of a ship whenher bolts and nails are so eaten with rust that she has become leaky.
Pertaining to, or characterized by, impressionism.

To unite, as by lacing together; to insert or interpose onething within another; to intertwine; to interweave.Severed into stripes That interlaced each other. Cowper.The epic way is every where interlaced with dialogue. Dryden.Interlacing arches (Arch.), arches, usually circular, so constructedthat their archivolts intersect and seem to be interlaced.
By means of, or in the manner of, intrigue.
Incapable of being refuted or disproved; indisputable.-- Ir`re*fut"a*ble*ness, n.-- Ir`re*fut"a*bly, adv.
Pertaining to the inion.

Want of due consideration; inattention to consequences;inconsiderateness.Blindness of mind, inconsideration, precipitation. Jer. Taylor.Not gross, willful, deliberate, crimes; but rather the effects ofinconsideration. Sharp.
Act of inthralling, or state of being inthralled; servitude;bondage; vassalage.
A line upon a thermodynamic diagram so drawn as to representthe pressures corresponding to changes of temperature when the volumeof the gas operated on is constant. -- I`so*chor"ic (#), a.
An individual cell, differing greatly from its neighbours inregard to size, structure, or contents.
Having equal entropy. Isentropic lines, lines which passthrough points having equal entropy.
Within the veins.
By induction or inference.
Want of plausibility; the quality of being implausible.

To become more nearly full; to show more of the surface; towax; as, the moon increases. Increasing function (Math.), a functionwhose value increases when that of the variable increases, anddecreases when the latter is diminished.
Inwrought; woven in.
Of equal force or size.
Capable of being imparted or communicated.

One of a religious sect which arose in Alexandria, in the reignof the Emperor Justinian, and which believed that the body of Christwas incorruptible, and that he suffered hunger, thirst, pain, only inappearance.
Between the transverse processes of the vertebræ.

Rendering null and void; conditionally invalidating.The states elected Harry, Duke of Anjou, for their king, with thisclause irritant; that, if he did violate any part of his oath, thepeople should owe him no allegiance. Hayward.
Not having money; habitually without money; poor.An impecunious creature. B. Jonson.
Dent; impression. [Obs.] Shak.
Somewhat ill. [Obs.] Howell.
Native. [Obs.] Chapman.
A plane for shaving or dressing the concave or inside faces ofbarrel staves.
Want of civism; want of patriotism or love to one's country;unfriendliness to one's state or government. [R.] Macaulay.
Want of worth; demerit. [R.] Suckling.
Discontent. [Obs.] Goodwin.
In an instinctive manner; by force of instinct; by naturalimpulse.
To apostemate; to form an imposthume or abscess. Arbuthnot.
Irrecoverable.-- Ir`re*cu"per*a*bly, adv.
Incapable of being deposed. [R.]Princes indeposable by the pope. Bp. Stillingfleet.
The Celtic people of Ireland. "The whole Irishry of rebels."Milton.
The action of a force during a very small interval of time; theeffect of such action; as, the impulse of a sudden blow upon a hardelastic body.
To insert a leaf or leaves in; to bind with blank leavesinserted between the others; as, to interleave a book.
Residence within, as in the heart.The personal indwelling of the Spirit in believers. South.
To make or declare illegal or unlawful.
A speech interposed between others. [R.] Blount.
To place the profits of (ecclesiastical property) in the handsof a layman for care and disbursement.
One who is irreligious.
A line of division or intersection; as, the tendinousinscriptions, or intersections, of a muscle.
The act of introverting, or the state of being introverted; theact of turning the mind inward. Berkeley.
One who infringes or violates; a violator. Strype.
An unregenerate state. [Obs.]
A person who dies without making a valid will. Blackstone.

The common designation of one a sect founded by the Rev. EdwardIrving (about 1830), who call themselves the Catholic ApostolicChurch. They are highly ritualistic in worship, have an elaboratehierarchy of apostles, prophets, etc., and look for the speedy comingof Christ.
An interregnum. [Obs.] Bacon.
A favorite sweet American grape of a purple color. See Foxgrape, under Fox.

To make timid or fearful; to inspire of affect with fear; todeter, as by threats; to dishearten; to abash.Now guilt, once harbored in the conscious breast, Intimidates thebrave, degrades the great. Johnson.
An extensive order of fishes, including the salmons, herrings,and many allied forms.
The state of being insatiate.

Not congruous; reciprocally disagreeing; not capable ofharmonizing or readily assimilating; inharmonious; inappropriate;unsuitable; not fitting; inconsistent; improper; as, an incongruousremark; incongruous behavior, action, dress, etc. "Incongruousmixtures of opinions." I. Taylor. "Made up of incongruous parts."Macaulay.Incongruous denotes that kind of absence of harmony or suitablenessof which the taste and experience of men takes cognizance. C. J.Smith.Incongruous numbers (Arith.), two numbers, which, with respect to athird, are such that their difference can not be divided by itwithout a remainder, the two numbers being said to be incongruouswith respect to the third; as, twenty-five are incongruous withrespect to four.
The state or quality of being intricate; intricacy.
The increase of a variable quantity or fraction from itspresent value to its next ascending value; the finite quantity,generally variable, by which a variable quantity is increased.
Full of entreaty. [Obs.] Spenser.
Want of diligence. [Obs.] B. Jonson.
Not satiable; incapable of being satisfied or appeased; verygreedy; as, an insatiable appetite, thirst, or desire."Insatiable of glory." Milton.
Not mixable. Bp. Wilkins.
Entangling. [Obs.] Shelton.
Mischievous; harmful; dangerous. [Obs.] "Infestuous asserpents." Bacon.
The act of imploring; earnest supplication. Bp. Hall.
To catch or entangle in, or as in, the meshes of a net. or in aweb; to insnare.
Not persuasible; not to be moved by persuasion; inflexible;impersuadable. Dr. H. More.-- Im`per*sua`si*bil"i*ty, n.
See Intendant, n. [Obs.]
Between septa; as, the interseptal spaces or zones, between thetransparent, or septal, zones in striated muscle; the interseptalchambers of a shell, or of a seed vessel.
Incapable of being supposed; not supposable; inconceivable.
Of or pertaining to the ischium and the capsule of the hipjoint; as, the ischiocapsular ligament.

Prone to indulge; yielding to the wishes, humor, or appetitesof those under one's care; compliant; not opposing or restraining;tolerant; mild; favorable; not severe; as, an indulgent parent. Shak.The indulgent censure of posterity. Waller.The feeble old, indulgent of their ease. Dryden.
Having the power of infusion; inspiring; influencing.The infusive force of Spirit on man. Thomson.
See Embay.
Incapable of being taught, or not easily instructed; dull inintellect; intractable; unteachable; indocile. Bp. Hall.-- In*doc"i*ble*ness, n.
A transparent, extensible membrane of extreme tenuity, whichforms the innermost coating of grains of pollen.
Improvidence. [Obs.] Sir T. Browne.
The quality of being invariable; invariableness; constancy;uniformity.
Not given to variation or change; unalterable; unchangeable;always uniform.Physical laws which are invariable. I. Taylor.-- In*va"ri*a*ble*ness, n.-- In*va"ri*a*bly, adv.
To grave or carve between; to engrave in the alternatesections.The work itself of the bases, was intergraven. 3 Kings vii. 28 (Douayversion. )
The quality of having similar sexual zooids or gonophores anddissimilar hydrants; -- said of certain hydroids.
To place between or among; as, to interplace a name. [R.]Daniel.
The point or line in which one line or surface cuts another.
Flesh-colored; of a carnation or pale red color. [Obs.]Lovelace.
The act of admitting into or within. Hammond.
Not commutable; not capable of being exchanged with, orsubstituted for, another. Cudworth.-- In`com*mut"a*ble*ness, n.-- In`com*mut"a*bly, adv.
The system or theory that denies the existence of materialbodies, and teaches that we have no rational grounds to believe inthe reality of anything but ideas and their relations.
Not liable to sin; exempt from the possibility of doing wrong.-- n.
Any of several isomeric iodine derivatives of the cresols,C6H3I(CH3)OH, esp. one, an odorless amorphous powder, used inmedicine as a substitute for iodoform.
To challenge or discredit the credibility of, as of a witness,or the validity of, as of commercial paper.
Not remunerable; not capable of remuneration.
The act or process of uniting lands, rights, or revenues, tothe ecclesiastical chamber, i. e., to the pope's domain.
A division of copepod crustaceans, including numerous speciesparasitic on fishes.
The quality of being impolitic; inexpedience; unsuitableness tothe end proposed; bads policy; as, the impolicy of fraud. Bp.Horsley.
Without regard to conditions; not making circumstances intoconsideration.Prosperity, considered absolutely and irrespectively, is better andmore desirable than adversity. South.
Indomitable. [Obs.] Tooke.
Winding, creeping, or flowing in, quietly or stealthily;suggesting; winning favor and confidence insensibly. Milton.His address was courteous, and even insinuating. Prescott.
The quality or state of being infrangible; infrangibleness.

Pertaining to the reception or the giving out of equalquantities of heat by a substance. Rankine. Isodiabatic lines orcurves, a pair of lines or curves exhibiting, on a diagram of energy,the law of variation of the pressure and density of a fluid, the oneduring the lowering, and the other during the raising, of itstemperature, when the quantity of heat given out by the fluid duringany given stage of the one process is equal to the quantity receivedduring the corresponding stage of the other. Such lines are said tobe isodiabatic with respect to each other. Compare Adiabatic.

Incapable of being estimated or computed; especially, toovaluable or excellent to be measured or fully appreciated; above allprice; as, inestimable rights or privileges.But above all, for thine inestimable love. Bk. of Com. Prayer.Science is too inestimable for expression by a money standard. LyonPlayfair.

The dramatic practice or purpose characteristic of the writingsof Henrik Ibsen (1828-1906), Norwegian poet and dramatist, whosebest-known plays deal with conventional hypocrisies, the story ineach play thus developing a definite moral problem.
Pressure acting within. [R.]
Having colors like the rainbow; exhibiting a play of changeablecolors; nacreous; prismatic; as, iridescent glass.

The condition or quality of being an idiot; absence, or markeddeficiency, of sense and intelligence.I will undertake to convict a man of idiocy, if he can not see theproof that three angles of a triangle are equal to two right angles.F. W. Robertson.
An ethereal fluid that supplied the place of blood in the veinsof the gods.
The quality of being incompressible, or incapable of reductionin volume by pressure; -- formerly supposed to be a property ofliquids.The incompressibility of water is not absolute. Rees.
To defame; to make infamous. [Obs.] Milton.Livia is infamed for the poisoning of her husband. Bacon.
One who holds the doctrine that immersion is essential toChristian baptism.
In an inconstant manner.

To adjudge as one's own (the sin or righteousness) of another;as, the righteousness of Christ is imputed to us.It was imputed to him for righteousness. Rom. iv. 22.They merit Imputed shall absolve them who renounce Their own, bothrighteous and unrighteous deeds. Milton.
The projector, manager, or conductor, of an opera or concertcompany.
Not accessible; not to be reached, obtained, or approached; as,an inaccessible rock, fortress, document, prince, etc.-- In`ac*cess"i*ble*ness, n.-- In`ac*cess"i*bly, adv.
Exemption or freedom from punishment, harm, or loss.Heaven, though slow to wrath, Is neimpunity defied. Cowper.The impunity and also the recompense. Holland.
Incapable of being assisted; helpless. [R.] Shak.
A person who is not of full age, or who has not attained theage of legal capacity; a person under the age of twenty-one years; aminor.
A complete entity; a whole number, in contradistinction to afraction or a mixed number. Complex integer (Theory of Numbers), anexpression of the form a + bsq. root-1, where a and b are realintegers.
Confinement within narrow limits, -- as of foreign troops, tothe interior of a country.
To consume or reduce to ashes by burning, as a dead body; tocremate.

So; to such a degree; in such wise; -- followed by that or as,and formerly sometimes by both. Cf. Inasmuch.Insomusch as that field is called . . . Aceldama. Acts i. 19.Simonides was an excellent poet, insomuch that he made his fortune byit. L'Estrange.
In an initial or incipient manner or degree; at the beginning.Barrow.

Having the same percentage composition; -- said of two or moredifferent substances which contain the same ingredients in the sameproportions by weight, often used with with. Specif.: (a) Polymeric;i. e., having the same elements united in the same proportion byweight, but with different molecular weights; as, acetylene andbenzine are isomeric (polymeric) with each other in this sense. SeePolymeric. (b) Metameric; i. e., having the same elements united inthe same proportions by weight, and with the same molecular weight,but which a different structure or arrangement of the ultimate parts;as, ethyl alcohol and methyl ether are isomeric (metameric) with eachother in this sense. See Metameric.
Same as Idiophanous.

Any one of a series of artificial blue dyestuffs, resemblingindigo in appearance, and obtained by the action of phenol on certainnitrogenous derivatives of quinone. Simple indophenol proper has notyet been isolated.
To enlighten. [Obs.]
Having the quality of not being impressed or affected; notsusceptible.
The same; the same as above; -- often abbreviated id.

To make thick or thicker; to thicken; especially, in pharmacy,to thicken (a liquid) by the mixture of another substance, or byevaporating the thinner parts.Acids dissolve or attenuate; alkalies precipitate or incrassate. SirI. Newton.Liquors which time hath incrassated into jellies. Sir T. Browne.
Not perceiving, or not able to perceive. A. Baxter.
A genus of violaceous plants, chiefly found in tropicalAmerica, some species of which are used as substitutes foripecacuanha.
See Emmantle. [R.]
Not apprehensive; regardless; unconcerned. Jer. Taylor.
The quality of being imputable; imputableness.
Interlaced; linked together; -- said of charges or bearings.See Fretted.
A dark resinous substance, polymeric with indol, and obtainedby the reduction of indigo white.
That part of the alimentary canal between the stomach and theanus. See Illust. of Digestive apparatus.
Not opulent; not affluent or rich.
See Encumber.
Immoderateness; excess. [R.] Sir T. Browne.
Between lobes; as, the interlobar notch of the liver; theinterlobar ducts of a gland.
Harmless; producing no ill effect; innocent.A patient, innocuous, innocent man. Burton.-- In*noc"u*ous*ly, adv.-- In*noc"u*ous*ness, n.Where the salt sea innocuously breaks. Wordsworth.
Insufficiency. Shak.
To link together; to join, as one chain to another. Dryden.
To swallow up or overwhelm in, or as in, a gulf; to cast into agulf. See Engulf.A river large . . . Passed underneath ingulfed. Milton.
Capable of being illuminated.
In a manner not to be felt or perceived; imperceptibly;gradually.The hills rise insensibly. Addison.
Alluring; attractive; enticing. [Obs.] Sir T. Elyot.
A cutaneous, pustular eruption, not attended with fever;usually, a kind of eczema with pustulation.
To make international; to cause to affect the mutual relationsof two or more nations; as, to internationalize a principle of law,or a philanthropic enterprise.
Of or pertaining to, or conforming to, the mode of expressionpeculiar to a language; as, an idiomatic meaning; an idiomaticphrase.-- Id`i*o*mat"ic*al*ly, adv.
Want of circumspection. Sir T. Browne.
Of or pertaining to ancient Idumea, or Edom, in Western Asia.-- n.
To wrap up; to infold; to swathe.Inswathed sometimes in wandering mist. Tennyson.
Idiocy. [R.] Bp. Warburton.
A European composite herb (Centaurea nigra); -- so called fromthe resemblance of its knobbed head to an iron ball fixed on a longhandle. Dr. Prior.
Incubation. [Obs.] J. Ellis.
State or quality of being implicit.
Indistinct. [R.] "That indistinguished mass." Sir T. Browne.
Not capable of being extirpated or rooted out; ineradicable.
In the form of a globe or sphere; -- applied to nebulous mattercollected into a sphere by the force of gravitation.
To render unsound; to make mad. [Obs.] Feltham.
The state or quality of being impreventable. [R.]
A cuirassier or cuirassiers; also, hardy veteran soldiers; --applied specifically to Cromwell's cavalry.
Situated apparently in reverse order, as strata when foldedback upon themselves by upheaval. Inverted arch (Arch.), an archplaced with crown downward; -- much used in foundations.
Of or pertaining to the incisors; incisor; as, the incisivebones, the premaxillaries.

Not credible; surpassing belief; too extraordinary andimprobable to admit of belief; unlikely; marvelous; fabulous.Why should it be thought a thing incredible with you, that God shouldraise the dead Acts xxvi. 8.
Capable of being inscribed; inscribable.
To cover or invest with flesh. [R.] Wiseman.
Between antæ; -- said of a portico in classical style, wherecolumns are set between two antæ, forming the angles of the building.See Anta.
To palsy; to paralyze; to deaden. [R.]
Same as Intussusception.
Not melodious.
To arrange in a file or rank; to place in order. [Obs.]Holland.
Embracery. [Obs.]
The day on which the President of the United States isinaugurated, the 4th of March in every year next after a yeardivisible by four.

Permanently existing in something; inseparably attached orconnected; naturally pertaining to; innate; inalienable; as, polarityis an inherent quality of the magnet; the inherent right of men tolife, liberty, and protection. "A most inherent baseness." Shak.The sore disease which seems inherent in civilization. Southey.
Inappealable; final.
An early Latin version of the Scriptures (the Old Testament wastranslated from the Septuagint, and was also called the Italicversion).
Insular. [Obs.] Howell.
Want of comprehension or understanding. "These mazes andincomprehensions." Bacon.
Being near or moving towards the shore; as, inshore fisheries;inshore currents.-- adv.
One who intercedes; an intercessor; a mediator. Johnson.
In a mixed manner.
Incapable of being eluded or evaded; unvoidable.Most pressing reasons and ineludible demonstrations. Glanvill.
One who is interrogated.
Indissolubleness.
Unprofitable. [Obs.]
See Encysted.

To do harm to; to impair the excellence and value of; to hurt;to damage; -- used in a variety of senses; as: (a) To hurt or wound,as the person; to impair soundness, as of health. (b) To damage orlessen the value of, as goods or estate. (c) To slander, tarnish, orimpair, as reputation or character. (d) To impair or diminish, ashappiness or virtue. (e) To give pain to, as the sensibilities or thefeelings; to grieve; to annoy. (f) To impair, as the intellect ormind.When have I injured thee when done thee wrong Shak.
Capable of being infected.
Not a true or noble falcon; -- said of certain hawks, as thegoshawk.
Iambic. [Obs. or R.]
Full of, or conveying, information; instructive. [R.] LondonSpectator.
Not appeased or placated. [Obs.]To rest inexpiate were much too rude a part. Chapman.
To intensify. [R.] Emerson.
To utter with a musical or prolonged note or tone; to chant;as, to intone the church service.
Inflection.
That can not be rejected; irresistible. Boyle.
Causing new flesh to grow; healing; regenerative.-- n.

Not susceptible; not capable of being moved, affected, orimpressed; that can not feel, receive, or admit; as, a limbinsusceptible of pain; a heart insusceptible of pity; a mindinsusceptible to flattery.-- In`sus*cep`ti*bly adv.
Want or neglect of cultivation or culture. [Obs.] Feltham.
Not defective; perfect; complete. "Absolute, indefectiveobedience." South.
Belonging to an interdiction; prohibitory.
The space between two dentils. Gwilt.
In an infectious manner. Shak.
A disease in which the skin is thick, rough, and scaly; --called also fishskin.-- Ich`thy*ot"ic, a.

To take by descent from an ancestor; to take by inheritance; totake as heir on the death of an ancestor or other person to whoseestate one succeeds; to receive as a right or title descendible bylaw from an ancestor at his decease; as, the heir inherits the landor real estate of his father; the eldest son of a nobleman inheritshis father's title; the eldest son of a king inherits the crown.
To subject to the action of intense heat; to heat strongly; --often said of incombustible or infusible substances; as, to igniteiron or platinum.

The act of breathing on or into anything; especially:(a) (R. C. Ch.) The breathing upon a person in the sacrament ofbaptism to symbolize the inspiration of a new spiritual life.(b) (Med.) The act of blowing (a gas, powder, or vapor) into anycavity of the body.
Incapable of being appeased or satisfied; unappeasable.
Infinite; perpetual, as a canon whose end leads back to thebeginning. See Infinite, a., 5.
To chill; to make cold; to cool. [Obs.] Boyle.
Not delectable; unpleasant; disagreeable. [R.] Richardson.

The intellect or understanding; mental powers or faculties.Her husband, for I view far round, not nigh, Whose higherintellectual more I shun. Milton.I kept her intellectuals in a state of exercise. De Quincey.
See Indigo blue, under Indigo.
Capable of being included.
A suborder of marine gastropod mollusks, in which the gills arebetween the foot and the mantle.
Causing hindrance; impeding. "Cumbersome, and impeditive ofmotion." Bp. Hall.
The quality or state of being incontestable.
The state or quality of being irreverent; want of properreverence; disregard of the authority and character of a superior.
A partial, secondary, or small involucre. See Illust. ofInvolucre.
Imaginary.
Between the mandibles; interramal; as, the intermandibularspace.
In an insatiable manner or degree; unappeasably. "Insatiablycovetous." South.
Insatiable; as, insatiate thirst.The insatiate greediness of his desires. Shak.And still insatiate, thirsting still for blood. Hook.
The state or quality of being immaterial; immateriality.
Not fabricated; unwrought; not artificial; natural. [Obs.]
Not perisha ble; not subject to decay; indestructible;enduringpermanently; as, an imperishable monument; imperishablerenown.-- Im*per"ish*a*ble*ness, n.-- Im*per"ish*a*bly, adv.
The quality of being instinctive, or prompted by instinct. [R.]Coleridge.
Not polite; not of polished manners; wanting in good manners;discourteous; uncivil; rude.-- Im`po*lite"ly, adv.-- Im`po*lite"ness, n.
An order of sessile-eyed Crustacea, usually having seven pairsof legs, which are all similar in structure.
Of or pertaining to the Ichneumonidæ, or ichneumon flies.-- n.
Of or pertaining to iatromathematicians or their doctrine.
The third joint or the antennæ of the Crustacea.
Of the nature of, or pertaining to, impetigo.
Not capable of being exactly expressed by an integral number,or by a vulgar fraction; surd; -- said especially of roots. See Surd.
In the form of, or by means of, a question; in an interrogativemanner.
Of or pertaining to ideology.

A white crystalline substance with a sweet taste, found incertain animal tissues and fluids, particularly in the muscles of theheart and lungs, also in some plants, as in unripe pease, beans,potato sprouts, etc. Called also phaseomannite.
The quality or state of being irrational. "Brutishirrationaliity." South.
A collection of pus or purulent matter in any part of an animalbody; an abscess.
The anatomy or dissection of fishes. [R.]
Disturbed state; uneasiness either of body or mind;restlessness; disquietude. Sir H. Wotton.
Connection between; mutual connection.
In an insolent manner.
To infix. [Obs.] Chaucer.
Not susceptive or susceptible. [R.] Rambler.
Unequally lobed; cut into lobes of different shapes or sizes.
Inserted or introduced among others in the calendar; as, anintercalary month, day, etc.; -- now applied particularly to the oddday (Feb. 29) inserted in the calendar of leap year. See Bissextile,n.
In an intermediate manner; by way of intervention.
Not compassionate; void of pity or of tenderness; remorseless.-- In`com*pas"sion*ate*ly, adv.-- In`com*pas"sion*ate*ness, n.
Incapable of being resuscitated or revived.-- Ir`re*sus"ci*ta*bly, adv.
Below the gills; -- applied to the ventral portion of thepallial chamber in the lamellibranchs.
The doctrine or practice of the iconoclasts; image breaking.

A view of the inside or interior; a looking inward;specifically, the act or process of self-examination, or inspectionof one's own thoughts and feelings; the cognition which the mind hasof its own acts and states; self-consciousness; reflection.I was forced to make an introspection into my own mind. Dryden.
Incapable o
Incapable of beingThe bad seed thus sown was ineradicable. Ld. Lytton.
Of or pertaining to the Ichthyosauria.-- n.
An interlocutory judgment or sentence.
The act or process of intenerating, or the state of beingintenerated; softening. [R.] Bacon.
Not persevering; fickle; thoughtless. [Obs.]
Not capable of being mitigated, softened, or appeased.Coleridge.
Want of congruence; incongruity. Boyle.
Not decomposable; incapable or difficult of decomposition; notresolvable into its constituents or elements.
Denoting a question; expressed in the form of a question; as,an interrogative sentence; an interrogative pronoun.
Rushing in or upon.
In an immodest manner.

A common American moth (Pyrrharctia isabella), of an isabellacolor. The larva, called woolly bear and hedgehog caterpillar, isdensely covered with hairs, which are black at each end of the body,and red in the middle part.
Inconstancy. Chaucer.
A grand division of the Vertebrata, including the Amphibia andFishes.
To stake; to wager; to pledge. [Obs.]Against the which he has imponed, as I take it, six French rapiersand poniards. Shak.
To deposit and cover in the earth; to bury; to inhume; as, tointer a dead body. Shak.
Insatiableness. T. Grander.
Not deficient; full. [Obs.]Brighter than the sun, and indeficient as the light of heaven. Jer.Taylor.
. See under Ill, a.
The state or condition of one under age, or under the age oftwenty-one years; nonage; minority.
To clasp within; to hold fast to; to embrace or encircle.[Written also enclasp.]The flattering ivy who did ever see Inclasp the huge trunk of an agedtree. F. Beaumont.

The apparent enlargement of a bright object seen upon a darkground, due to the fact that the portions of the retina around theimage are stimulated by the intense light; as when a dark spot on awhite ground appears smaller, or a white spot on a dark groundlarger, than it really is, esp. when a little out of focus.
To invent; to contrive. [Obs.] Daniel.
Within the house; -- usually separated, in doors.
Doctrine and polity of the Independents.
Having iron sides, or very firm sides.
Insinuating; insinuative. [Obs.]
Inclined or disposed to intermeddle.-- In`ter*med"dle*some*ness, n.
One who holds the doctrine of the immortality of the soul. [R.]Jer. Taylor.
Rude; uncivil; disobedient. [Obs.] -- Im`mo*rig"er*ous*ness, n.[Obs.] Jer. Taylor.
The restitution of an outlawed person to the protection of thelaw; inlawing. Bouvier.
Not to be gashed or marked with furrows. [Obs.]As easy mayest thou the intrenchant air With thy keen sword impress,as make me bleed. Shak.
The act of assuming, or state of being clothed with, flesh;incarnation.
The state of being illegitimate. Blackstone.
The variety of sugar (glucose) obtained from the glucosideindican. It is unfermentable, but reduces Fehling's solution.

Relating to, dependent on, or denoting, illation; inferential;conclusive; as, an illative consequence or proposition; an illativeword, as then, therefore, etc. Illative conversion (Logic), aconverse or reverse statement of a proposition which in that formmust be true because the original proposition is true.-- Illative sense (Metaph.), the faculty of the mind by which itapprehends the conditions and determines upon the correctness ofinferences.
Blown in; inflated. Chaucer.
Capable of being instructed; teachable; docible. Bacon.
One who improvises.
Like, or pertaining to, fishes.
Inorganic. Locke.
Wearing a periwig.
A subclass of Gastropoda, in which the body is symmetrical, theright and left sides being equal.
See Emboil.

The dorsal one of the three principal bones comprising eitherlateral half of the pelvis; the dorsal or upper part of the hip bone.See Innominate bone, under Innominate. [Written also ilion, andileum.]
A provocative; an incitant; a stimulant. [R.] Jervas.
A salt of iodic acid.
The act of linking together; enchaining. [R.] Goldsmith.
Same as Urrhodin.
Freedom from agitation of mind; calmness; quietude. W. Montagu.
Bred within; innate; as, inbred worth. "Inbred sentiments."Burke.
Of or pertaining to ichnology.
See Embase.
AThis sweet intercourse Of looks and smiles. Milton.Sexual intercourse, sexual or carnal connection; coition.
Not capable of being repressed, restrained, or controlled; as,irrepressible joy; an irrepressible conflict. W. H. Steward.
An order of birds, formerly established to include the perchingbirds, but now generally regarded as an artificial group.
Insignificance.
Pertaining to, or obtained from, nux vomica or St. Ignatius'sbean; as, igasuric acid.
See Engross.
Impossibility to be avoided or shunned; inevitableness.Shelford.
Not devirginate. [Obs.] Chapman.
Not declinable; not varied by inflective terminations; as,nihil (nothing), in Latin, is an indeclinable noun.-- n.
To treat cruelly or improperly; to ill use; to maltreat.
A state of being unmixed; separateness. Sir T. Browne.
The act of imprecating, or unvoking evil upon any one; a playerthat a curse or calamnity may fall on any one; a curse.Men cowered like slaves before such horrid imprecations. Motley.
Of or pertaining to illuminism, or the Illuminati.
Unconformable. [Obs.] Gauden.
To come into contact with (an ovum or egg) so as to causeimpregnation; to fertilize; to fecundate.

Untouched, especially by anything that harms, defiles, or thelike; uninjured; undefiled; left complete or entire. Buckle.When all external differences have passed away, one element remainsintact, unchanged, -- the everlasting basis of our common nature, thehuman soul. F. W. Robertson.
Pertaining to inspiration.
Having the quality of relieving ischury.-- n.

That which enters into a compound, or is a component part ofany combination or mixture; an element; a constituent.By way of analysis we may proceed from compounds to ingredients. SirI. Newton.Water is the chief ingredient in all the animal fluids and solids.Arbuthnot.
An inflection; a bend or fold. [R.] Sir T. Browne.

Any mental apprehension of an object. First intention (Logic),a conception of a thing formed by the first or direct application ofthe mind to the individual object; an idea or image; as, man, stone.-- Second intention (Logic), a conception generalized from firstintuition or apprehension already formed by the mind; an abstractnotion; especially, a classified notion, as species, genus,whiteness.-- To heal by the first intention (Surg.), to cicatrize, as a wound,without suppuration.-- To heal by the second intention (Surg.), to unite aftersuppuration.
Between the tarsal bones; as, the intertarsal articulations.

Any bird of the genus Ibis and several allied genera, of thefamily Ibidæ, inhabiting both the Old World and the New. Numerousspecies are known. They are large, wading birds, having a long,curved beak, and feed largely on reptiles.
Isomorphism between the three forms, severally, of twotrimorphous substances.
To weave in or together; to intermix or intertwine by weaving;to interlace.Down they cast Their crowns, inwove with amaranth and gold. Milton.
A begining. [Obs.] "Their springings and imprimings." Sir H.Wotton.
Inexactness; uncertainty; as, geographical inexactitude.
Impertinence. [R.]O, matter and impertinency mixed! Reason in madness! Shak.
Not tractable; not easily governed, managed, or directed;indisposed to be taught, disciplined, or tamed; violent; stubborn;obstinate; refractory; as, an intractable child.
See Embolden.
Not momentous; unimportant; insignificant. [R.] A. Seward.
Coming in together; entering; commingling. [R.] Sir T. Browne.

An artificial international language, selected by the"Delegation for the Adoption of an Auxillary International Language"(founded at Paris in 1901), made public in 1907, and subsequentlygreatly revised and extended by a permanent committee or "Academy."It combines systematically the advantages of previous schemes with athoroughly logical word formation, and has neither accented constantsnor arbitrarily coined pronominal words. For each idea that root isselected which is already most international, on the principle of the"greatest facility for the greatest number of people." The word "Ido"means in the language itself "offspring." The official name is:"Linguo Internaciona di la Delegitaro (Sistema Ido)." --I"dism (#),n. -- I"dist (#), n.
The insertion of a day, or other portion of time, in acalendar.

Not communicable; incapable of being communicated, shared,told, or imparted, to others.Health and understanding are incommunicable. Southey.Those incommunicable relations of the divine love. South.-- In`com*mu"ni*ca*ble*ness, n.-- In`com*mu"ni*ca*bly, adv.
Peculiarity of constitution; that temperament, or state ofconstitution, which is peculiar to a person; idiosyncrasy.
A woman who is an imitator.
Same; each; every. [Archaic] Spenser. Of that ilk, denotingthat a person's surname and the title of his estate are the same; as,Grant of that ilk, i.e., Grant of Grant. Jamieson.
To form into an island; to surround. [Obs.] Drayton.
A genus of sapotaceous trees of India. Isonandra Gutta is theprincipal source of gutta-percha.
The act of incommoded. [Obs.] Cheyne.
In an curious manner.
The state of interdigitating; interdigital space. Owen.
Tending to illuminate or illustrate; throwing light;illustrative. "Illuminative reading." Carlyle.
The quality of being imbecile; weakness; feebleness, esp. ofmind.Cruelty . . . argues not only a depravedness of nature, but also ameanness of courage and imbecility of mind. Sir W. Temple.
With indentations.
Interstellar.
Communicating or transmitting impressions between differentparts of the body; -- said of the nervous system. Carpenter.
Deduced or deducible by inference. "Inferential proofs." J. S.Mill.
Not ponderable; without sensible or appreciable weight;incapable of being weighed.
The substance or body that insulates; a nonconductor.
To stuff; to swell. [Obs.]The body is infarced with . . . watery humors. Sir T. Elyot.

Of, pertaining to, or containing, the petrified cases of thelarvæ of certain insects. Indusial limestone (Geol.), a fresh-waterlimestone, largely composed of the agglomerated cases of caddiceworms, or larvæ of caddice flies (Phryganea). It is found in Miocenestrata of Auvergne, France, and some other localities.

To attack by words or arguments; to contradict; to assail; tocall in question; to make insinuations against; to gainsay; tooppose.The truth hereof I will net rashly pugn, or overboldly affirm.Peacham.

A peculiarity in the design of bas-relief by which the heads ofhuman figures are kept at the same height from the ground, whetherthe personages are seated, standing, or mounted on horseback; --called also isokephaleia.
To deceive; to entice; to lure. [Obs.]The devil insnareth the souls of many men, by illuring them with themuck and dung of this world. Fuller.
A device. See Impresa.An imprese, as the Italians call it, is a device in picture with hismotto or word, borne by noble or learned personages. Camden.
A world between other worlds. Holland.
Incapable of being found out. Bp. Morton.
The state or quality of being irreligious; ungodliness.
Indentation; an impression like that made by a tooth.
The act by which falsehood and forgery are proved; an actionbrought for the purpose of having some instrument declared false orforged. Bell.
That which intoxicates; an intoxicating agent; as, alcohol,opium, and laughing gas are intoxicants.
Incidentally. [Obs.]
To generate within; to inbreed. [Obs.] Hakewill.
Empery. [Archaic] Joye.
One who issues, emits, or publishes.
An intertie.
Want of appreciation.

A neck or narrow slip of land by which two continents areconnected, or by which a peninsula is united to the mainland; as, theIsthmus of Panama; the Isthmus of Suez, etc. Isthmus of the fauces.(Anat.) See Fauces.
The frequent use of the sound of iota (that of English e inbe), as among the modern Greeks; also, confusion from soundingLittré.

Without stain or blemish; spotless; undefiled; clear; pure.Were but my soul as pure From other guilt as that, Heaven did nothold One more immaculate. Denham.Thou sheer, immaculate and silver fountain. Shak.Immaculate conception (R. C. Ch.), the doctrine that the Virgin Marywas conceived without original sin.-- Im*mac"u*late*ly, adv.-- Im*mac"u*late*ness, n.
In an impolitic manner.
In an irrational manner. Boyle.
Not consummated; not finished; incomplete. Sir M. Hale.-- In`con*sum"mate*ness, n.

Too numerous or variable to make a particular enumerationimportant; -- said of the parts of a flower, and the like. Also,indeterminate. Indefinite article (Gram.), the word a or an, usedwith nouns to denote any one of a common or general class.-- Indefinite inflorescence. (Bot.) See Indeterminate inflorescence,under Indeterminate.-- Indefinite proposition (Logic), a statement whose subject is acommon term, with nothing to indicate distribution ornondistribution; as, Man is mortal.-- Indefinite term (Logic), a negative term; as, the not-good.
To shut off or out from a place or course, by somethingintervening; to intercept; to cut off; to interrupt. Mitford.So all passage of external air into the receiver may be intercluded.Boyle.
In an incompatible manner; inconsistently; incongruously.
In an impenetrable manner or state; imperviously. "Impenetrablyarmed." Milton. "Impenetrably dull." Pope.
To confine as in a cloister; to cloister. Lovelace.
Want of equity; injustice; wrong. "Some form of inequity." H.Spencer.
The quality of being implacable; implacability.
Impartation.
In possibility; possible, although not yet in existence or cometo pass; -- contradistinguished from in esse.
Having an odd number of fingers or toes, either one, three, orfive, as in the horse, tapir, rhinoceros, etc.
A foreign substance, either liquid or solid, usually of minutesize, inclosed in the mass of a mineral.
Capable or susceptible of being investigated; admittingresearch. Hooker.
Of or belonging to idyls.
Inconsequence.
Refusing compromise; uncompromising; irreconcilable. Lond. Sat.Rev.
Careless; heedless; indifferent; unconcerned. J. S. Mill.
One who instigates or incites. Burke.
To renew or renovate. [R.]
Isotropic.

To make worse; to diminish in quantity, value, excellence, orstrength; to deteriorate; as, to impair health, character, the mind,value.Time sensibly all things impairs. Roscommon.In years he seemed, but not impaired by years. Pope.
Not perturbed.
One who wishes ill to another; an enemy.
One of several species of wild goats having very large,recurved horns, transversely ridged in front; -- called alsosteinbok.
Quality of being imputable.
The act of making into paste; that which is formed into a pasteor mixture; specifically, a combination of different substances bymeans of cements.
The theory or method of suggesting an effect or impressionwithout elaboration of the details; -- a disignation of a recentfashion in painting and etching.
Not equally distant; not equidistant.
To run between parties and intercept without right theadvantage that one should gain from the other; to traffic without aproper license; to intrude; to forestall others; to intermeddle.
That may be imaged. [R.]
Liable to illusion.
In an impracticable manner.Morality not impracticably rigid. Johnson.
Not cogitative; not thinking; wanting the power of thought; as,a vegetable is an incogitative being. Locke.
Of or pertaining to iridium; -- applied specifically tocompounds in which iridium has a low valence.
A kindler of anger or enmity; an inciter.
Subcutaneous.
At the same node with opposite or whorled leaves, but occupyinga position between their places of attachment.
Inside the line of a vessel's bulwarks or hull; the opposite ofoutboard; as, an inboard cargo; haul the boom inboard.

Not discriminate; wanting discrimination; undistinguishing; notmaking any distinction; confused; promiscuous. "Blind orindiscriminate forgiveness." I. Taylor.The indiscriminate defense of right and wrong. Junius.-- In`dis*crim"i*nate*ly, adv. Cowper.

A certain conic section supposed to be drawn in the tangentplane to any surface, and used to determine the accidents ofcurvature of the surface at the point of contact. The curve issimilar to the intersection of the surface with a parallel to thetangent plane and indefinitely near it. It is an ellipse when thecurvature is synclastic, and an hyperbola when the curvature isanticlastic.
Freedom from affectation; naturalness. [R.]
A hospital, or place where the infirm or sick are lodged andnursed gratuitously, or where out-patients are treated.
Not bearing fruit; not fructiferous.
So as not to be extinguished; in an inextinguishable manner.
Not capacious; narrow; small; weak or foolish; as, anincapacious soul. Bp. Burnet.-- In`ca*pa"cious*ness, n.
An agent or preparation for destroying insects; an insectpowder.-- In*sec"ti*ci`dal, a.
One who has the charge, direction, or management of some publicbusiness; a superintendent; as, an intendant of marine; an intendantof finance.
Not liable to relapse; secure. Dr. H. More.
To unite by twining one with another; to entangle; tointerlace. Milton.
An improviser, or improvvisatore.
Beneath the scapula, or shoulder blade; subscapular.

Remaining within; inherent; indwelling; abiding; intrinsic;internal or subjective; hence, limited in activity, agency, oreffect, to the subject or associated acts; -- opposed to emanant,transitory, transitive, or objective.A cognition is an immanent act of mind. Sir W. Hamilton.An immanent power in the life of the world. Hare.
Internally; inwardly.
A coating or covering resembling ice, as of sugar and milk orwhite of egg; frosting.
Out of season; untimely. [Obs.] Burton.Intempestive bashfulness gets nothing. Hales.
A quantity greater than any assignable quantity of the samekind.
Within the mesentery; as, the intermesenteric, or aortic,plexus.
A line connecting points on the earth's surface having the samemean summer temperature.
The art or method of determining the coloring power of indigo.
Undoubtedly; unquestionably; in a manner to remove all doubt.Oracles indubitably clear and infallibly certain. Barrow.
A yellow dye obtained from the leaves of the holly.
Act of thinning a wood to let in light. [Obs.] Evelyn.
Producing but one kind of spore, as the ferns and Equiseta. Cf.Heterosporic.
The act of pouring into a vessel; specif. (Med.), the operationof introducing a substance into a blood vessel; as, intrafusion ofblood.
In an isolated manner.
The state of being intestate, or of dying without having made avalid will. Blackstone.
Expressing or pertaining to a beginning; inceptive; as, aninchoative verb. "Some inchoative or imperfect rays." W. Montagu.-- n.
Power over fire. [R.]
Tending to improve, beneficial; growing better.-- Im*prov"ing*ly, adv. Improving lease (Scots Law), an extend leaseto induce the tenant to make improvements on the premises.
To intone. Cf. Entune.
To wrinkle. [Obs.]
See Enfeoffment.
The quality or state of being invisible; invisibility.
The state or quality of being inordinate; excessiveness;immoderateness; as, the inordinacy of love or desire. Jer. Taylor.
An intermediate depot or station between one commercial city orcountry and another. Mitford.
The want of unctuosity; freedom from greasiness or oiliness;as, the inunctuosity of porcelain clay. Kirwan.
Having the shape of an isopod; -- said of the larvæ of certaininsects.
A maker of images. Fairholt.
To incarnate.
The qual ity or state of being inoculable.
Act of leaning upon something; incumbency. [Obs.] Derham.
State of being within; interiority. [R.] H. Brooke.
Pertaining to, or derived from, the holly (Ilex), and alliedplants; as, ilicic acid.
The act of immigrating; the passing or coming into a countryfor the purpose of permanent residence.The immigrations of the Arabians into Europe. T. Warton.
A Japanese measure of length equal to about two and one twelfthyards. [Written also ink.]
Formed between the upper and lower teeth; as, interdentalconsonants.
To interpose; to insert or place between. [R.] Cudworth.
To sprinkle; to scatter. [Obs.] Bailey.
Marked with different shades. W. Browne.
Incapable of being moved; immovable; fixed; stable. Prof.Shedd.
To pleach; to interweave. [Obs.] Shak.
A mediator.

A small bottle of horn or other material formerly used forholding ink; an inkstand; a portable case for writing materials."With a writer's inkhorn by his side." Ezek. ix. 2.From his pocket the notary drew his papers and inkhorn. Longfellow.

A funnel-shaped or dilated organ or part; as, the infundibulumof the brain, a hollow, conical process, connecting the floor of thethird ventricle with the pituitary body; the infundibula of thelungs, the enlarged terminations of the bronchial tubes.
Intercommunication; community of possessions, religion, etc.In consequence of that intercommunity of paganism . . . one nationadopted the gods of another. Bp. Warburton.
Full of ire; angry; wroth. "The ireful bastard Orleans." Shak.-- Ire"ful*ly, adv.
Same as Isopod.
Not admitting excuse, evasion, or plea; rigorous. [R.] T.Adams.

A substance of very wide occurrence. It is found dissolved inthe sap of the roots and rhizomes of many composite and other plants,as Inula, Helianthus, Campanula, etc., and is extracted by solutionas a tasteless, white, semicrystalline substance, resembling starch,with which it is isomeric. It is intermediate in nature betweenstarch and sugar. Called also dahlin, helenin, alantin, etc.
A red, gummy, coloring matter, extracted from the colorlessjuice of the Otaheite chestnut (Inocarpus edulis).
Not capable of being remitted; irremissible. Holinshed.
The typical limb, or lateral fin, of fishes.
The quality or state of being inalienable; inalienability.

Not capable of being reduced to the form of a liquid bypressure; -- said of any gas above its critical point; -- alsoparticularly of oxygen, hydrogen, nitrogen, and carbon monoxide,formerly regarded as incapable of liquefaction at any temperature orpressure.
Unutterable; inexpressible. Milton.
Having no force, effect, or efficacy; void; null; as, aninvalid contract or agreement.
Incorporeally. [Obs.]
The state or quality of being icy or very cold; frigidity.
The quality of being indemonstrable.
Impostrous; deceitful.Strictness fales and impostrous. Beau. & Fl.
To affict with pestilence; to infect, as with plague. [Obs.]
The insertion of a scion in a stock; ingraftment. Ray.
That can not be execrated enough. [R.]
Fearless.-- Im*pav"id*ly, adv.
The quality or state of being impertransible. [R.]
Irascible; choleric. "Iracund people." Carlyle.
One who plays upon an instrument of music, as distinguishedfrom a vocalist.
The quality or state of being irrelevant; as, the irrelevancyof an argument.
In an injudicious manner.

Pertaining to, containing, or combined with, the radical NH,which is called the imido group. Imido acid, an organic acid,consisting of one or more acid radicals so united with the imidogroup that it contains replaceable acid hydrogen, and plays the partof an acid; as, uric acid, succinimide, etc., are imido acids.
Want of urbanity or courtesy; unpolished manners or deportment;inurbaneness; rudeness. Bp. Hall.
To thicken or bring to greater consistence, as fluids byevaporation.
An extinct genus of large, fossil, bivalve shells,allied to themussels. The genus is characteristic of the Cretaceous period.

Of or pertaining to the intestines of an animal; as, theintestinal tube; intestinal digestion; intestinal ferments.Intestinal canal. Same as Intestine, n.-- Intestinal worm (Zoöl.), any species of helminth living in theintestinal canal of any animal. The species are numerous.
To inhabit. [Obs.]
Having equal pressure. Isopiestic lines, lines showing, in adiagram, the relations of temperature and volume, when the elasticforce is constant; -- called also isobars.
In an impertinent manner. "Not to betray myself impertinently."B. Jonson.
The act of invigorating, or the state of being invigorated.
That part of physiology which treats of the integuments ofanimals and plants.
A thundering; thunder. [Obs.] Bailey.
Having or measuring (so many) inches; as, a four-inched bridge.Shak.
Within the cranium or skull. Sir W. Hamilton.
To bastardize; to debase. [Obs.] Milton.
The state of being inextricable.

Existing only in contemplation of law; not capable of actualvisible seizin or possession; not being an object of sense;intangible; -- opposed to corporeal. Incorporeal hereditament. Seeunder Hereditament.
In an intellectual manner.
Growing immediately above, or in front of, a leaf; as,intrafoliaceous stipules.
See Endowment.
Induction.

Not refragable; not to be gainsaid or denied; not to be refutedor overthrown; unanswerable; incontestable; undeniable; as, anirrefragable argument; irrefragable evidence.-- Ir*ref"ra*ga*ble*ness, n.-- Ir*ref"ra*ga*bly, adv.
A line or curved surface passing beneath the earth's surfacethrough points having the same mean temperature.
Idealism. J. Grote.

The quality or state of being inflexible, or not capable ofbeing bent or changed; unyielding stiffness; inflexibleness;rigidity; firmness of will or purpose; unbending pertinacity;steadfastness; resoluteness; unchangeableness; obstinacy.The inflexibility of mechanism. A. Baxter.That grave inflexibility of soul. Churchill.The purity and inflexibility of their faith. T. Warton.
Undetermined.
Capable of being impressed; susceptible; sensitive.-- Im*press"i*ble*ness, n.-- Im*press"i*bly, adv.
Serving to initiate; inceptive; initiatory; introductory;preliminary.
Not angular. [Obs.]
Not confutable.-- In`con*fut"a*bly, adv. [Obs.] Jer. Taylor.
Irrelevancy.
Cloth of silver or of gold. [R.]
A woman in love; a mistress. "The fair inamorata." Sherburne.

Not provident; wanting foresight or forethought; not foreseeingor providing for the future; negligent; thoughtless; as, animprovident man.Improvident soldires! had your watch been good, This sudden mischiefnever could have fallen. Shak.
To render immaterial or incorporeal.Immateralized spirits. Glanvill.
The act of induing, or state of being indued; investment;endowment. W. Montagu.
Isomorphism between the two forms severally of two dimorphoussubstances.
Same as Ishial.
Incapable of being lost. [R.] Hammond.-- In`a*mis"si*ble*ness, n. [R.]
Not explicit; not clearly stated; indefinite; vague.
Made hollow; bent round or in.
Done without deliberation; unpremeditated. [Obs.] --In`de*lib"er*ate*ly, adv. [Obs.]
One who, or that which, influences.
Unlucky; unfortunate. [Obs.] Shak."A most infortynate chance." Howell.- In*for"tu*nate*ly, adv. [Obs.]
Having no communion or intercourse with each other. [Obs.] SirM. Hale.
To inhume; to bury; to inter. Hedge.
See Enfranchise.
One of the teeth in front of the canines in either jaw; anincisive tooth. See Tooth.
In an improper manner; not properly; unsuitably; unbecomingly.
A steering gear, esp. for an automobile, not affected by theroad wheels, as when they strike an obstacle side ways, but easilycontrolled by the hand wheel or steering lever.
Undivided. [Obs.]
To gain favor. [R.] Sir W. Temple.
That can not be suppressed or concealed; irrepressible. Young.-- In`sup*press"i*bly, adv.
Unquietness; restlessness. Sir W. Temple.
Pertaining to the goddess Isis; as, Isiac mysteries.
Lack of proper digestive action; a failure of the normalchanges which food should undergo in the alimentary canal; dyspepsia;incomplete or difficult digestion.
Pertaining to, or derived from, indigo; as, indigotic acid,which is also called anilic or nitrosalicylic acid.
Not consumable; incapable of being consumed, wasted, or spent.Paley.-- In`con*sum"a*bly, adv.
Between the orbits; as, the interorbital septum.

The quality or state of being imprudent; want to caution,circumspection, or a due regard to consequences; indiscretion;inconsideration; reshness; also, an imprudent act; as, he was guiltyof an imprudence.His serenity was interrupted, perhaps, by his own imprudence. Mickle.
Commanding. [R.] Baxter.
The quality or state of being immovable; fixedness;steadfastness; as, immovability of a heavy body; immovability ofpurpose.
Capable of illustration. Sir T. Browne.
To entreat. [Obs.]
Not obtrusive; unobtrusive.-- In`ob*tru"sive*ly, adv.-- In`ob*tru"sive*ness, n.
Not favorable; unlucky; unpropitious; sinister. [R.] Ld.Lytton.
Between the petals of a flower.
See Encumber.
To know mutually. [Obs.]
In an inaccurate manner; incorrectly; inexactly.
The quality of being intractable; intractableness. Bp. Hurd.
The property or state of being indehiscent.
Not reparable; not capable of being repaired, recovered,regained, or remedied; irretrievable; irremediable; as, anirreparable breach; an irreparable loss. Shak.
Having twenty equal sides or faces.
An oily substance prepared by the dry distillation of abituminous mineral containing fossil fishes. It is used in medicineas a remedy in some forms of skin diseases.

Incapable of suffering; inaccessible to harm or pain; not to betouched or moved to passion or sympathy; unfeeling, or not showingfeeling; without sensation. "Impassible to the critic." Sir W. Scott.Secure of death, I should contemn thy dart Though naked, andimpassible depart. Dryden.
Incapable of being corroded, consumed, or eaten away.
Isotrimorphous.
Unable to perceive.The imperceptive part of the soul. Dr. H. More.
A complex, nitrogenous radical, C8H5NO, regarded as theessential nucleus of indigo.

The most common and most useful metallic element, being ofalmost universal occurrence, usually in the form of an oxide (ashematite, magnetite, etc.), or a hydrous oxide (as limonite, turgite,etc.). It is reduced on an enormous scale in three principal forms;viz., cast iron, steel, and wrought iron. Iron usually appears darkbrown, from oxidation or impurity, but when pure, or an freshsurface, is a gray or white metal. It is easily oxidized (rusted) bymoisture, and is attacked by many corrosive agents. Symbol Fe (LatinFerrum). Atomic weight 55.9. Specific gravity, pure iron, 7.86; castiron, 7.1. In magnetic properties, it is superior to all othersubstances.
Imperative. [R.]
Badly put together; inartificial; rude; unpolished; irregular."Carol incondite rhymes." J. Philips.
Of or pertaining to the Isospondyli; having the anteriorvertebræ separate and normal.
An arrow poison, made from an apocynaceous plant (Strophanthushispidus) of the Gaboon country; -- called also onaye.
Of or pertaining to infiltration. Kane.
Idle-headed; stupid. [Obs.]
The state or quality of being immutable; immutableness. Heb.vi. 17.
Pertaining to the mutual intercourse or relations of persons insociety; social.
