A rich, powerful, perfume, obtained from the volatile oil ofthe flowers of Canada odorata, an East Indian tree. [Also writtenylang-ylang.]
See Ensconce.
Pertaining to, involving, or caused by, imagination.

Lying or being in the middle place or degree, or between twoextremes; coming or done between; intervening; interposed;interjacent; as, an intermediate space or time; intermediate colors.Intermediate state (Theol.), the state or condition of the soulbetween the death and the resurrection of the body.-- Intermediate terms (Math.), the terms of a progression or seriesbetween the first and the last (which are called the extremes); themeans.-- Intermediate tie. (Arch.) Same as Intertie.
Disordered; disturbed. [Obs.] Milton.-- In`com*po"sed*ly, adv. [Obs.] -- In`com*pos"ed*ness, n. [Obs.]
Introduction. [Obs.]
Unpardonable. [Obs.] South.
Wearing mail or armor; clad of armor. W. Browne.
To twist in and out; to twine; to wreathe; to wind; to wring.Pope.
The worship of images as symbols; -- distinguished fromidolatry, the worship of images themselves.
Want of regular form; shapelessness. [Obs.]
An interregent, or a regent.

The quality or state of being intrepid; fearless bravery;courage; resoluteness; valor.Sir Roger had acquitted himself of two or three sentences with a lookof much business and great intrepidity. Addison.
To manacle; to fetter; hence; to confine; to restrain from freeaction.Although this corporal rind Thou hast immanacled. Milton.
Below the spine; infraspinal; esp., below the spine of thescapula; as, the infraspinous fossa; the infraspinate muscle.
Not liable to exception or rejection. Sir W. Hamilton.
Not proportionable. [Obs.] B. Jonson.
A person indicted.
Not dispersed. [R.]
Intolerant. [R.]
Between and uniting the nervous ganglions; as, interganglioniccords.
Mutual trade of traffic.
In the first place; first in order.
Mutual or reciprocal relation; correlation.

That property of matter by which it tends when at rest toremain so, and when in motion to continue in motion, and in the samestraight line or direction, unless acted on by some external force; -- sometimes called vis inertiæ.
In a manner or to a degree beyond endurance; intolerably; as, ablaze insufferably bright; a person insufferably proud.
In the manner of an index.
Susceptibility of taking fire readily; the state or quality ofbeing inflammable.
Uttered or done again; repeated. [Obs.] Bp. Gardiner.
To inclose; to surround of hem in with troops, so as tointercept succors of men and provisions and prevent escape; to laysiege to; as, to invest a town.
Greater than any assignable quantity of the same kind; -- saidof certain quantities.
Infusorial.
A swelling; the act of swelling, or state of being swelled.[Obs.] Sir T. Browne.
Intertwined; interlocked; clasped together. Longfellow.
Indicating equal auroral display; as, an isochasmic line.

To thrust one's self in; to come or go in without invitation,permission, or welcome; to encroach; to trespass; as, to intrude onfamilies at unseasonable hours; to intrude on the lands of another.Thy wit wants edge And manners, to intrude where I am graced. Shak.Some thoughts rise and intrude upon us, while we shun them; othersfly from us, when we would hold them. I. Watts.
One who meddles with, or intrudes into, the affairs of others.Swift.
A female inspector.
Itinerant; traveling; passing from place to place; done on ajourney.It was rather an itinerary circuit of justice than a progress. Bacon.
The second digit, that next pollex, in the manus, or hand; theforefinger; index finger.
Pedantry. Sir T. Wilson.
See Enablement. [Obs.]
Same as Intrusive.
Soaring too high for safety, like Icarus; adventurous inflight.
Hoary with white pubescence.
Void of meaning. [Obs.] Shak.
Want of devotion; impiety; irreligion. "An age of indevotion."Jer. Taylor.
Capable of being iterated or repeated. [Obs.]
That which incubates, especially, an apparatus by means ofwhich eggs are hatched by artificial heat.
The interval or space between two pilasters. Elmes.
A figure or polygon whose angles are equal.
Being within the substance of the walls of an organ; as,intramural pregnancy.
See Inhabitativeness.What the phrenologists call inhabitiveness. Lowell.
See Entombment.
Infantile; childish.A degree of credulity next infantine. Burke.
Not warlike or martial. [Obs.] R. Junius.
Intermediate. [Obs.]
Of or pertaining to the Incas.
To play upon by artifice; to deceive; to mock; to excite anddisappoint the hopes of.
The state or quality of being illiberal; narrowness of mind;meanness; niggardliness. Bacon.
Not capable of joint existence; incompatible; inconsistent.[Obs.]Ambition and faith . . . are . . . incompossible. Jer. Taylor.-- In`com*pos`si*bil"i*ty, n. [Obs.]
To exist within; to dwell within. [Obs.]Substances inexisting within the divine mind. A. Tucker.
To color or tinge with purple; to make red or reddish; topurple; as, a field impurpled with blood.Impurpled with celestial roses, smiled. Milton.The silken fleece impurpled for the loom. Pope.
Inserted in the corner of the eye; -- said of the antenn
In the innermost place. [R.]His ebon cross worn innermostly. Mrs. Browning.
A silicate of alumina, iron, and magnesia, having a bright bluecolor and vitreous luster; cordierite. It is remarkable for itsdichroism, and is also called dichroite.
To insnare; to entrap; to entangle; to catch.Let not the surpassing eloquence of Taylor dazzle you, nor hisscholastic retairy versatility of logic illaqueate your good sense.Coleridge.
The state of being without perforation.

A willful neglect or refusal to acquire knowledge which one mayacquire and it is his duty to have. Book of Common Prayer. Invincibleignorance (Theol.), ignorance beyond the individual's control and forwhich, therefore, he is not responsible before God.
The middle pair of tail feathers, or middle rectrices.
The quality of being illusive; deceptiveness; false show.
With security from error; infallibly; unerringly.

Not considerable; unworthy of consideration or notice;unimportant; small; trivial; as, an inconsiderable distance; aninconsiderable quantity, degree, value, or sum. "The baser scum andinconsiderable dregs of Rome." Stepney.-- In`con*sid"er*a*ble*ness, n.-- In`con*sid"er*a*bly, adv.
See Enfeeble.
To set between or among. [R.]
Pronunciation of e in the English word be. This was thepronunciation advocated by ReuEtacism.In all such questions between a the confusing element of itacismcomes in. Alford.
To give nervous energy or power to; to give increasedenergy,force,or courage to; to invigorate; to stimulate.
To the inside of; within. It is used in a variety ofapplications.
Not confused; distinct. [Obs.]
Pardonable. [Obs.] Bailey.
Narrowed at the forward end; -- said of an automobile framewhen the side members are closer together at the forward end than atthe rear.
To entitle; to give a title to. Selden.
The quality or state of being inflexible; inflexibility;rigidity; firmness.
To animate or inspire mutually. [Obs.] Donne.
Of or pertaining to crimination; tending to incriminate;criminatory.
Attentively; closely. [Obs.] "Intentively to observe." Holland.
The quality of being intolerable; intolerableness. [R.]
The condition of an invalid; sickness; infirmity.
Having nothing distinctive; common.-- In`dis*tinc"tive*ness, n.

To meddle with the affairs of others; to meddle officiously; tointerpose or interfere improperly; to mix or meddle with.The practice of Spain hath been, by war and by conditions of treaty,to intermeddle with foreign states. Bacon.

Incapable of being resolved; not separable into componentparts. Irresolvable nebulæ (Astron.), nebulæ of a cloudlikeappearance, which have not yet been resolved by the telescope intostars. Sir W. Herschel.
The quality of being injurious or hurtful; harmfulness; injury.

Ignorant or negligent of the rules of logic or correctreasoning; as, an illogical disputant; contrary of the rules of logicor sound reasoning; as, an illogical inference.-- Il*log"ic*al*ly, adv.-- Il*log"ic*al*ness, n.
An extinct order of marine reptiles, including Ichthyosaurusand allied forms; -- called also Ichthyopterygia. They have not beenfound later than the Cretaceous period.
Self-heating; warmed, as the body of animal, by process goingon within itself.
Unworthily. [Obs.]
A prefix signifying in, within, interior; as, intraocular,within the eyeball; intramarginal.
A small circle. [Obs.] Sir P. Sidney.
In its natural position or place; -- said of a rock or fossil,when found in the situation in which it was originally formed ordeposited.
To write on a scroll; to record. [Written also inscrol.] Shak.
The act of upbraiding or taunting; a reproach; a taunt. [Obs.]Improperatios and terms of scurrility. Sir T. Browne
Innutritious.
Bent or turned abruptly inwards, or toward the axis, as thepetals of a flower.
The act of interposing; interposition; intervention.
A covering or inlaying of marble, mosaic, etc., attached to themasonry by cramp irons or cement.
The space between two axes. See Axis, 6.The doors, windows, niches, and the like, are then placed centrallyin the interaxes. Gwilt.
To yoke or harness, as oxen to a vehicle. [South Africa]
The quality or condition of being illegal; unlawfulness; as,the illegality of trespass or of false imprisonment; also, an illegalact.
A celebrated Greek epic poem, in twenty-four books, on thedestruction of Ilium, the ancient Troy. The Iliad is ascribed toHomer.
Enraged; rading; furiously angry; infuriated. Milton.Inflamed beyond the most infuriate wrath. Thomson.
To send in; to inject; to infuse; -- the correlative of emit.[R.] Boyle.
Iliac. [R.]
The act of imparting, or the thing imparted.The necessity of this impartation. I. Taylor.
Pertaining to, or performed or pronounced at, an inauguration;as, an inaugural address; the inaugural exercises.
Incitingly; encouragingly.
Investing. [R.] Mir. for Mag.
Exhibiting interference figures without the aid of apolariscope, as certain crystals.
Hardware; a general name for all articles made of iron. Gwilt.
To invest with the privileges of a denizen; to naturalize. [R.]Words indenizened, and commonly used as English. B. Jonson.
Safety; security. [Obs.] Howell.
In an infirm manner.
The act of involving, or the state of being involved. LewWallace.
The state or quality of being isostatic. Specif. (Geol.),
Rendered idiotic; befooled. [R.] Tennyson.
The act of instilling; also, that which is instilled. [Writtenalso instilment.]
Felt inwardly; heartfelt. [R.]The baron stood afar off, or knelt in submissive, acknowledged,infelt inferiority. Milman.
The median of the three elements composing the centra of thevertebræ in some fossil batrachians.
Between vertebræ.-- In`ter*ver"te*bral*ly, adv.
A light powder used as a substitute for iodoform. It is acompound of iodoform and albumin.
A growth or development inward. J. LeConte.
Wanting beauty or attractiveness; deformed; ugly; ill-looking.Ill-favored and lean-fleshed. Gen. xli. 3.-- Ill`-fa"vored*ly, adv.-- Ill`-fa"vored*ness, n.
One who, or that, increases.
A tribe of North American Indians, which formerly occupied theregion between the Wabash and Mississippi rivers.
The state or quality of being immature; immaturity. Boyle.
Not broken or fractured; unharmed; whole. [Obs.] Chapman.
The quality or state of being isostemonous.
Not consonant or agreeing; inconsistent; discordant.-- In*con"so*nant*ly, adv.
A kind of stone containing native vitriol or subphate of iron,used in making ink.
The act of interweaving, or the state of being interwoven; thatwhich is interwoven. "Knit in nice intertexture." Coleridge.Skirted thick with intertexture firm Of thorny boughs. Cowper.
Inimical; hurtful. [Obs.] Evelyn.
A short musical dramatic piece, of a light and pleasing,sometimes a burlesque, character; an interlude introduced between theacts of a play or an opera.
Not lacerable; incapable of being torn or rent. [Obs.]
The Australian Eucalyptus Sideroxylon, used largely bycarpenters and shipbuilders; -- called also ironwood.

The bone or cartilage between the radiale and ulnare in thecarpus, and between the tibiale and fibulare in the tarsus. Itcorresponds to the lunar in the carpus, and to a part of theastragalus in the tarsus of man and most mammals.
To drive or urge forward or on; to press on; to incite toaction or motion in any way.The surge impelled me on a craggy coast. Pope.
Not elaborate; not wrought with care; unpolished; crude;unfinished.
In an inveterate manner or degree. "Inveterately tough."Hawthorne.
The of instilling; also, that which is instilled. Johnson.
In an insufficient manner or degree; unadequately.

A compound with, or derivative of, the imido group; specif., acompound of one or more acid radicals with the imido group, or with amonamine; hence, also, a derivative of ammonia, in which two atoms ofhydrogen have been replaced by divalent basic or acid radicals; --frequently used as a combining form; as, succinimide.
Inciting; stimulating.

To follow up step by step by patient inquiry or observation; totrace or track mentally; to search into; to inquire and examine intowith care and accuracy; to find out by careful inquisition; as, toinvestigate the causes of natural phenomena.
One opposed to the diffusion of knowledge; an obscuriantist.
In the place; in the proper or natural place.
Incapable of being severed; indivisible; inseparable. DeQuincey.
Incapable of being together without mutual reaction ordecomposition, as certain medicines. Incompatible terms (Logic),terms which can not be combined in thought.
Insecurity.
The act or process of implantating.
A morbid state produced by the use of iodine and its compounds,and characterized by palpitation, depression, and general emaciation,with a pustular eruption upon the skin.
A substance isomeric with, and resembling, indigo blue, andaccompanying it as a side product, in its artificial production.
The act of poisoning or impoisoning. [Obs.] Pope.
Capable of being mutually communicated.
Want of activity or exertion; inertness; quietude. [R.]These vicissitudes of exertion and inertion of the arterial systemconstitute the paroxysms of remittent fever. E. Darwin.

The apparent resistance in an electric circuit to the flow ofan alternating current, analogous to the actual electrical resistanceto a direct current, being the ratio of electromotive force to thecurrent. It is equal to R2 + X2, where R = ohmic resistance, X =reactance. For an inductive circuit, X = 2pfL, where f = frequencyand L = self-inductance; for a circuit with capacity X = 1 ÷ 2pfC,where C = capacity.
Something infixed. [R.] Welsford.
Infusibility.
Destitute of life; lacking animation; unanimated. Pope.
To impress or mark with a seam or cicatrix. Pope.
Intercessory.
A tick of the genus Ixodes, or the family Ixodidæ.
Want of concinnity or congruousness; unsuitableness.There is an inconcinnity in admitting these words. Trench.
See Embraid.
Intermediate agency.
Overcome by some foolish passion or desire; affected byinfatuation.
Toughtless; inconsiderate. [R.] Milton.Men are careless and incogitant. J. Goodman.
An induction coil.
God with us; -- an appellation of the Christ. Is. vii. 14.Matt. i. 23.
The act of going in; entrance.
An islander. [R.] Berkeley.
The first word of ancient charters in England, confirming agrant made by a former king; hence, a royal grant.
Uniting two groups; -- said of certain genera which connectfamily groups, or of species that connect genera. See Osculant.
Incapable of being passed through. [R.]
Not defectible; unfailing; not liable to defect, failure, ordecay.An indefectible treasure in the heavens. Barrow.A state of indefectible virtue and happiness. S. Clarke.
A retention or suppression of urine.
Not putrescible.

Passing or traveling about a country; going or preaching on acircuit; wandering; not settled; as, an itinerant preacher; anitinerant peddler.The king's own courts were then itinerant, being kept in the king'spalace, and removing with his household in those royal progresseswhich he continually made. Blackstone.
The pallah deer of South Africa.

Corporate; incorporated; made one body, or united in one body;associated; mixed together; combined; embodied.As if our hands, our sides, voices, and minds Had been incorporate.Shak.A fifteenth part of silver incorporate with gold. Bacon.
Emitting no odor; wthout smell; scentless; odorless.-- In*o"dor*ous*ness, n.
In an inquiring manner.
Not frequently; rarely.
One who intervenes; a mediator; especially (Eccles. Hist.), aperson designated by a church to reconcile parties, and unite them inthe choice of officers. Coleman.
Want of harmony.
See Entreat. Spenser.
Swelling up; expanding.
Not maleable.
To print in Italic characters; to underline written letters orwords with a single line; as, to Italicize a word; Italicizes toomuch.
To pierce; to penetrate. [Obs.] Drayton.
The act or process of impaneling, or the state of beingimpaneled.
Affording no aliment or nourishment. [Obs.] Bacon.
Inquisitorial. [Obs.] "Our inquisiturient bishops." Milton.
To practice idolatry. [R.]To idolize after the manner of Egypt. Fairbairn.
Capable of being, or liable to be, indicted; subject toindictment; as, an indictable offender or offense.

To deprive of legal or constitutional requisites, or of abilityor competency for the performance of certain civil acts; todisqualify.It absolutely incapacitated them from holding rank, office, function,or property. Milman.

A pressure gauge; a water gauge, as for a steam boiler; anapparatus or instrument for showing the working of a machine ormoving part; as:(a) (Steam Engine) An instrument which draws a diagram showing thevarying pressure in the cylinder of an engine or pump at every pointof the stroke. It consists of a small cylinder communicating with theengine cylinder and fitted with a piston which the varying pressuredrives upward more or less against the resistance of a spring. Alever imparts motion to a pencil which traces the diagram on a cardwrapped around a vertical drum which is turned back and forth by astring connected with the piston rod of the engine. See Indicatorcard (below).(b) A telltale connected with a hoisting machine, to show, at thesurface, the position of the cage in the shaft of a mine, etc.
Engaging the attention; exciting, or adapted to excite,interest, curiosity, or emotion; as, an interesting story;interesting news. Cowper.
One given to illusion; a visionary dreamer.
One who invents.
By intertwisting, or being intertwisted.
Passing between; mediating; pleading. [R.] --In`ter*ced"ent*ly, adv.
Same as Vesuvianite.
Not discriminating.-- In`dis*crim"i*na`ting*ly, adv.
One who, or that which, individuates. Sir K. Digby.
Deceiving, or tending of deceive; fallacious; illusive; as,illusory promises or hopes.
See Illumine.
By implication or inference. Bp. Montagu.
Of or pertaining to Iran.-- n.
Proclaimed; declared; public. Kennet.
A presbyter appointed by the bishop to institute a rector orassistant minister over a parish church.
The state or quality of being inimical or hostile; hostility;unfriendliness. [R.]
To fill up intermediate terms of, as of a series, according tothe law of the series; to introduce, as a number or quantity, in apartial series, according to the law of that part of the series.
Not rethorical.
Want of reflection.
The quality of being ineffervescible.
Resembling, or pertaining to, the iguana.
To sacrifice; to offer in sacrifice; to kill, as a sacrificialvictim.Worshipers, who not only immolate to them [the deities] the lives ofmen, but . . . the virtue and honor of women. Boyle.
Not retrievable; irrecoverable; irreparable; as, anirretrievable loss.
The act of immitting, or of sending or thrusting in; injection;-- the correlative of emission.
To encircle to gird; to engirt.The wreath is ivy that ingirts our beams. Drayton.
Added or placed between the parts of another thing, as a clauseinserted parenthetically in a sentence.

Intricate; entangled; complicated; complex.The fable of every poem is . . . simple or implex. it is calledsimple when there is no change of fortune in it; implex, when thefortune of the chief actor changes from bad to good, or from good tobad. Addison.
With intermissions; at intervals. W. Montagu.
One who believes in or professes, immaterialism.
Incapacity of being engendered or produced. Cudworth.

Affected with indignation; wrathful; passionate; irate; feelingwrath, as when a person is exasperated by unworthy or unjusttreatment, by a mean action, or by a degrading accusation.He strides indignant, and with haughty cries To single fight thefairy prince defies. Tickell.
Not transient; remaining; permanent. Killingbeck.
To cause to cease for a time, or at intervals; to interrupt; tosuspend.Pray to the gods to intermit the plague. Shak.
One who gives information; an intelligencer. [Obs.] Holinshed.
The quality or state of being imponderable; imponderableness.
To intersect or penetrate with mines. [Obs.] Drayton.
To put in an urn, as the ashes of the dead; hence, to bury; tointomb.The sepulcher Wherein we saw thee quietly inurned. Shak.
Any species of the genus Iguana, a genus of large Americanlizards of the family Iguanidæ. They are arboreal in their habits,usually green in color, and feed chiefly upon fruits.
Not rotatory; passing from one point to another by a movementother than rotation; -- said of the movement of parts of a liquid oryielding mass. Sir W. Thomson.
To root deeply. [R.]
Characterized by imposture; deceitful. "Impostrous pretense ofknowledge." Grote.
To join; to unite. [R.] Shak.
Mutually repellent. De Quincey.
To lock in, or inclose.
A prefix signifying within, into, in, inward; as, introduce,introreception, introthoracic.
Want of submission; disobedience; noncompliance.
Undesirable.
In a manner not exact or precise; inaccurately. R. A. Proctor.
That may be impeached; liable to impeachment; chargeable with acrime.Owners of lands in fee simple are not impeachable for waste. Z.Swift.

Junior or subordinate in rank; as, an inferior officer.Inferior court (Law), a court subject to the jurisdiction of anothercourt known as the superior, or higher, court.-- Inferior letter, Inferior figure (Print.), a small letter orfigure standing at the bottom of the line (opposed to superior letteror figure), as in A2, Bn, 2 and n are inferior characters.-- Inferior tide, the tide corresponding to the moon's transit ofthe meridian, when below the horizon.
Same as Iguanoid.
See Inchpin.
To bind up,as in a knot; to include. [Obs.] Fuller.

The act of infatuating; the state of being infatuated; folly;that which infatuates.The infatuations of the sensual and frivolous part of mankind areamazing; but the infatuations of the learned and sophistical areincomparably more so. I. Taylor.Such is the infatuation of self-love. Blair.
Not submitting to authority; disobedient; rebellious; mutinous
Bending gradually toward the axis or center, as branches orpetals.

Not official; not having official sanction or authoriy; notaccording to the forms or ceremony of official business; as,inofficial intelligence.Pinckney and Marshall would not make inofficial visits to discussofficial business. Pickering.
Want of distance o [Obs.] Bp. Pearson.
Redoubled; repeated. Jer. Taylor.
The state or property of being indivisible or inseparable;inseparability. Locke.
To place in a tomb; to bury; to entomb. See Entomb.
A patient who receives lodging and food, as well as treatment,in a hospital or an infirmary; -- distinguished from outpatient.

A nonmetallic element, of the halogen group, occurring alwaysin combination, as in the iodides. When isolated it is in the form ofdark gray metallic scales, resembling plumbago, soft but brittle, andemitting a chlorinelike odor. Symbol I. Atomic weight 126.5. Ifheated, iodine volatilizes in beautiful violet vapors.

A prefix from Eng. prep. in, also from Lat. prep. in, meaningin, into, on, among; as, inbred, inborn, inroad; incline, inject,intrude. In words from the Latin, in- regularly becomes il- before l,ir- before r, and im- before a labial; as, illusion, irruption,imblue, immigrate, impart. In- is sometimes used with an simpleintensive force.
Unsubstantiality; unreality. [R.]
Pertaining to the ileum and colon; as, the ileocolic, orileocæcal, valve, a valve where the ileum opens into the largeintestine.
In an intolerant manner.
A crystalline hydrocarbon derivative, metameric with orcin, butproduced artificially; -- called also cresorcin.
Not manifest. [Obs.] Sir T. Browne.

Not permitted or allowed; prohibited; unlawful; as, illicittrade; illicit intercourse; illicit pleasure.One illicit . . . transaction always leads to another. Burke.-- Il*lic"it*ly, adv.-- Il*lic"it*ness, n.
Inventive. [Obs.]
Untamable. [R.]
A complex nitrogenous substance, which, by Hermann'shypothesis, is continually decomposed and reproduced in the muscles,during their life.
Lustful; lewd; salacious; indecent; obscene.

To goad or urge forward; to set on; to provoke; to incite; --used chiefly with reference to evil actions; as to instigate one to acrime.He hath only instigated his blackest agents to the very extent oftheir malignity. Bp. Warburton.
The act of interfusing, or the state of being interfused.Coleridge.
Not prepared or mediated beforehand; extemporaneous. [Obs.]Jonhson.
Not edible; not fit for food. -- In*ed`i*bil"i*ty (#), n.
Indolence. [Obs.] Holland.

The fusion of a female germ cell (ovum) with a male germ cell(in animals, a spermatozoön) to form a single new cell endowed withthe power of developing into a new individual; fertilization;fecundation.
Beginning to be, or to show itself; commencing; initial; as,the incipient stage of a fever; incipient light of day.-- In*cip"i*ent*ly, adv.
The state or quality of being interested; selfishness.Richardson.
The quality or state of being intentional; purpose; design.Coleridge.
The quality or state of being irreconcilable;irreconcilableness.
Connection by marriage; reciprocal marriage; giving and takingin marriage, as between two families, tribes, castes, or nations.
A failure to recognize; absence of recognition. Lamb.
To engrave; to carve; to sculpture. [Obs. & R.] Shak.Which he insculped in two likely stones. Drayton.
To stain; to paint; to daub.

Unlimited; not bounded or restricted; undefined. Infinitivemood (Gram.), that form of the verb which merely names the action,and performs the office of a verbal noun. Some grammarians make twoforms in English: (a) The simple form, as, speak, go, hear, beforewhich to is commonly placed, as, to speak; to go; to hear. (b) Theform of the imperfect participle, called the infinitive in -ing; as,going is as easy as standing.
Between the radii, or rays; -- in zoölogy, said of certainparts of radiate animals; as, the interradial plates of a starfish.
Having the quality of cutting; incisor; incisive.
Pictured; impressed. [Obs.] Spenser.
Capable of being indorsed; transferable; convertible.

A glucoside obtained from woad (indigo plant) and other plants,as a yellow or light brown sirup. It has a nauseous bitter taste, adecomposes or drying. By the action of acids, ferments, etc., itbreaks down into sugar and indigo. It is the source of naturalindigo.
The extreme radicals; the party of the irreconcilables.
Imprisoned. Dr. H. More.
To seek or search out. [Obs.]
To involve one within another; to twist or coil together.Milton.

Situated or occurring within an inclosure; shut off from publicsight; private; secluded; retired.I have no Turkish proclivities, and I do not think that, after all,impaling is preferable as a mode of capital punishment tointraparietal hanging. Roll
Not separate; together; united. Shak.
Unexpected. [Obs.]
Insatiably. Sir T. Herbert.
Unfruitful; not producing young; barren; infertile. [Obs.]Evelyn.
Change; alteration; mutation. [R.] Dr. H. More.
See Inlard.
Having the quality of isotrimorphism; isotrimorphic.
The quality or state of being implacable.
The state of being intimate; close familiarity or association;nearness in friendship.

Not personal; not representing a person; not havingpersonality.An almighty but impersonal power, called Fate. Sir J. Stephen.Impersonal verb (Gram.), a verb used with an indeterminate subject,commonly, in English, with the impersonal pronoun it; as, it rains;it snows; methinks (it seems to me). Many verbs which are notstrictly impersonal are often used impersonally; as, it goes wellwith him.
Suitable for, or pertaining to, inauguration. Johnson.

Not elegant; deficient in beauty, polish, refinement, grave, orornament; wanting in anything which correct taste requires.What order so contrived as not to mix Tastes, not well joined,inelegant. Milton.It renders style often obscure, always embarrassed and inelegant.Blair.
With reference to industry.
Inflammatory.
Uncredited. [Obs.]
Not exhausted; not emptied; not spent; not having lost allstrength or resources; unexhausted. Dryden.
To indulge. [R.] Sandys.
A leaning; pressure; weight. [R.] Sir T. Browne.
The person insured. Champness.
Want of festivity, cheerfulness, or mirth; dullness;cheerlessness. [R.]
A female worshiper of idols.
One who intervenes; especially (Law), a person who assumes apart in a suit between others.
That property in virtue of which two portions of matter can notat the same time occupy the same portion of space.
Idiocracy.
Improvidently. [R.]
The system of writing in ideographic characters; also, anythingso written.
The act of making unlucky; misfortune; bad luck. [Obs.] Bacon.
By imputation.
Pertaining to, or designating, an acid obtained from atropine,and isomeric with cinnamic acid.

Designed to imitate another species of animal, or a plant, orinanimate object, for some useful purpose, such as protection fromenemies; having resamblance to something else; as, imitative colors;imitative habits; dendritic and mammillary forms of minerals areimitative.-- Im"i*ta*tive*ly, adv.-- Im"i*ta*tive*ness, n.
Not disputable; incontrovertible; too evident to admit ofdispute.
Incidence. [Obs.] Shak.
Not felonious, malignant, or criminal. G. Eliot.
To look into or within; to view the inside of. Bailey.
In a ill manner; badly; weakly.How ill this taper burns! Shak.Ill fares the land, to hastening ills a prey, Where wealthaccumulates and men decay. Goldsmith.
In an imminent manner.
The condition or quality of being indisposed. [R.] Bp. Hall.
Having colors like those of the rainbow; iridescent. Holmes.
Not destructible. [Obs.] -- Im*per"di*bly, adv. [Obs.]
Ill desert. [R.] Addison.
Not admitting relief; incurable; hopeless.
The quality of being impersonal; want or absence ofpersonality.
To put in a state of inflammation; to produce morbid heat,congestion, or swelling, of; as, to inflame the eyes by overwork.
The state of being immense.
Not apposite; not fit or suitable; not pertinent.-- In*ap"po*site*ly, adv.
Unburied. [Obs.]
Not frugal; wasteful; as, an infrugal expense of time. J.Goodman.
A cutting off, through, or asunder; interruption. [R.] Sir T.Browne.
To come between. [R.]Self-sown woodlands of birch, alder, etc., intervening the differentestates. De Quincey.
Not convincible; incapable of being convinced.None are so inconvincible as your half-witted people. Gov. of theTongue.
To surround or encompass as with a wreath. [Written alsoenwreathe.]Resplendent locks, inwreathed with beams. Milton.
Produced by the action of fire, as lava. [R.]
Want of sleep; inability to sleep; wakefulness; sleeplessness.
An inhabitant. Spenser.
A tendency or propensity to permanent residence in a place orabode; love of home and country.
One who intrudes; especially, one who favors the appointment ofa clergyman to a parish, by a patron, against the wishes of theparishioners.
Want of use; disuse. [R.] Paley.
The state or quality of being imitable; worthness of imitation.
Uncertain; doubtful; unsteady.-- In*cer"tain*ly, adv.Very questionable and of uncertain truth. Sir T. Browne.
To naturalize. [R.]

To lead astray as if blind; to persuade to something evil bydeceptive arts or flattery; to entice; to insnare; to seduce; towheedle.Yet have they many baits and guileful spells To inveigle and invitethe un unwary sense. Milton.
Not evident; not clear or obvious; obscure.
One who inherits; an heir.Born inheritors of the dignity. Milton.
One who or that which intensifies or strengthens; inphotography, an agent used to intensify the lights or shadows of apicture.
With intermissions; in an intermittent manner; intermittingly.
One who has constant day duties on board ship, and keeps noregular watch. Totten.
Plumage; feathers.
One who indulges. W. Montagu.
Want of subjection or obedience; a state of disobedience, as togovernment.
Not receiving; incapable of receiving.
The state or quality of being iOf every species of incredulity, religious unbelief is the mostirrational. Buckminster.
Incapable of being diminished. [R.] Milton.

In like degree; in like manner; seeing that; considering that;since; -- followed by as. See In as much as, under In, prep.Inasmuch as ye did it not to one of the least of these, ye did it notto me. Matt. xxv. 45.
One who, or that which, inks; especially, in printing, the pador roller which inks the type.
Insanity; madness.
Not memorable; not worth remembering. Johnson.
In an intricate manner.
Consisting of a short syllable followed by a long one, or of anunaccented syllable followed by an accented; as, an iambic foot.
Exhibition of colors like those of the rainbow; the quality orstate of being iridescent; a prismatic play of color; as, theiridescence of mother-of-pearl.
Shining in. South.
The act of imbuing; the state of being imbued; hence, a deeptincture.
Inland. [Obs.] T. Reeve(1657)

The quality or condition of being instrumental; that which isinstrumental; anything used as a means; medium; agency.The instrumentality of faith in justification. Bp. Burnet.The discovery of gunpowder developed the science of attack anddefense in a new instrumentality. J. H. Newman.
One who insnares.
Indeed; truly. See Ywis. [Written also iwys, iwisse, etc.][Obs.] Ascham.
A passage; esp., the passage between the third and fourthventricles in the brain; the aqueduct of Sylvius.
Inexhaustible. Thomson.
Not contested. Addison.
Given to investigation; inquisitive; curious; searching.
To intervene; to come or occur in the meantime. [Obs.] Shelton.
Cut or stamped in, or hollowed out by engraving. "Irregularincuse square." Dr. W. Smith.
The same as Isocheim.
One who, or that which, insures; the person or company thatcontracts to indemnify losses for a premium; an underwriter.
See Entrap. Spenser.
Isocrymal.
To flow in. Wiseman.
To register; to enter, as in a register. [R.] Walsh.
Not transitive; not passing over tas, an intransitive verb, e.g., the bird flies; the dog runs.
One who holds the doctrine of impanation.
In a manner tending to inflate.
Unsociably.
Not adequate; unequal to the purpose; insufficient; deficient;as, inadequate resources, power, conceptions, representations, etc.Dryden.-- In*ad"e*quate*ly, adv.-- In*ad"e*quate*ness, n.
Unseasonably. [Obs.]
The quality or state of being irrelative; want of connection orrelation.
Ill-bred. Shak.
A popular name for mica, especially when in thin sheets.
Not valorous; cowardly.
Unfashionable. [Obs.] Beau. & Fl.
The act of pursuing; pursuit; harassment; persecution. [Obs.]Sir T. More.
In an irreproachable manner; blamelessly.
To do the first act; to perform the first rite; to take theinitiative. [R.] Pope.
Strength; health. [Obs.]
of Inlay.
Having the quality of impelling.
Uncertainty; doubtfulness; doubt.The incertitude and instability of this life. Holland.He fails . . . from mere incertitude or irresolution. I. Taylor.
Between planets; as, interplanetary spaces. Boyle.
Idiopathic. [R.]
Not purified according to the ceremonial law of Moses; unclean.
A morbid state or condition not preceded or occasioned by anyother disease; a primary disease.
Of or pertaining to, or producing, indoxyl; as, indoxylic acid.
A plant with a conspicuous, dry, unwithering involucre, as thespecies of Antennaria, Helichrysum, Gomphrena, etc. See Everlasting.
Want of elasticity.
In an inconsistent manner.
Same as Intuitionalism.

The quality of being impatient; want of endurance of pain,suffering, opposition, or delay; eagerness for change, or forsomething expected; restlessness; chafing of spirit; fretfulness;passion; as, the impatience of a child or an invalid.I then, . . . Out of my grief and my impatience, Answeredneglectingly. Shak.With huge impatience he inly swelt More for great sorrow that hecould not pass, Than for the burning torment which he felt. Spenser.
In an irrestible manner.
A state of not being exposed.
The act of incapacitating or state of being incapacitated;incapacity; disqualification. Burke.
In an immitigable manner.
One who treats of ideas; one who theorizes or idealizes; oneversed in the science of ideas, or who advocates the doctrines ofideology.
Misapplied; treated badly.
To point; to mark with stops or pauses; to punctuate. [R.]Her sighs should interpoint her words. Daniel.
A pasture or meadow; generally one lying low, near a river.[Obs. or Prov. Eng.]
The quality or state of being incommensurable. Reid.
The state of being impaired; injury. "The impairment of myhealth." Dryden.
One who, or that which, irons.

The condition of being inane; emptiness; want of fullness, asin the vessels of the body; hence, specifically, exhaustion from wantof food, either from partial or complete starvation, or from adisorder of the digestive apparatus, producing the same result.Feeble from inanition, inert from weariness. Landor.Repletion and inanition may both do harm in two contrary extremes.Burton.
Very great; huge; vast; also, monstrous in character; inhuman;atrocious; fierce. [Obs.] "So immane a man." Chapman.-- Im*mane"ly, adv. [Obs.]
In a manner or to a degree that can not be repressed.
One who holds to inspiration.
To write between. [R.]
A gaping after; eager desire; craving. [R.] Bp. Hall.
A tall weed with purplish flowers (Vernonia Noveboracensis).The name is also applied to other plants of the same genus.

The act of exciting, or the condition of being excited toaction, by stimulation; -- as, the condition of an organ of sense,when its nerve is affected by some external body; esp., the act ofexciting muscle fibers to contraction, by artificial stimulation; as,the irritation of a motor nerve by electricity; also, the conditionof a muscle and nerve, under such stimulation.
Characterized by a current which flows inward; as, theincurrent orifice of lamellibranch Mollusca.
A shining between or among. [R.] Smart.
A dwelling or standing on something; fixedness; persistence.[Obs.] Shak.
An inhabitant. [R.] Derham.
One who inlays, or whose occupation it is to inlay.
The act of imparting, or that which is imparted, communicated,or disclosed. [R.]It beckons you to go away with it, As if it some impartment diddesire To you alone. Shak.
To bring into peril; to endanger.
Irresistible. [Obs.] Glanvill.
Excitable; susceptible of strong emotion.
To have time before pleading; to have delay for mutualadjustment. Blackstone.
The state or quality of being irreversible; irreversibleness.
Iranian.
Not observable.
Indulgence. [R.] Wood.
A mental act or process; especially: (a) The act ofunderstanding; simple apprehension of ideas; intuition. Bentley. (b)A creation of the mind itself. Hickok.
That loss of character, or public disgrace, which a convictincurs, and by which he is at common law rendered incompetent as awitness.
Inconsiderateness; thoughtlessness. [Obs.] Chesterfield.

A paper having on it these letters, with a sum named, and dulysigned; -- in use in England as an acknowledgment of a debt, andtaken as evidence thereof, but not amounting to a promissory note; adue bill. Wharton. Story.
Incapable of being circumscribed or limited. Cranmer.
Between members or limbs; as, intermembral homology, thecorrespondence of the limbs with each other.
Making an angle with some line or plane; -- said of a line orplane.

Not consolable; incapable of being consoled; grieved beyondsusceptibility of comfort; disconsolate. Dryden.With inconsolable distress she griev'd, And from her cheek the roseof beauty fied. Falconer.-- In`con*sol"a*ble*ness, n.-- In`con*sol"a*bly, adv.
The representation of natural objects, scenes, etc., in such away as to show their most important characteristics; the study of theideal.
Any symptom or occurrence in a disease, which serves to directto suitable remedies.
Not capable of being calculated; beyond calculation; verygreat.-- In*cal"cu*la*ble*ness, n.-- In*cal"cu*la*bly, adv.
Destitute of strength, whether of body or mind; feeble;impotent; esp., mentally wea; feeble-minded; as, hospitals for theimbecile and insane.
Imposture. [Obs.] Fuller.
A small escutcheon borne within a shield.
To curtain. [Obs.]
Repetition; reduplication; reiteration. De Quincey.That Sacred ingemination, Amen, Amen. Featley.Happiness with an echo or ingemination. Holdsworth.
Incapable of being expresses in words; unspeakable;unutterable; indescribable; as, the ineffable joys of heaven.Contentment with our lot . . . will diffuse ineffable contenBeattie.
The state or quality of being invisible; also, that which isinvisible. "Atoms and invisibilities." Landor.
That portion of an electrical apparatus, in which is theinducing charge or current.
The act of impersonating; personification; investment withpersonality; representation in a personal form.
Incapable of weeping. [Obs.] Bailey.
Having the nature of an isothere; indicating the distributionof temperature by means of an isothere; as, an isotheral chart orline.
An artificial ulcer, usually made in the fleshy part of the armor leg, to produce the secretion and discharge of pus for the reliefof some affected part.
In an immature manner. Warburion.
The state of being internal or within; interiority.
Between the scapulæ or shoulder blades.
Not correctly; inaccurately; not exactly; as, a writingincorrectly copied; testimony incorrectly stated.
The act or the process of inspissating, or thickening a fluidsubstance, as by evaporation; also, the state of being so thickened.
One who intrigues.
Unfit for respiration; not having the qualities necessary tosupport animal life; as, irrespirable air.
To take in; to absorb. [Obs.]
Characterized by invection; critical; denunciatory; satirical;abusive; railing.
In an imperious manner.
The quality of
Not sanitary; unhealthy; as, insanitary conditions of drainage.
A cutting in; incisure; incision.
To defile; to pollute; to contaminate; to befoul. [Obs.] Sir T.Browne.
See Entice.
Of or pertaining to iatrochemistry, or to the iatrochemists.

Any damage or violation of, the person, character, feelings,rights, property, or interests of an individual; that which injures,or occasions wrong, loss, damage, or detriment; harm; hurt; loss;mischief; wrong; evil; as, his health was impaired by a severeinjury; slander is an injury to the character.For he that doeth injury shall receve that he did evil. Wyclif(Col.iii. 25).Many times we do injury to a cause by dwelling on trifling arguments.I. Watts.Riot ascends above their loftiest towers, And injury and outrage.Milton.
Without energy. [R.]

To deliver (something) to another in trust; to deliver to(another) something in trust; to commit or surrender (something) toanother with a certain confidence regarding his care, use, ordisposal of it; as, to intrust a servant with one's money or intrustmoney or goods to a servant.
Infertile; barren; unprofitable; unproductive. [Obs.] Glanvill.

One who, or that which, sends or conveys intelligence or news;a messenger.All the intriguers in foreign politics, all the spies, and all theintelligencers . . . acted solely upon that principle. Burke.
See Yttria.
Intimate connection. [Obs.] W. Montagu.
Not having being; not existing.
Ill-disposed. Byron.

White, glowing, or luminous, with intense heat; as,incandescent carbon or platinum; hence, clear; shining; brilliant.Holy Scripture become resplendent; or, as one might say, incandescentthroughout. I. Taylor.Incandescent lamp or light (Elec.), a kind of lamp in which the lightis produced by a thin filament of conducting material, usuallycarbon, contained in a vacuum, and heated to incandescence by anelectric current, as in the Edison lamp; -- called also incandescencelamp, and glowlamp.
The state or quality of being inviolate; as, the inviolacy ofan oath.
To come into a country of which one is not a native, for thepurpose of permanent residence. See Emigrate.
The state or quality of being indigestible; indigestibleness.
Not erudite; unlearned; ignorant.
The act of isolating, or the state of being isolated;insulation; separation; loneliness. Milman.
One who imposes upon others; a person who assumes a characteror title not his own, for the purpose of deception; a pretender. "Thefraudulent impostor foul." Milton.
Separate existence; individuality; oneness. Fuller.
Irishism. [R.] Jeffrey.
Destitute of an idea.
With a degree of guilt or folly beyond excuse or justification.Inexcusably obstinate and perverse. Jortin.
In an intelligent manner; with intelligence.
The inside sole of a boot or shoe; also, a loose, thin strip ofleather, felt, etc., placed
Unchanged. [Obs.]
The quality or condition of being impure; impurity. Milton.

The state, quality, or relation, of two or more isomericsubstances. Physical isomerism (Chem.), the condition or relation ofcertain (metameric) substances, which, while chemically identical (inthat they have the same composition, the same molecular weights, andthe same ultimate constitution), are yet physically different, as intheir action on polarized light, as dextro- and lævo-tartaric acids.In such compounds there is usually at least one unsymmetrical carbonatom. See Unsymmetrical.

A short poem; properly, a short pastoral poem; as, the idyls ofTheocritus; also, any poem, especially a narrative or descriptivepoem, written in an eleveted and highly finished style; also, byextension, any artless and easily flowing description, either inpoetry or prose, of simple, rustic life, of pastoral scenes, and thelike. [Written also idyll.]Wordsworth's solemn-thoughted idyl. Mrs. Browning.His [Goldsmith's] lovely idyl of the Vicar's home. F. Harrison.
A complex nitrogenous radical, C8H4NO2, regarded as theessential residue of a series of compounds, related to isatin, whicheasily pass by reduction to indigo blue.-- I*sat`o*gen"ic, a.
